QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPLOYMENT OF HMAS DARWIN IN PERSIAN GULF

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to reports today that the Government has decided to send HMAS Darwin back to the Persian Gulf region to participate in the enforcement of sanctions against Iraq. Will the Opposition be consulted about this deployment, as it has been in the previous deployments? Will the Prime Minister or the Minister be making a statement to Parliament about this deployment and any future deployments of this kind in the Gulf as the sanctions are still maintained?

—I would not believe that the current circumstances anywhere near equate with the circumstances of the initial commitment or the commitment of other ships that we made late last year. The commitment of HMAS Darwin here is just continuing an Australian flag presence in the Gulf whilst we await further resolutions of the United Nations Security Council. If the proposition is put seriously to me that this is a breach of faith or that we have not followed proper procedures, I would argue that the circumstances are different. Nevertheless, if Senator Durack is of that view I will entertain it and ensure that consultation occurs in future. I did not think that these circumstances, given the threat assessment, et cetera, were anything like they were last year. But, if it is Senator Durack's view that he would like to be consulted in a continuing way on these developments, I will undertake to do so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that there is obviously to be a continuing process of sanctions against Iraq for perhaps an indefinite period, I did ask whether there was going to be a statement in relation to that matter as well.

—Again, I refer to the previous part of my answer. It depends on the objective circumstances at the time and the seriousness of the decision. I deploy ships to different parts of the globe every day of the week almost, but I do not necessarily make a parliamentary statement on it. I would have thought it would come as no surprise to Senator Durack or anyone else that, as long as the United Nations sanctions are maintained in the Gulf, Australia should have a role to play. That may not be the view of every country.
—Canada has pulled its ships out.

—Yes and no. In any event, the last thing I want to see happen is only one country left to enforce the sanctions in the Gulf. That would be most unfair and it would develop the sort of paranoia that exists in some parts of the world when only one country is part of this sort of process. We would encourage as many of our allies as possible to have an ongoing presence in the Gulf until the United Nations deems that it is time for it to be wound back.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the Government's intentions with regard to the recognition of conscientious objection to military service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week Cabinet gave approval for me to introduce, probably in the spring session depending on drafting resources, legislation covering the area of conscientious objection. The legislation that I intend to introduce stems from the Government's response to a Senate committee report which considered a private member's Bill introduced into this chamber by my colleague Senator Tate, which first raised the issue of broadening the grounds for conscientious objection to military service. I acknowledge that this issue has been around for some time.

ANSWER.PARA: Specifically, the amendments will provide for the classes of person who may be called up in the time of the war to be prescribed by regulations rather than specified in the Act. This will have the effect of removing the discriminatory provisions now in the Act and provide flexibility to address our requirements for the future responses to threats at that time. It will provide a requirement for parliamentary approval prior to a call up proclamation being made. It will also provide comprehensive provisions within the legislation for conscientious belief.

The areas that we will cover will do the following: clearly define the term `conscientious belief'; provide the right for a person to claim exemption from compulsory service in a particular war or warlike operation; enable the establishment of new tribunals to determine claims of conscientious objection; provide for a review of tribunal decisions on the grounds of material change in circumstances; and finally, provide an appeal mechanism through the appropriate court system.

In addition, we will repeal the National Service Act 1951 and the National Service Termination Act 1973. I hasten to say that these Acts are already defunct. Should the question of conscription ever arise in this country, this Government will only consider it in circumstances of a direct threat to Australia. Before the rumour-mongers get going and misrepresent what I say, the Government has no intention, now or in the future, of introducing conscription.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In 1982 the now Treasurer and his senior Australian Labor Party colleagues described the Australian economy as being in a state of depression when the rate of unemployment reached 9.4 per cent. As the rate of unemployment today is at 9.9 per cent, using the Treasurer's own yardstick, is Australia in depression?

—I have said on a number of occasions in the Senate that the economy is deeply recessed at the present moment. Having said that, I do not see any advantage in playing verbal tootsies in here in respect of semantic issues of this kind.
—You did in 1982.
—In 1982, there was not only a high level of unemployment but also every other indicator, such as high inflation, falling about the then Government's ears--
—That does not signify a depression.

—It signifies incompetence in the case of the then Government. A whole range of indicators in 1982 were sufficient to induce a severe state of depression, as anyone who contemplated those indicators would know. In 1982, those in government were in a situation where they had a highly static economy which was over-regulated, which had not been subject to the wand of any structural adjustment at all. That Government had sat on its hands for seven years.
—You have really done well, haven't you?

—No doubt I will get an opportunity to answer a question from Senator Kemp on these issues. As I was just saying, structural adjustment in the Australian economy was necessary but it was delayed by people of conservative mind-set-the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia-hand in hand, walking down the maze of non-progress which they followed in those days. In terms of all these structural issues, no progress had been made at all, so I think we are entitled to be depressed.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, what test does the Government apply in addressing the question of whether the economy has moved from recession to depression?
—I do not think that that is an economic art form. I think that Senator Hill should probably look in the Oxford dictionary and come back and ask a question tomorrow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, in the context of Mother's Day just past and to correct a figure which the Parliamentary Library gave me last week. Does the Minister recall that in 1976 family allowance payments to mothers replaced the tax rebate for children? Was this in fact not a transfer from the hip pocket of the taxpayer father to the purse of the mother? Is it not a fact that, because of the lost value of family allowances since then, successive Federal governments have robbed the purses of mothers of $7 billion-and I emphasise that $7 billion-as distinct from the $18 billion that the Parliamentary Library gave me last week? It has given me the corrected figure today. Senator Grimes, the then Minister for Social Security, told the national economic summit conference:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that family allowances are not and were never meant to be a welfare program in the strict sense. Rather, they are designed to achieve a broad measure of equity in the tax transfer system between those with and those without dependent children.
In view of that comment, when is the Government going to restore the full value of family allowances, which are now only two-thirds of their 1976 value?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, the statement that former Senator Grimes made, that family allowances were not meant to be welfare payments, is as true today as it was when he made it. It was about recognising that families with children have special burdens placed upon them and it was an attempt to deal with those problems. I concur that it was not the case that family allowances were welfare payments. I have been asked whether successive governments have robbed mothers' purses, I think was the phrase, of $6 billion. Whatever we have our hands in, I hope we do not have our hands in mothers' purses around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In looking at the real value of family allowances, it is important to look at the packages as a whole. When one looks at the reforms to the tax system during the course of the last six or seven years, there have been some significant reductions in tax rates, which benefit all Australian families. I do not think one single benefit can be singled out. Currently in the portfolio, I am looking at all benefits, allowances and supplements. I will be making some recommendations on those allowances to the expenditure review committee of Cabinet. Unfortunately, I cannot share my thoughts on that with Senator Harradine at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, although initially I would have wished to ask it of the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is it true that the gemfish population has been rapidly and progressively depleted in recent years despite the setting of total allowable catch levels by Federal Government authorities-a TAC of 3,000 tonnes in 1988-89, a catch of only 2,000 tonnes; a TAC of 1,750 tonnes in 1990 but a catch of only 700 tonnes? Is it true that much of the fishing effort has switched to the orange roughy, for which a TAC of 24,000 tonnes has been set? How comprehensive is the research data which underpins the setting of this TAC of 24,000 tonnes? In view of the fact that this is a relatively new fishery, that the orange roughy has a lifespan, when not fished, of perhaps 100 years and is a very slow growing fish, what assurance can the Federal Government give that this fish will not follow the fate of the gemfish?

—Senator Coulter referred in his question to the fish the orange roughy in relation to the regulation of its catch versus the regulation of the catch of a gemfish. While I do represent the Minister for Resources in this place, I am not familiar with the actual limits on the catch of the orange roughy or the gemfish at the present time. The question is a bit of a roughy.
—Oh, what a compliment.

—No, I am not fishing for compliments. Since I do not have that particular detail at my disposal, I will inquire of the Minister whom I represent in this place of the detail and supply Senator Coulter with an answer in due course.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government have a commitment to manage Australia's fisheries on a sustainable basis? How far are Australia's fisheries from sustainability? How long will it take to bring them to sustainable management?
—The answer to the first of those supplementary questions is yes. I will take the second and third supplementary questions on notice.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald alleging that the Government has sent a secret mission to South Africa to discuss economic policy in post-apartheid South Africa. What is the purpose of this visit? Is it correct to describe it as a secret mission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing remotely secret about that visit, nor was it intended to be secret at any stage. It is just part of the ongoing process of developing a pattern of helpful cooperation with the future government of South Africa and rendering such assistance as we can in helping it to improve its policy processes and, in this instance, its capacity in relation to economic policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The background to the visit is the discussions that the Prime Minister had specifically on this subject with leaders of the anti-apartheid movement and, in particular, Nelson Mandela during his visit to Australia last year. The initiative in question reflects the Government's and, in particular, the Prime Minister's longstanding concern to encourage the development of a mixed free enterprise economy in post-apartheid South Africa.
We decided to explore with the African National Congress and other black groups a means of assisting those groups in developing further expertise in the formulation of economic policy with the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you talk to Buthelezi?

—We will be talking to Chief Buthelezi and others with a significant potential role in the future of the country, as we have in the past, with the specific aim of helping such groups to develop, as I said, moderate mixed economy options for post-apartheid South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: The team, which is led by Ross Garnaut, is visiting South Africa from 9 May to 16 May to look at what kind of assistance might be developed. Professor Garnaut is one of Australia's most highly respected economists, particularly in the field of development economics, with substantial international experience. The team is consulting with a wide range of people who will be influential in developing South Africa's post-apartheid economic policy. The visit was discussed with South African Government officials.

The team will be talking to such government officials, not just as a courtesy but also because of the understanding it has about the future of the economy and the contribution it can make to our understanding of what, in turn, we can contribute to developing further policy thought in that respect.

After the team has returned to Australia, it will present recommendations to government, and we will then decide on what assistance may be appropriate. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau will then be tasked to follow up on the Government's decision. It would be premature at this stage to speculate about what kind of assistance might be offered or how it would be provided before the team has completed its work.

The initiative, generally speaking, reflects the forward looking approach to relations with South Africa that Australia is now taking. This sort of cooperation is a very tangible way in which Australia can promote a democratic, non-racial and prosperous future for that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Administrative Services confirm that the Human Rights Commissioner has delivered verbal or written advice to the Government that the legislation to ban political advertising would breach Australia's international obligations by curbing freedom of speech?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Burdekin, has made his concerns known both publicly and privately from the time the Government announced our decision to introduce legislation to regulate political broadcasting and to provide for effective disclosure of political donations. He has provided the Government with advice based on his understanding of the Government's proposals, reflecting his concerns.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time we made the decision and drafted the legislation, we were satisfied that the issues raised by Mr Burdekin concerning freedom of speech had been considered. Since receiving the most recent advice from Mr Burdekin, I have sent him copies of the Bill, which he did not have earlier on, together with copies of the explanatory memorandum on the second reading speech. I will soon be meeting with him to discuss any concerns he might have following his consideration of the Government's Bill which, as honourable senators know, was introduced into the House of Representatives last Thursday night.

The advice of the Commissioner to the Government is part of the process of consultation with the Commission, which is ongoing. As such, I repeat that I will soon be meeting with Mr Burdekin to discuss any concerns he might have once he has had a chance to read the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister table the advice received thus far from Mr Burdekin and, if not, why not?

—I probably should have pre-empted that supplementary question. As I said, the advice from the Commission to the Government is part of our process of consultation with the Commission. It is ongoing and, as such, it would be inappropriate to table the Commission's advice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Will the Minister tell the Senate whether the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) has agreed to the purchase of a supercomputer? If so, what will the supercomputer be used for? Further, does the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation intend to create a supercomputer bureau at its Lucas Heights research laboratories near Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is yes. After a somewhat protracted period of negotiation, ANSTO has entered into an agreement with Fujitsu Australia for the purpose of installing a supercomputer. It will be installed at Lucas Heights in mid-year and it will be the first supercomputer to commence operations in New South Wales. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation research scientists will reap the benefits in carrying forward their research and development projects and in expanding their capabilities in areas such as advance materials, environmental sciences and industrial technology, in each area of which ANSTO has become more involved with private sector industry in the last few years.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of projects that relate to those three areas will involve the use of the supercomputer. However, ANSTO will not be using the equipment to its full capacity, and it is proposed that the supercomputer will be connected to the Australian Academic Research Network, making it accessible to universities and research groups. The power available to scientists will significantly enhance Australia's industrial innovation and help our management abilities. The bureau to be established by ANSTO will be run as a joint venture with Fujitsu Australia. The joint venture is known as Australian supercomputing technology. The contract with Fujitsu will also enable ANSTO to act as a technology bridge between Australia and Japan for research and development projects to the value of $5m over five years-that is by arrangement with Fujitsu. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation is currently arranging the sale, by tender, of the IBM mainframe which the supercomputer will replace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to last week's Australian Bureau of Statistics release showing a further horrendous increase in unemployment and I also refer him to the Government's preparations for the forthcoming Premiers Conference. I ask, firstly, what is the now expected Budget outcome for 1990-91? Secondly, what are the now expected outlays over the original Budget estimates for unemployment benefit payments in 1991? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short is able to ask this question because this Government does publish forward estimates of outlays, as distinct from other governments of the past. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When those revised estimates are completed, will he undertake to provide them to the Senate?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to constant claims that the employment agreement negotiated at Power Brewing in Brisbane is a triumph for the kind of enterprise bargaining proposed by the Opposition? Do these claims suggest that the agreement was negotiated outside the Industrial Relations Commission and that, as a result of the agreement, Power Brewing employees have achieved spectacular increases in pay and productivity? Can the Minister advise whether or not these claims are correct? If they are not correct, can he advise what this suggests about the credibility of the people who are making them and therefore of the enterprise bargaining proposals they are putting forward?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard, in the Hansard reports of 15 October 1990 and 17 April 1990 and on the Lateline program on 11 April 1990, has made in essence three claims: that the Power Brewing agreement was achieved outside the Industrial Relations Commission and is therefore a model; that it resulted in an 85 per cent lift in the productivity of that company; and that workers have between $8,000 and $10,000 per annum more because of that productivity agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been a fourth claim: that is, that Power Brewing has captured 20 per cent of the Queensland beer market in 3 1/2 years. I do not think anyone in the wildest of dreams would put that down to an enterprise agreement. To do so would be like saying that enterprise agreements can fix up foot and mouth disease, carbuncles and boils or a hole in the ozone layer. Market share is about taste, price and advertising, and I dismiss that claim from the list of claims.

The first claim, that the agreement was achieved outside the Industrial Relations Commission, is factually not true. The present award is an award of the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission. The original voluntary employment agreement, as it was called under the Bjelke-Petersen legislation, was required to be presented to the registrar of the Queensland Commission for approval, and it was. The present award is the brewing industry Power Brewing employees award. It was issued by the Queensland Commission, by Commissioner Edwards, on 24 April 1991. The first claim is factually incorrect, the allegation being made by Mr Howard.

The second claim, that the agreement resulted in an 85 per cent lift in productivity, is fraudulent. If it were true, by the way, there is no evidence that any employee of Power Brewing has received anything like any advantage out of such a dramatic lift. The company commenced its operations in December 1988 with new plant, new technology, and newly trained workers. The only way an 85 per cent comparison in productivity can be demonstrated over that time is by comparing the running-in phase, the trial phase, of the new plant, new technology and new workers to the full production phase of the plant. That would not be, in any sense, a reasonable comparison for older plants that did not start operation with those advantages. In fact, it is a fraudulent comparison, as I have said. No measurements have ever been produced to show a scientific basis for the 85 per cent claim that has been made.

The claim that there is a $8,000 to $10,000 payment more per worker is not true. Most workers employed at Power Brewing are at level 2 or level 1 of the award; that is, at the rate of $24,700 a year. That is comparable to the brewing industry award in Queensland of $21,330 a year. But Power Brewing workers work a 38-hour week compared with brewery workers, who work a 35-hour week. The hourly rate difference between both is a dollar an hour. But if all workers worked the same hours, a 38-hour week, then the difference between the take home pay of workers under the standard award and workers at Power Brewing is negligible.

The claim for an increase of $8,000 to $10,000 to Power Brewing workers can only be based on an assumption that all will reach level 7 of the award. That level is described as being payable to holders of degrees or diplomas in food technology or to people who are in senior management. The classification of level 7 does not appear in the general award, so there is no comparison of like with like. It would not even be an apples and oranges comparison; it is more like apples and kiwi fruit. It is just not a fair comparison to make.

While the Government applauds workers and employers getting together and planning how strategically they can increase productivity to reduce price, increase wages and improve a profit sharing, I do not think the Power Brewing agreement in terms of what Mr Howard has said can be sustained at all. On the three fundamental issues, he is just plain wrong. It has been through the Commission; it has not resulted in that productivity improvement; workers do not receive those money amounts that he is claiming. His arithmetic preparation or arguments here are either sloppy or deceitful; it is one or the other. If this is the rock on which Liberal industrial relations policy is built, then that policy is demolished by virtue of the facts in this case and has no standing. But that is not surprising, given the fact that these are the words of someone who has been a suburban solicitor and a politician all his life and has never worked in industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. We were told that the decision to construct the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was to be made in February of this year; we were then told it was to be made in June or July of this year. We are now told that the environmental impact statement (EIS) will not be completed until the end of July this year. Can the Minister assure the Senate that this long-awaited decision to construct a third runway will be made by October?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. In fact, I concur with the remarks that I noted in today's press by the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, who said that he was hoping there would be a decision certainly before the end of this year. The current situation, as Senator Brownhill knows, is that the EIS process is under way. It is quite impossible for the Government to circumvent it, as I know Senator Brownhill also knows, and there is certainly no intention by the Government to do that. Thousands of submissions were received addressing the many complex issues that are associated with the construction of this runway.
—What complexities?

—I pause because I would like that interjection noted in Hansard. There is nothing complex, says Senator Parer, about the third runway. That clearly can only come from someone who has not even taken the interest to read the draft EIS, which throws up the many complex issues that are posed by the construction of the third runway. Among the thousands of submissions received, some 14,000 separate issues have been raised, all of which under the EIS process are required to be addressed. That is precisely the reason why the process is set up. The issues involve dredging, the bedrock on which the runway will be based, noise, air pollution, air traffic management and the alternative arrangements associated with Badgerys Creek. They are in every sense of the word complex issues. Those issues will be addressed.

ANSWER.PARA: The expected completion of the EIS supplement will be achieved by the end of July or early August. In fact, 2 August has been set currently as the date by which Kinhills expect, should there be no other extraneous issue raised in the meantime, the completion of that EIS.

I might add that the reason the Premier of New South Wales made such an informed and reasonable statement as he did about the runway-even in the context of the New South Wales election campaign-is that the Government of New South Wales is closely involved, both at political and departmental level, in the progression of the EIS process. As soon as the EIS process is completed-and I do recognise Senator Brownhill's continuing interest in this matter and also in that of peak period pricing, about which I expect a question from him sooner or later--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am awaiting the reply you were going to give me.

—I can answer the question now and avoid another one by telling Senator Brownhill that the review of peak period pricing at Sydney Airport will be completed by the end of this month. As soon as the EIS process on the third runway at Sydney Airport is completed, the matter will go back to Cabinet for its final decision.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF STATE BANK OF VICTORIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. What are the implications of the recent sale of the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank for employees of the State Bank of Victoria? In particular, has the Minister placed an embargo on the redeployment, redundancy and retrenchment agreement negotiated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, the Australian Bank Employees Union and the Commonwealth Bank in December 1990, even though this agreement is inferior to redundancy pay rates available in the big private banks? Since it is argued by bank employee unions that an embargo is delaying the final pay-out to migrant liaison officers who have been in limbo since February and who have been under considerable stress and trauma, can the Minister advise when they will finally be able to get their lives in order? Finally, how does this retrenchment package compare with the average $100,000 per employee-which goes as high as $180,000 per annum-plus leave and superannuation which was given to waterfront workers in the Commonwealth Government's reform package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth has not placed an embargo on the Commonwealth Bank. That is not an accurate description of what has happened. The facts of the case are that last year the Commonwealth Bank applied to me to propose to it a retrenchment package for redundancies arising out of the merger of the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria. Rather than me proposing a package for it, I asked the bank what it would propose to me as being a reasonable basis for redundancy. The Commonwealth Bank came forward with a package which I, in consultation with other senior Ministers in this Government, examined.

ANSWER.PARA: We recognised immediately that that package would have broken the Commonwealth standard redundancy provisions. However, we made a decision to allow the bank to go forward with that package and negotiate it with the unions on the basis that it did reflect standards in the private sector of banking and finance but that the package that it was proposing did not lead and was not the best, nor the worst, in the banking and finance sector. Because it was in the medium range we agreed to it and I issued to the Commonwealth Bank, as negotiating parameters, the package that it had asked for.

What has happened is that the Commonwealth Bank exceeded those parameters in the negotiations and did not inform the Government that it had. We later discovered that it had exceeded those parameters. I have now had discussions with the Managing Director of the bank and with the relevant unions and I have told them that the Government will not vary its instructions and that the Commonwealth Bank is to renegotiate the agreement, in essence, because the bank, when it wished to exceed the instructions, did not come back to us and ask for new instructions; it just broke the arrangements that I had issued to it. That is not a situation that the Government will tolerate.

In the second part of the question Senator McLean asked about migrant liaison officers. The bank, by managerial decision at the merger, decided to make redundant 35 migrant liaison officers. That was a managerial decision, not a government decision. I have asked both the bank and the unions to give a high priority to settling the terms and conditions of their redundancy.

The honourable senator asked finally whether the package meets the $100,000 employee pay-out for the waterfront workers. It does not meet the waterfront standard. The waterfront package is a package which is designed for, and applicable to, the unique characteristics of the waterfront. The bank package is a package which is designed for, and applicable to, the unique characteristics of the banking and finance industry. I might also say that the airlines package, which I have approved, is applicable to the airlines sector and the Telecom Australia package and the rail package are both applicable to their particular sectors.

What the Government has done here is to devolve more autonomy to government business enterprises to enable them to compete within the sectors in which they exist but on the basis that they do not leave those sectors with the best pay-outs, nor do they trail, but are in the middle range of those sectors. With that more relaxed coordination we expect that the particular deals that government business enterprises will reach reflect the sector in which they operate.

We will not be party to cross sector leapfrogging in which, because a deal for a government business enterprise is better in one sector than in another sector, the claim can be made that they are all government business enterprises and they should all observe the same standards. The requirement is that with the devolved responsibility they relate to their sector and we will resist any effort to try to pick the best standards out of the whole government area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: as Minister responsible for industrial relations when Australia has the largest number of unemployed ever in its history, and presiding over a high unemployment policy which was verified by the extra 350,000 Australians who have become unemployed during the past 18 months of this Government has he, his Department, or anyone else for the Government made any and, if so, what estimates of how many more Australians will become unemployed because of the enforcement of the accord mark VI?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the premises upon which this question is based. One of the variables that Senator Lewis has not included to arrive at his conclusions in this question is the level of participation rate. It is a fact that if the participation rate that we now enjoy-one of the record levels of participation rates in the Australian economy-were at the level suggested, unemployment would be much higher than it is now.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that we have expanded and grown the economy and have got more people aged between 18 years and 65 years in the work force than ever before is one of the reasons that unemployment is as large as it is. Having said that, I must also say that in no way means that we do not take seriously the level of unemployment and the hardship it visits on people.

In the second part of Senator Lewis's question he asks about accord mark VI. What needs to be understood by the Opposition and, indeed, some independent commentators is that accord mark VI is in three parts. The first part is a $12 flat rate increase which is in exchange for a continuance and a bringing to conclusion of award restructuring, which is one of the great reforms that have occurred in industrial relations under this Government.

The second part of the accord is to deregulate or to decentralise the wage fixing system to one based more upon an enterprise focus, something for which employers, unions and the Government asked the national wage case bench to issue guidelines. Those negotiations at that level are about sharing the advantage of achieved productivity and profitability.

As a consequence, the accord direction is to lower unit labour costs and to achieve out of the greater productivity an increase in wages, an increase in profits and a reduced price to consumers for the good or service offered by a company. That is a positive way of fighting the difficulties of a recession and generating that productivity to claw our way out of the recession, and is not a negative factor.

The third area attends to the issue of superannuation, the options of which the Government is currently examining. That package as a whole is not a package that will generate more unemployment; it is a package that will generate growth and higher productivity in the economy and is thus a beneficial package for the economy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PASSENGER SAFETY ON BUSES AND COACHES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the progress that is being made with the Government strategy to improve passenger safety on buses and coaches?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following information in relation to Senator Zakharov's question. The Federal Government has been working intensively on the issue of heavy vehicle safety since 1987. The tragic coach crashes on the Pacific Highway focused further attention on this issue. The Federal Government has now put into place a package of Australian design rules aimed at providing improved protection for occupants in the event of a crash as well as helping to avoid crashes.

ANSWER.PARA: Front row and exposed seating positions in light and heavy coaches will have to be provided with seat belts. Buses and coaches will have to comply with new regulations covering seat strength, seat anchorage strength and padding. Light buses in the 3.5 to 5-tonne range will have to comply with the standard from January 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that apply to school buses?

—Yes. Australia is the first country to implement the requirements of the latest international standard for bus roll-over strength. This will bring about significant strength in new bus and coach structures. The heavy vehicle design improvement package also includes the introduction of speed limiters for heavy buses and coaches.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian design rule 6500 takes effect from July 1991. This design rule requires that heavy buses and heavy goods vehicles be fitted with speed limiting devices to limit their maximum speed to 100 kilometres per hour.

Other areas of activity in heavy vehicle standards are anti-lock braking and vehicle lighting. Work is advanced on proposals to extend anti-lock braking requirements and improve braking standards on all buses and coaches above 14.5 tonnes gross vehicle mass. The Australian design rule package for vehicle lighting comes into effect in October this year.

Crash investigations have revealed the need to examine further the issue of occupant restraint. The Minister for Land Transport has asked the Federal Office of Road Safety to investigate the feasibility of installing seat belts in all seating positions as a matter of urgency. The Vehicle Standards Advisory Committee has studied the technical implications of fitting three-point seat belts in all seating positions and a draft Australian design rule will be issued this month for public comment.

The bus and coach safety package shows the Federal Government's commitment to make bus and coach travel as safe as possible. It also demonstrates the Government's commitment to take the lead with these issues. When the package is fully implemented, Australian standards will be among the highest in the world.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport seen the report of a study by the Queensland Council of Parents and Citizens Associations Inc. claiming that up to 100 Australian children per week are injured or killed on their way to and from school, with accidents involving children as passengers, pedestrians and cyclists? Bob Brown to put school travel on the agenda of the next Federal-State Ministers conference so that a unified national school travel safety project can be developed?

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade indicate the Government's response to the policy changes announced by the United States (US) concerning the chemical weapons convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, President Bush announced some quite major changes in the United States policy toward the negotiations in Geneva on the chemical weapons convention. The principal changes announced included: that the negotiators should set a target of the end of 1991 to resolve the outstanding issues in the negotiations with a view to final completion of the treaty by this time next year; secondly, that the US would forswear the use of chemical weapons by way of retaliation against any country for any reason once the convention is in force; thirdly, that the US would provide an unconditional assurance to destroy all its chemical weapons stocks and production facilities within 10 years of the treaty's entry into force and not retain any stockpile of its own; and finally, that the United States would intend to become an original signatory to the convention.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia very warmly welcomes these new elements in the US policy toward the convention. We fully share the objective of concluding the negotiations as soon as possible. We believe that the changes announced are important. We have been encouraging the United States in these various directions for some time. The US announcement should provide a significant impetus to concluding the negotiations.

We intend to continue taking a leading role in those multilateral negotiations in Geneva. The prospects for early finalisation of the treaty have been enhanced by the announcement in Washington yesterday. We believe that it would be desirable to hold a ministerial meeting of the conference on disarmament, this year if possible, aimed at resolving the remaining difficult issues which still require a political input. The US announcement does clear a good deal of the remaining ground and, in doing so, sharpens the focus on the remaining issues and it reinforces, in our judgment, the desirability of there being such a meeting.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled, Aboriginal Development Commission-Legal costs in relation to a Senate privileges matter, May 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Today I table a report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled, Aboriginal Development Commission-Legal costs in relation to Senate privileges matter. This matter was referred to the Committee in November 1989. A motion was moved during the committee stage of debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989. It was moved as a result of an answer provided by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) to a question asked during the examination of the 1989-90 Budget Estimates by Senate Estimates Committee E. The answer disclosed that the ADC had paid more than $160,000 for legal representation of itself and various other parties involved in an inquiry by the Senate Committee of Privileges. The terms of reference required the Committee to investigate the level of and justification for these legal expenses.

The inquiry was concerned with the fees charged by lawyers representing members of the ADC and various other parties. They were represented before the Senate Committee of Privileges by lawyers of considerable standing, and it is to be expected that the charges made by them would be substantial. The Committee agrees that people should be properly represented before the Senate and bodies of the Senate. Proper representation includes senior counsel, eminent juniors and outstanding solicitors. The Committee understands that these must be paid for. However, it is appropriate for the Senate to scrutinise the fees paid to professional people preparing cases brought before it and its committees and appearing before those bodies.

The Senate has the power to regulate its own proceedings and those of its committees. This includes the inherent power to scrutinise the fees charged by professionals who prepare the cases of and appear for the people before its committees.

In this case it had a further responsibility. The people involved in the inquiry of the Senate Committee of Privileges had lawyers who were paid for by the Aboriginal Development Commission. This is a body funded from Consolidated Revenue. Accordingly, it was proper for the Senate to examine how the funds were spent. The Committee sought the advice of a legal cost consultant in preparing this report. Given the nature of the task that the Committee was required to undertake, it felt that it was incumbent upon it to consider expert advice to enable it to report to the Senate. The Committees's findings are set out in the report at page (ix). In addition to these findings, the Committee has recommended that a Commonwealth agency seeking to engage legal representation from the private sector require a detailed bill of costs as a matter of course.

Both in this inquiry and in the Committee's larger inquiry into the costs of legal services and litigation, the Committee has been made aware of problems associated with lawyers' abbreviated bills of cost. A detailed bill would assist agencies which are spending taxpayers' moneys in meeting their obligations and ensuring that the expenditure of that money is properly accounted for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the report of the Committee entitled Purpose built computer centre for Australian Customs Service, Bruce, ACT, and I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish to make a couple of brief comments and then I will seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks in Hansard. Very briefly, the Public Works Committee showed some concern as to the fact that the Customs facility was almost an absolute carbon copy of the facility being built for the Australian Taxation Office right alongside. It should be noted that there was a proposal to build a computer facility to be shared by at least four departments and, until some time in 1990, Customs and the Australian Taxation Office planned to share a facility.

Because Customs fell behind with its approval process, the two facilities ended up being side by side, and things such as power had to be shared separately. The Committee was very concerned about this and, in the report, we called on the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to conduct a review of all Commonwealth departments and authorities to ensure that, as far as practicable, facilities such as computer installations are collocated. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Tuesday 14 May 1991

The report I have just tabled proposes the construction of a two storey structure of approximately 3780 square metres gross floor area which will provide 1425 square metres of computer floor area and associated office space, staff amenities, loading dock, storage and plant rooms. The limit-of-cost estimate for the project is $16.9m at November 1990 prices.
The Committee has approved this project, but with reservations which relate principally to:
* the location of the proposed building on a site next to a similar facility being built for the Australian Taxation Office; and
* the arrangements for the power supply to the building.
The Committee received a considerable amount of material dealing with the proposed location of the Customs building next to the Taxation Office building which is currently under construction.

Evidence was given that since 1985 there had been attempts to build a computer facility to be shared by three or four departments. Until sometime in 1990, Customs and Tax were planning a shared facility; only when Customs fell behind in the approval process did the two facilities side by side become inevitable.

We accept that it is now too late to delay either project; we also accept evidence that amalgamation of both facilities would incur significant costs. On the other hand, we are of the view that substantial overall savings could have been made if both facilities had been in the same building from the earliest planning stage. Accordingly, we have recommended that the Minister for Administrative Services should conduct a review of all Commonwealth departments and authorities to ensure that, as far as practicable, facilities such as computer installations are collocated.

We believe this review is very important and should be undertaken as a matter of urgency because of the sums of money which could be involved. It is also important because of the long term and rational development of Commonwealth facilities which would result from it.

While at one time neither Customs nor Tax appeared to have any problems about sharing a facility, at a later stage in the planning process concerns were expressed about having them in the same building, because of the risks of industrial disputation or sabotage. The Committee found this an intriguing situation and believed it was an excellent example of a two way bet which could not be sustained. If the two facilities were at risk in the same building, we are at a loss to understand how that risk is reduced by having them in separate buildings on adjacent sites.

In our Sixth Report of 1990, dealing with the Taxation Office's computer centre, the Committee drew attention to the power supply arrangements for that building. In particular, we questioned the need for two independent high voltage supplies and asked that this be reviewed, because of the provision of other substantial backup facilities. The Committee was never informed whether there was a review or not.

The inquiry into this reference revealed the same independent power supply arrangement was required with similar backup arrangements. While we accept there must be backup arrangements, we are not convinced of the need for a double power supply. We also accept that this is a requirement of the supplying authority, not an additional item included by Customs. The Committee has therefore recommended that Customs and Australian Construction Services take up with the ACT Electricity and Water Authority its insistence that two independent power supplies be provided to computer installations.
I would now like briefly to consider some of the other issues which came up during this inquiry.

After the project was referred to the Committee, we became aware that the Joint Committee on the ACT was conducting an inquiry into proposals for the transport system to service a new part of Canberra, Gungahlin. One of the components of that system which was causing community concern was the route of a proposed major north/south road, John Dedman Parkway. This route could have been very close to the site proposed for the Customs building.

The Committee took evidence from the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the ACT Committee. I should mention, Mr Speaker, that it is quite unusual for one committee to ask members of another committee to give evidence. It was also perhaps unusual that they were so keen to appear before us. The Honourable Member for Fraser and Senator Margaret Reid did appear before us and, on behalf of the members of the PWC, I would like to thank them for their contribution.

As a result of our concerns, the planners at the national and the local level got together and produced an alignment which would not compromise the Customs site. The planners gave evidence that this proposed westerly alignment would meet their needs if, in fact, it was ever built. The Committee also received evidence that, provided appropriate precautions were taken, construction of the Parkway would not endanger either the Customs or Taxation buildings.

This Committee can only report to the Parliament on the reference it has received. It will be for the Joint Committee on the ACT to make a recommendation on the route for the John Dedman Parkway. The Australian Sports Commission forwarded two submissions which set out its concerns, principally reductions in car parking spaces and worsened access to this part of Bruce, if the Parkway was to be built on the westerly route. These are issues more appropriately dealt with by the Joint Committee on the ACT.

The Committee would like to acknowledge the contribution of community groups such as the North Canberra Protection Group. Its concerns with another possible route of the Parkway led to the delineation of this westerly option.

The Committee received a detailed submission from the Windass Hanmer Partnership in Sydney. This submission argued that the proposed Customs building was too expensive for what was needed and over-specified in many details.

The Committee sought additional information from Customs, Australian Construction Services and the Tax Office on the issues it raised in that submission. The Committee concluded that the Windass Hanmer Partnership was not able to sustain its views. SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991
This Bill would implement one of the most significant changes to the Australian system of social security since the 1940s.

It involves the end of the unemployment benefit program-a program which was created in a world very different from today's. It will see the introduction of a new strategy-the Newstart program-which will help us deal far more effectively with the pressing problems of the 1990s.

Mr President, I do not need to remind members of the urgent need for a program such as this at this time. We must not repeat the mistakes of 1982-83. Those who lost their jobs at that time were largely ignored. As a result, enormous damage was done to their skills and motivation and serious problems of poverty were created. When the recovery came, long term unemployment remained a serious problem that has taken many years of Government effort to tackle.

The major changes which are introduced in this Bill build on the successful reforms of recent years which have received widespread community support and produced far more effective outcomes for the unemployed. The job search allowance for youth and the initial NEWSTART program for the long term unemployed have clearly demonstrated the effectiveness of positive measures of assistance; and form the foundation for our new approach.

The Newstart program provided for in this Bill is a wide ranging strategy. It centres on the creation of two new payments-job search allowance and newstart allowance-which in turn involve new patterns of obligation, greater emphasis on training, increased responsibility for the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), and improved CES/DSS liaison.

Newstart is a major step forward in the integration of income support with labour market assistance. We recognise that it is simply not enough in these difficult times to provide people with income support and leave them to their own job search. We have to find out why people are having difficulty in finding work. We have to think about their prospects, not just immediately, but in the longer term. We then have to make serious attempts at dealing with their needs through training and other programs.

One of the keys to the success of this strategy, Mr President, therefore, is the availability of labour market programs. The Government has substantially increased the availability of these programs for the long term unemployed in recent years. As part of the Newstart program, an additional $227 million is to be provided for labour market programs until the end of 1993-94, giving over 50,000 additional program places each year. This increase will be supplemented by the $105 million expansion of labour market programs announced in the Prime Minister's March 1991 Industry Statement.

With the Newstart Program, we will not be repeating the disastrous social and economic policy of 1982-83. We will be working with unemployed Australians in the most effective way possible to ensure that they will share in the benefits of economic recovery. More than that, we will be working to improve the competitiveness of the Australian economy and its labour force. The Newstart Program integrates social and economic goals in a way which will build on Australia's proud reputation as an international leader in social policy.

In developing the arrangements for Job Search Allowance, a major aim is to help prevent long term unemployment wherever possible-to deal with problems before they become entrenched. Recipients will be required to participate in a labour market program or vocational training if this is likely to improve their chances of finding a job. The CES will provide early intervention assistance to job search allowance recipients within the first three months where it is needed. There will remain a strong focus on helping young people, and the current arrangements for 16 and 17 year olds will be incorporated into the Job Search Allowance provisions.

The Bill provides that Job Search allowees, like Newstart allowees, who start CES-approved training will continue to receive their job search payment together with the normal training allowances. Improving skills should be seen as an integral part of effective job search, particularly in the current economic situation. The change will help resolve some problems of interruption of income support that people have experienced under current arrangements when transferring from unemployment benefit to a training allowance.

When unemployment benefit was first introduced, and indeed for most of the first thirty years of its operation, long term unemployment was largely unknown. For the last ten years, however, it has been a major community problem. The introduction of Newstart Allowance for the long term unemployed will enable us to meet this problem in the specialised way that is needed.

Experience has shown that the key to tackling successfully the problems of the longer term unemployed lies in integration of income support and other forms of assistance. Since the Government upgraded efforts in this area, with the first phase of the Newstart program, the results have been striking. NEWSTART has also shown that concentrated efforts, utilising options from a range of available measures, to assist the long term unemployed can contribute to useful employment outcomes, even for persons in receipt of UB for 5 years or more. No country has found this problem easy to deal with but the figures show that significant numbers of people can be helped.

Between February 1989 and December 1990, 134,000 persons in the NEWSTART target group left unemployment benefit. During this time, around 75,000 unemployment benefit recipients have participated in labour market programs which will improve their employment prospects. The proportion of the unemployed who are long term fell from around 38% in February 1989 to 25% in November 1990.

Under the arrangements for Newstart Allowance, therefore, the CES will have greatly increased responsibility for the long term unemployed. Willingness to undertake training or take advantage of other program assistance will be a major condition of income support. The CES will, under delegation, administer the activity test for Newstart allowees.

The Newstart Program will see assistance and requirements tailored far more closely to individual needs and capacities. A key feature of the Newstart Allowance will be the Activity Agreement that recipients will have to enter into to receive the Allowance. In each case, the Activity Agreement will set out the steps that individuals will have to take to improve their employment prospects. There should be no misunderstanding about this. The Activity Agreement will be a requirement for payment. If a person is not prepared to enter into, and abide by, an Agreement they will not be paid Newstart Allowance.

Mr President, this is an initiative very much aimed at providing real hope and assistance to people. It offers scope to people to acquire skills so that they will be better placed when the labour market starts to improve. I should stress, however, that the Government is strongly of the view that acceptance by the community of increased obligation to help the unemployed must be accompanied by increased reciprocal obligations for the unemployed to take advantage of the Assistance available and so help themselves. Recipients of either Allowance who unreasonably refuse offers of assistance or make insufficient efforts themselves will have their payments suspended for a period, or cancelled. Job Search Allowance for those over 18 will be available for no more than twelve months. Transfer to Newstart Allowance is not automatic. These are firm signals that income support will be payable only where recipients' obligations are met.

The interests of the community will also be protected by continuation of the measures introduced by the Government in recent years within the Department of Social Security to reduce the risk of fraud and incorrect payment. The Department will maintain its efforts in this area through its program of interviews and reviews, computer data matching, mobile review teams and other strategies. Those receiving Job Search Allowance and Newstart Allowance will have to lodge a form in person each fortnight to continue payment. Compliance will be enhanced by significantly improved liaison arrangements with the CES and the increased contact with individuals that is an essential feature of the Newstart Program.

When the Newstart Program was announced in the February 1990 Economic Statement, it was estimated that the program would be a minor net cost to the Commonwealth in 1990-91 ($0.4m) with net savings of around $12.13m accruing in subsequent years.

The announcement of new labour market programs in the March 1991 Industry Statement and substantial changes to the UB parameters since early 1990 will change the overall cost savings of the program from the February 1990 estimates. However, net program savings are still anticipated from 1991-92.

There are those who would wish to deal with the problems of unemployment in a simplistic and socially and economically irresponsible way-by, for example, providing little or no program assistance and terminating benefits after a period regardless of whether a person has genuinely been able to find work.

This Government, however, has no intention of making scapegoats of the unemployed. The necessary measures to require reciprocal obligation on the part of the unemployed and to maintain the integrity of the system should be seen in the contest of the positive assistance and encouragement which will be provided. The Newstart Program is intended to address the real problems of the unemployed and work in their interest and that of the whole community.

Mr President, this Bill would also incorporate initiatives introduced during the Budget Sittings 1990 that would impact on the payability of Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance or the rate of payment at which a person is to be paid.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The Bill will amend the social security legislation to implement some relatively minor initiatives.

Mr President, the Social Security Act 1947 provides an assets test exemption for certain pre-paid funeral expenses. Generally, this involves a person entering into a contract with a funeral director where he or she pays over money and the funeral director agrees to provide a funeral service at some future time. However, some investment companies now offer funeral bonds. These allow people to set aside money for the payment of funeral expenses without necessarily committing themselves to a particular funeral director. Income accrues to such bonds. This Bill introduces an exemption from the income and assets tests for these bonds provided that the bond has a contribution limit of $5,000 or less per funeral and cannot be redeemed before maturity on the death of the investor or the investor's spouse. A person will not be able to benefit from both the exemption for funeral bonds and the existing exemption for pre-paid funeral expenses.

The definition of `income' in the Act at present does not exclude certain scholarship payments. As a result, a person could have a social security payment cancelled or reduced under the income test on receiving a scholarship payment. The Government has decided that, with effect from 1 September 1990, a scholarship awarded from outside Australia to a person is to be excluded from the person's income if the payment does not include any component for living expenses and if the Minister approves the scholarship payment for this purpose.

A recent decision of the Supreme Court of Victoria has cast some doubt on whether existing provisions of the Social Security Act enable the Commonwealth to recover social security payments from compensation payments where State or Territory legislation purports to make such compensation payments inalienable. This Bill makes it clear that the Commonwealth can recover social security payments in spite of such provisions in State or Territory legislation.
The Bill also makes some minor technical amendments to refine and clarify measures introduced in the last year.

Mr President, this Bill is one of several social security bills to be introduced during the current Sittings. Other bills will provide for the transition from the Social Security Act 1947 to the clear English Social Security Act 1991 and update the Social Security Act 1991 to take account of social security initiatives introduced in legislation during the Budget Sittings last year or in this Bill and provide for the implementation of initiatives announced in the 1990/91 Budget such as the NEWSTART strategy and disability reform.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991
This Bill will provide for the transition from the Social Security Act 1947 (the 1947 Act) to the Social Security Act 1991 (the 1991 Act).
The Bill will achieve four specific objectives. It will:
* repeal the 1947 Act;
* provide for the transition from the 1947 Act to the 1991 Act;
* consolidate all applicable savings provisions; and
* make consequential amendments to other Acts.

The overall aim of this Bill will be to achieve an uncomplicated transition so that the general administration of pensions, benefits and allowances will continue as normal under the legislative scheme of the 1991 Act. Social security recipients will not be disadvantaged by the transition.

The Bill will provide that where persons are receiving a pension, benefit or allowance they will continue to do so without having to lodge a new claim form. It will provide arrangements for the treatment of claims and reviews which had not been determined before the repeal of the 1947 Act. It will also provide for other administrative matters such as the continuity of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and its members.
The Bill does not have any financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

TRAINING GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The Training Guarantee requires employers to spend a minimum amount on training, broadly defined. It was established by legislation introduced into this House almost twelve months ago, and it came into effect on 1 July 1990.

The scheme was introduced by the Government in recognition of the pressing need for more and better quality training in Australia, to equip us with the highly skilled and flexible workforce we urgently need in order to compete in the international marketplace.

The Training Guarantee is a carefully constructed measure aimed at improving the training effort of businesses which did not, before its introduction, invest in training, or invested very little. Firms which already recognise the value of training and train above the required minimum level are affected very little.

An important objective of the Training Guarantee is to change industry attitudes towards training. For too long, many firms have regarded training as a cost to be minimised rather than as an investment from which they can expect measurable returns. Even firms which train their staff in times of economic buoyancy are inclined to jettison their training effort first, in times of economic downturn.

The Training Guarantee is designed to make our nation's training effort stronger-both in terms of quantity and quality-more equitable-so that ``good'' trainers are not disadvantaged by having their trained staff poached by ``bad'' trainers-and more consistent-so that at least a minimum amount of training is undertaken every year, and that economic recovery is not jeopardised by skill shortages.

The Training Guarantee has only been in force since 1 July 1990, so it is too early to make conclusive statements about the changes it has wrought in practice or attitude. The ABS Training Expenditure Survey, which is due to be released later this month, will provide the first conclusive data on changes in employer expenditure.

A quarterly survey conducted in NSW however, by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the State Bank, indicates that 45% of employers surveyed had increased their training expenditure in the September 1990 quarter, and that more than 90% had training plans in place.

Anecdotal evidence also indicates that there is a much greater level of interest in training among the business community than has been the case in the past. Certainly the Minister's office and the Department have received many enquires about the Scheme, and great interest has been shown in the registered industry training agent concept.

This Bill amends the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 to give effect to undertakings made by the Government in relation to outstanding trainers and to fees charged by industry training agents. It clarifies the intentions of the original legislation in several regards and makes some minor technical amendments to the provisions. It also makes provision for the recognition of alternative training levy schemes.

During the Second Reading Speech on the original Training Guarantee legislation, mention was made of the useful contribution during the process of consultation and development by the Australian Democrats, particularly their suggestions in relation to registered industry training agents and to the possibility of exemptions from the provisions of the Act for employers who are outstanding trainers.

This Bill will enable the establishment of a system to exempt outstanding trainers from the provisions of the Act. It provides that Regulations may be made which allow the Minister, among other things, to establish criteria against which the training effort of applicant employers may be measured, in order to award them outstanding trainer status.

The recognition of outstanding trainers will be a positive acknowledgment that some employers are committed to training and well exceed the minimum requirements of the Act. At the same time, it provides an incentive for other employers to achieve this status.

The criteria, to be set by Regulation, have been the subject of consultation with employer representatives and unions. Honourable Senators may recall that the Prime Minister announced, in his 12 March Economic Statement, that in order to achieve outstanding trainer status, and to qualify for exemption from the provisions of the Training Guarantee Act, employers will need to spend at least 5% of payroll on quality structured training.

The establishment of a system of Registered Industry Training Agents (now known as RITAs) was provided for in the original Training Guarantee (Administration) Act. This Bill makes some amendments to the way the system operates, on the basis of suggestions made to the Government by the National Training Board, by industry and, indeed, by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.

For example, the Bill allows RITAs and the training advisory body to charge fees on application for a certificate rather than, as in the original legislation, only when a certificate is issued. This amendment allows RITAs to charge a fee to recover their costs when a training program is assessed and found to be not an eligible training program, and a certificate is refused.

The Bill clarifies the status of RITAs while they are performing services for employers and issuing training advisory certificates. The Bill states that both RITAs and the training advisory body are, in this context, not agents of the Commonwealth. The provisions ensure that those bodies may charge fees in their own right.

Additional flexibility has been provided in fee-setting to allow RITAs to set fees according to circumstances. Rather than providing for a fixed amount, the Bill allows fees to be set on a sliding scale up to a maximum of $500. That maximum amount is automatically indexed. A provision has also been inserted which allows the training advisory body to deregister a RITA which overcharges.
The Bill makes absolutely clear that RITAs are covered by the existing secrecy provisions of the Act.
The Bill introduces two changes to the wording of the section which deals with the definition of ``eligible training programs''.

The first specifies that training programs which are not designed by a person with appropriate qualifications must be approved by such a person, in advance of their delivery. This was, in fact, the intention of the original legislation but was not specifically stated.

The second tightens the clause on objects of training programs and, in effect, ensures that an eligible training program has no significant object which is not training related. At the same time, the amendment ensures that structured on the job training with an unavoidable production element, which is otherwise eligible, will still be eligible training.

The Bill widens the definition of related companies who may elect to group, for Training Guarantee purposes, and to be treated as a single employer. Such an election has advantages in terms of record keeping and reporting, and this amendment will benefit certain corporations such as Commonwealth and State instrumentalities which were previously prevented from participating.

The Bill inserts provisions into the Act which restate the situation in relation to partnerships, unincorporated associations and trusts, to make clear on whom obligations fall, and by whom they may be discharged. New provisions relating to offences have been included which ensure that action can be easily taken in the event of a failure to fulfil obligations. It is also made clear that obligations are determined on a partnership by partnership, association by association or trust by trust basis.
The Bill also provides the basis for alternative training levy schemes to be recognised.

Some industries or industry sectors have expressed interest in implementing their own training levy schemes as an alternative to the Training Guarantee. The Minister has, in fact, indicated his willingness to consider such approaches on the basis of a number of conditions, not the least of which is the amount of money which will, as a result of such an alternative scheme, be spent on eligible training.

It is possible for an industry to be exempted from the provisions of the Training Guarantee, under existing legislation. This amendment, however, provides a more flexible basis for the regulation of such schemes, for the benefit of industries which prefer to be responsible for their own training needs.
In summary then, this Bill introduces some new aspects to the Training Guarantee in response to good ideas and suggestions which the Government has received since the Scheme's inception.
It also makes some amendments to current provisions to facilitate the administration of the Training Guarantee and to ensure that it achieves its objectives.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

What I find is probably the most sad thing of all in this whole sorry saga is the reflection that the Minister has cast upon professional diplomats and even some of the other political appointees by saying that he will now revise the whole procedure, criteria and method of operation of ambassadors just because one ambassador has done something wrong-not one thing wrong, but has committed a multitude of offences. So all career diplomats will now be put under scrutiny and have their rules changed because of Mr Burke's conduct.

Labor mates might be asked to resign when they are silly enough to go public, as Mr Burke did on 27 April when he gave the game away by saying that if he were not a Labor mate he would have been ditched `years ago'. The Minister might have disagreed with what Mr Renouf had said, but Mr Burke did not-he agreed that he would have been pelted out had he not been a mate.

Of course, what is even more sad for the taxpayer is what Mr Burke gets as a consequence. As it is, a Labor mate has pocketed three months salary for no work and gained a $28,000 severance payment on top of his free telephone calls, despite having resigned the first time rather than being sacked-but no doubt that was a protection against an unsympathetic coalition government when the contract was drawn up.
