TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating three Bills jointly-Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation Bill (No.5) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2)-all of which relate to the current financial year, 1990-91. They form the additional Budget estimates for this financial year. They cover the unexpected costs of government in running the administration of this country. Those costs were unexpected at the time the Budget was brought down last August and they complete the Budget for the year. The total amount of money in the Bills to be appropriated over and above that in the previous Budget Bills is about $1,000m. In addition to that, the three Bills provide savings of some $270m in relation to funds approved in previous Acts which give effect to this Budget for the current year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very unusual for us to have five Appropriation Bills in a financial year. Normally there are four but a special Bill was brought down in January-Appropriation Bill (No. 3)-to cover the unforeseen costs to the Australian Government of its involvement in the hostilities in the Persian Gulf. Appropriation Bill (No. 4) includes some $28m extra for Austudy and some $5m extra for emergency refugee programs. Appropriation Bill (No. 5) includes, for example, an extra $75m as grants to the States for natural disaster relief.

This afternoon, I would like to dispense with the financial facts and figures about these Bills and turn to the economic situation, which I will look at in some depth. I will also look at the changes in Government policy which have been given effect to over the last 12 months in order to level out our economic activity. In regard to the economic indicators, I would like to look at the current recession and at recent economic trends.

Certainly, last week there was a great deal of focus on the unemployment figures for April. These were of great concern to all Australians and are a great concern on this side of Parliament. It is understandable that people are concerned that unemployment has reached 9.9 per cent, because many of our Australian colleagues have lost their livelihood, and it is a very uncomfortable time for many Australian families. That 9.9 per cent unemployment rate is almost up to the levels of 1982-83 when unemployment reached a figure of 10.4 per cent. Of course, that period represented the worst recession that Australia has seen since the Great Depression in the 1930s.

However, there is something odd about the figures for the labour market for April in that, while there was a rise in the number of people out of work, the labour force participation rate showed an increase. That is most unusual at a time of recession. The participation rate, of course, represents that proportion of the Australian population of working age who are interested in actually being in the work force. The figures showed an increase of between 10,000 and 11,000 in the number of jobs at the same time that unemployment went to the rate of 9.9 per cent. But, of course, all these figures are preliminary and maybe the final figures for April will be adjusted so that we have a clearer picture of what happened in that month.

It is relevant to note that, at the same time as the unemployment rate went to 9.9 per cent in April, the Australia and New Zealand (ANZ) Banking Group Ltd brought out its regular monthly series on newspaper advertisements for employment in the major capital city newspapers. In that particular month, while unemployment was recorded as rising, for the first time in some months this series published by the ANZ Bank showed an increase in the number of newspaper advertisements for employment. In fact, in that month there was a 3 per cent rise in the number of advertisements in metropolitan daily newspapers regarding opportunities for employment. That was certainly a very interesting contradiction of the unemployment figures for that month.

However, as we all know in regard to economic management, there are substantial time-lags in the effect of economic policies. The high unemployment figures of today do not reflect the economic policies of today; they reflect the economic policies of 1990 because of time-lags. When a policy is changed it does not mean that economic variables such as investment, employment or unemployment change immediately. They take many months to feed through the system. What we are seeing today is the result of policies that no longer exist but which were in effect in the first half of 1990 and, of course, those policies were changed many months ago.

In 1990, we had very tight monetary policy. The Government through the Reserve Bank was selling bonds in order to reduce the amount of liquidity in the community. High interest rates were the result of that move and they were certainly the more evident result of those open market operations. At the time, 1990, official cash rates, interest rates, were 18.0 per cent. That is the sort of figure we had at the beginning of last year, not at the beginning of this year.

At the same time, again in 1990, we had extremely tight fiscal policy. We had a very large Budget surplus, that is, an excess of government revenue over government expenditure through the Commonwealth Budget. In fact, the outcome for last financial year was for a surplus of $8,000m. At the same time as there were high interest rates there was a surplus of $8,000m in the Commonwealth Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has disappeared; it is not there.

—It is something that the Liberals or the Nationals have never been able to do, that is, to actually develop a Budget surplus in recent times. Senator O'Chee parrots away naively on the other side but the National Party of Australia, of which he is a member, and the Liberal Party of Australia represented alongside him have not recorded a Budget surplus in this country for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: Last financial year we brought in our third consecutive Budget surplus, and it amounted to $8,000m. It was very unusual to have both tight monetary policy and tight fiscal policy represented through the Budget but that is the reason we had such tight economic conditions and why we now have relatively high unemployment rates. But those policies were not put forward in isolation. They were not developed on the whim of the Government. They were done for a very important reason, which the Opposition very studiously ignores and refuses to talk about, that is, that we have had an excess of import expenditure in Australia over our export proceeds. In other words, we have a deficit on our balance of payments on our current account.

In 1989, in particular, total spending in Australia went far ahead of the ability of the economy to produce. As a result of that excess of expenditure over domestic production, there was a spill over into imports which resulted in the rise in the current account deficit on our overseas balance of payments. Of course, that was not sustainable because either one runs down one's foreign currency reserves to fund such a deficit or one has to rely on a capital inflow to make it sustainable in the short or medium term.

The Government policy has been to slow down growth in the economy, to cut demand and, therefore, to cut the propensity of Australians to purchase imported products. That slowing in the demand for imports has been very successful indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was successful all right; it threw a lot out of employment.

—We will go on to the Liberals' record in a minute. Senator Panizza is asking for it and he is going to get it. We might look at the success of this particular policy because in the nine months to March 1990, that is, the first nine months of the 1990 financial year, the current account deficit was $17.6 billion. In the nine months to March this year, the deficit has been reduced to $13.4 billion and, of course, the Budget forecast for the year was $18 billion. So the current account deficit is coming well within the Budget expectation of $18 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: But more importantly than that, we have moved into surplus on physical trade for the first time in a long time. The actual balance of physical exports compared with physical imports has moved into surplus. In the first nine months of the current financial year, that is, to March this year, the total surplus now is $649m compared with a deficit of $4,200m in the first nine months of the previous financial year. So there has been a substantial turnaround in the balance of trade. It has gone from a deficit to a surplus-a turnaround approaching $5,000m, which is very welcome.

That is one of the tangible results of the sacrifices which have been made by the Australian community. I admit that sacrifices have been made and pain has been experienced in the labour force, but it has resulted in this very welcome reduction in our dependence on foreign savings to fund the operations of the Australian economy as the excess of exports over imports has developed this year.

It is very interesting to note, as Senator O'Chee is here in the chamber, that the Budget forecast of $18,000m for this year for the current account deficit on our overseas activities was 4.5 per cent of our total national income-our gross domestic product.

It is very illuminating to look at the Liberals' record in 1981-82. In that year they had a current account deficit-an actual deficit-of $9,000m when the economy was much smaller than it is now. As a result, the last Liberal government had a current account deficit of 5.8 per cent of gross domestic product. The present deficit was forecast this year at 4.5 per cent of gross domestic product. It will probably be a little lower because, as I have pointed out, the current balance of payments current account deficit is lower than the forecast $18 billion for the year, so this current account deficit will be much more impressive as a percentage of gross domestic product than the deficit in 1981-82. These are some of the achievements that have been mounting very quietly, but positively, regarding the balance of payments.

I mentioned that the official cash interest rates were 18 per cent at the beginning of last year. When we proposed easing those interest rates in February last year, a number of people opposite said that, in fact, the reductions in interest rates proposed by the Government were premature, and that we were somehow electioneering when we were proposing to reduce interest rates from the 18 per cent level. That is what they said, they cannot deny it, they are on the record as having said that. That easing of interest rates from the 18 per cent level early last year was appropriate. There have been several rounds of reductions in official cash interest rates since that time and now we have a rate of 11.5 per cent. In other words, there has been a 6 1/2 percentage points cut in official rates in about 15 months. Rates have been cut by well over one-third and that has been reducing the cost of finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still double what it is in the UK.

—I will come to the United Kingdom in a moment; I have been waiting for this opportunity. Late last week, in response to the reductions in the official interest rates, it was very interesting to note that the chief economist of the Commonwealth Bank, which happens to be not only Australia's largest bank but also Australia's largest lender for housing, pointed out that there should be a pick-up in the number of housing starts-the commencements on new dwellings-in the financial year ahead of us. For example, compared with the 122,000 starts of new dwellings this current financial year, the chief economist of the Commonwealth Bank forecasts 134,000 starts next financial year. That is not a Government forecast; that comes from Australia's largest home loan lender.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there will probably be more good news in the pipeline tomorrow when the consumer price index comes out. One of the factors that will generate a very low consumer price index is the Government's trade-off by providing income tax cuts to employees in return for them foregoing gross wage rises, through the process of giving higher after-tax incomes instead of employees being encouraged to demand higher gross wages from their employers. This has meant that costs for business have been kept down and, as a result, this will help to keep down prices in the Australian economy. The report of the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ), Business Indicators, which was released yesterday, agrees wholeheartedly that the process of providing tax cuts in order to reduce wage demands will have a beneficial effect on the consumer price index.

The current consumer price index annual rate is 6.9 per cent to the December quarter last year. Tomorrow we expect to get the March quarter figures. The great thing about those figures is that when they are published, the March quarter figure for last year will come out of the index annual rate-will no longer be in it-and that was a figure of 1.7 per cent. The inflation rate at the end of the Liberals' tenure of office was not 6.9, 7.9 or even 8.9 per cent, it was 11.5 per cent. So tomorrow we will be well on track for an inflation rate half the double digit rate that those opposite left office with.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the unemployment rate?
—The unemployment rate is still lower than it was under Senator Panizza's Government, when it was 10.4 per cent.
—You have fiddled the figures.

—Senator O'Chee should read the parliamentary publications. The figures are all on the record and it is just a matter of Senator O'Chee learning how to read. If we get a consumer price index figure of 0.7 per cent tomorrow-and that is probably on the high side-that would give us an annual inflation rate of 5.9 per cent. The last time Australia had an inflation rate below 6 per cent on an annual basis was six years ago, in 1985. We are certainly getting inflation out of the system and making Australia much more competitive than those opposite ever did.

SPEECH.PARA: The current average inflation rate of our major trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) based in Paris is 6.7 per cent. If we get a figure tomorrow of 1.5 per cent or less, we will be below the average inflation rate of our overseas trading partners. That will really give a boost to the competitiveness of Australian business and will certainly help them compete better with imports.

I put on the record the fact that these predictions are not necessarily only coming from the Government side in the Australian community, but they are also coming from key influential forecasting groups in the private sector in business. I would like to mention some of the forecasts for the inflation rate which is coming out tomorrow, because I suspect that we will not get any questions from the Opposition about the inflation rate for the March quarter. The Opposition will run away from it, because it knows what good news it will be for the Australian economy and what a boost it will give to the competitiveness of Australian exporters.

These are the forecasts put forward by some of the major forecasting groups in Australia: Syntec is suggesting that by December, Australia's inflation rate will be 3 1/2 per cent-it has not been in that range since the 1960s. Certainly, 3 1/2 per cent would be 8 percentage points below the 11 1/2 per cent double digit rate that the Liberals left Australia with when they went out of office in March 1983. The Westpac Banking Group forecasts a 4 1/2 per cent inflation rate by December this year. So there is one forecast at 3 1/2 per cent and another at 4 1/2 per cent.

Bain and Company, a large sharebroking organisation based in Sydney, is suggesting a rate of 4 to 4 1/2 per cent-yet another very low forecast. It points out that Australia has had an inflation rate on average, per annum, since 1970 of 9 per cent so that that 4 to 4 1/2 per cent rate will be a very competitive rate. The ANZ Bank Business Indicators publication, which I referred to a moment ago in another context, yesterday forecast an inflation rate possibly below 4 per cent. All of these forecasts are fairly consistent in that 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent range; all of them are from private sector organisations; and all of them suggest that there will be good news for Australia in getting inflation down and in getting price pressures and cost pressures out of the Australian economy.

If the Liberal Party ever got into power, inflation would go through the roof. Throughout the 1970s the Liberals said that they would fight inflation first. I well remember that the keystone to their economic policy was to fight inflation first. When they left office the level of inflation was in double digits-11.5 per cent, as Senator Jones would well remember. These are the people who said that they would fight inflation first, and they failed.

This time the Liberal Party is going to fight inflation by bringing in a consumption tax. The reality of the Liberal policy is a broad-based consumption tax-a goods and services tax-a tax, as far as I can see, on everything produced in the Australian economy except fuel. Everything produced in the Australian economy would be taxed by the Liberals if they ever got into government and this would blow inflation through the roof. It would add another range of percentage points onto our annual inflation rate.

There is a proposal by the Liberals that somehow they could hold down the rate of inflation by removing the current wholesale sales tax and replacing it with a broad-based consumption tax. These are amazing, funny money statistics. I do not know how the Liberals come to these conclusions because at the moment in the Australian economy there are two major areas of expenditure which are almost totally tax exempt, and that is food and clothing. The Liberals' consumption tax would automatically go onto every item in all of those areas.

—I ask those opposite to name them right now. SPEECH.PARA: I refer to Senate Question No. 286, which I put on notice some time ago, where I asked what specific food items are subject to current wholesale tax. I might continue to nail this lie, that food is somehow taxed at the present time, by referring to the Australian Bureau of Statistics regular publication called, Average Retail Prices of Selected Items, Eight Capital Cities, in which the official statistician looks at the retail prices of 44 major food commodities in every capital city of Australia on a quarterly basis. There we are: it is a fiction that somehow food is taxed at the present time. We saw the Liberals and the Nationals run out of steam here this afternoon. They started with ice-cream, they got up to orange juice and then it stopped. Senator Knowles blustered away and said there were lots of others but she got stuck-she got jammed. I caught them out. He inferred that bringing down the cost of alcohol would increase the road toll. Also, in relation to his final point, I point out that beef would still be much cheaper than canned baked beans or takeaway foods. I believe that beef is too cheap at present.

SPEECH.PARA: I go to the substance of my contribution to the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91. I will address three points. The first is the failure of the Federal Government to provide necessary assistance to give students from isolated and remote areas access to education similar to that which is available in urban areas of Australia. Before Senator Tate or anyone else tells me that my speech is a repeat of the speeches made yesterday on this topic, I say that it is not. I am talking about assistance for isolated children in remote areas in order to give them equal access to the education system.

The second point I raise is the failure of this Government in delaying the decision to mine Coronation Hill and develop other resources that should be developed. The third point is the failure of this Government to implement the National Rail Freight Corporation as promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last year. This matter was also the subject of a question which was raised yesterday and which was ducked by Senator Collins, as the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown).

As I said earlier, my contribution, which is about access to equal education, is a not a repeat of the speeches made yesterday. I believe it is a basic right of all students, wherever they are in Australia-in the cities or the country-to have equal access to education, just as we hope that there are equal opportunities for access to everything else. However, with equal opportunities come equal responsibilities.

Most Australian students do not have that equal right of access to education. In fact, 9,000 children in Australia do not and these are the children living in isolated and remote areas. They do not have that access unless their parents are put under extreme financial pressure. There is a basic allowance available at present that was introduced in 1973 by Mr Kim Beazley, Sr, the then Minister for Education. In 1973, there were 32,000 students in that category. That figure is now down to 9,000, partly because of the provision of extra high schools around Australia. However, the main reason for the drop in that figure is the drain of the population away from the country because of the decisions by this Government to close certain resources and to prevent others from starting up.

In 1973 payment under the assistance to isolated children (AIC) scheme was set at 55 per cent of average boarding costs. The AIC has been calculated on the difference between the costs of keeping children at home and having them in boarding hostels. I will take a country hostel as the main example in my speech today.

In 1991, the basic figure available under that scheme is $1,500. That now relates to only 32 per cent of the average boarding costs; that is an exact figure. However, there is further help available. A pamphlet describing the scheme says that, for primary and secondary students under 16, higher amounts can be paid depending on family income and the assets test. So we are back to the assets test. I will not question the existence of the income test, but I believe that the assets test should not be there on that extra amount or that there should be some provision for hardship cases. When it comes to the subject of equal access to education, I believe that nothing should stand in a student's way, irrespective of the financial position of that student's family or the family's location. The fact that the allowance is available does nothing for the people who need it.

At present the Isolated Childrens Parents Association is looking for that figure to be lifted to $2,650 per annum and indexed so that we do not have to go through the same argument next year, the year after and the year after that. Of course, if we have that indexation, it will take away the need for the 55 per cent rate.

One can argue that when a student passes 16 years he or she can go onto Austudy. However, as was outlined in the debate we had yesterday, once a student is on Austudy, there is an income and asset test. I believe that that is not the right way to go. Allowances for isolated children should not be assets or income tested. One may ask me why. The answer is that there is a basic right for all to have equal access to education. I fully support income and assets tests for Austudy in normal circumstances. Unfortunately, these are not normal circumstances because we have a position where assets cannot be sold and have no value. As I have said, we have already had this debate.

The plight of the people from remote areas is vastly different. Why should there be assets or income testing when there is a non-availability of schools in remote areas? Except for those 9,000 isolated people, freedom of access to education is available to enable students to matriculate. If students are not given the chance to matriculate when they are at matriculation age, it is very hard for them to get back into study. Unfortunately, if students have to spend a few years away from study before they matriculate, they do not often get back to study later. These include children who do not have access or transport to normal schooling, and I believe that they should have it.

There is no income or assets test on children using the school bus system in Australia; they can travel quite freely. In Western Australia the Government pays, on average, $1,350 per annum to the contractors to allow students to travel on those buses. At least that figure could be added on to the non-income tested allowance that is provided by the Government. That would lift the figure to around $2,850-and that is only to get the children to the school gate. If this access to education is not there, what is the alternative? The only alternative is to board children away.

If parents are not in a position to board children away, there are a few other possibilities. The first is to change jobs. The second is that the wife can move into town and get a job if possible. The third is that children can leave school, study under distance education and complete only the compulsory years or just leave and be thrown uneducated into the work force. But there are problems with all these options, including the changing of jobs. If a parent moves away from a job, firstly, that person has to find a job wherever he or she goes; and secondly, the work force resource in these remote areas will be removed. A wife moving to town and getting a job also presents problems because there are strains on family relationships. All the other points about children leaving school early create problems.

With only $1,500-odd available for children in isolated areas to have access to education, parents in these areas try to obtain assistance by other measures. In the present economic downturn it is very hard to do that. I refer to the case of a woman from a Western Australian pastoral region whom I became aware of last week. She did just that: she went in and applied for assistance through Austudy. This was because she was getting only $1,500 through the basic isolated children's allowance. However, she was told that, as a result of assets testing, she was precluded. She explained that they had tried to sell or auction her station but had had no bidders or takers. The fellow who was dealing with her said, `It must have a value of some sort. I will give you $10 for the station, if it has no other value'.

Apparently, she was supposed to take $10 for the station and lose any base that might exist to enable the family to recover, first in order to qualify for this living away from home allowance, or whatever one wants to call it, to enable the children to go to school. Of course, though, if she sold the station she would not be living there any more and could move closer to a school. However, that is the sort of answer that people are getting.

I heard about another person last week who is in a trucking business. Because of the economic downturn, last year his trucking business lost $8,000 to $10,000. That is what the balance sheet showed for last year. When he asked for some sort of help, he was asked whether he could sell some of the business. The business consists of one prime mover and one tipping semitrailer, which are used to cart material from a stockpile to a crushing plant for one of the mines. What is he supposed to sell? Is he supposed to sell off the trailer, or half the trailer? The officers who deal with these people do not know what they are talking about. I believe that officers of the departments who have to deal with people from these areas should go out and get some training in the field and see for themselves what things are really like. They may then have more commonsense when dealing with people and problems like this.

I now refer to the matter of country hostels, where most of these children from isolated areas board in order to have equal access to education. I will not compare this situation with the more up-market city schools, though some of those city boarding schools are no dearer than many of the hostels. The average boarding fee for those country boarding hostels in Australia is $4,700 a year. Mind you, only $1,500 is allowed now free of income or assets testing; so, per child, a family has to make up $3,200. Of course, in better economic turns, parents are willing to pay it, but in the current economic downturn it is becoming impossible to get anywhere near it. I refer in particular to Western Australian Government hostels and to the submission of the Federal Council of the Isolated Childrens Parents Association. It states:
WA Government hostels fees for 1991 are $4,700 per annum.

Forty-seven isolated students did not proceed with their bookings for 1991. Twenty-nine students have been withdrawn from hostels in 1991, two from the beginning of second term. Five students from non-government schools in WA have transferred to hostels. Many students have transferred to Distance Education and some have not proceeded to upper secondary.
One WA hostel has fees on seven students outstanding.

The New South Wales situation is very much the same. The city boarding schools are having difficulties and, to their credit, they have tried to come to some arrangement with the parents so that the children from the isolated areas do not have to pull out of school. It is one thing to attend an elite city boarding school if one is from the city, but the children from the isolated areas have to board somewhere. The average cost of country hostels is $4,700 a year and the average cost of a private boarding school in the city-and I will use Western Australian figures-is around $5,500. So there is not a great deal of difference.

The Government, in order to make up the difference to the level at which the Isolated Childrens Parents Association is looking, could take that original $1,500 that is provided and add the $1,350 that is being spent on getting children in isolated areas to school on school buses. If those figures are added together we have $2,850 per annum, and that, of course, should remain free of any testing whatsoever. This is to give those children in isolated areas equal access to education.

I read from submissions made to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. These were submissions to the Committee's inquiry into student financial assistance. I note from this inquiry that most of the submissions came from Western Australia, and so I presume that that is where the most problems lie. The submission from the Shire of Narembeen states:
This figure is arrived at by using the 4 per cent return suggested above and the current income test cut off point of $32,043 per annum for one child.
The cut-off point for any assistance is $32,000, and someone with a farming property is deemed to have a return of around 4 per cent. It further states:
The assets test threshold should then increase by some $318,600 for each additional child . . .

The assets test cuts off at a certain figure, at whatever it is now, and for farming properties it is around $700,000. But it does not matter whether the family has one child, two children, four or five children, the assets test eligibility figure cuts out at the same level whereas on income testing the income is scaled up. I believe that the Shire of Narembeen has a point. There are submissions from other shires including one from the Shire of Wongan-Ballidu, one from the Shire of Lake Grace, and also one from the Country Shire Councils Association. All of them point out where things are going wrong for isolated children.

Of course, if this equal access of opportunity to education is not available in remote areas in Australia, it makes it twice as hard, in comparison with other places in Australia, to keep key personnel, or indeed any sort of personnel, so that the enterprises can continue being run in those places. At this stage I will leave that subject and move on to the matter of mining at Coronation Hill.

Coronation Hill is a prime example of this Government's inertia in opening up resources in Australia. Honourable senators may remember that it was put on hold during the election period of 1990, when the Prime Minister decided that the matter would be handed over to the Resource Assessment Committee to have another look at it. In other words, he was not game to tell us exactly what was going to happen with Coronation Hill until after the election.

Coronation Hill has known reserves of at least one million ounces of gold. Never have I known of a mine-and I have been in the mining areas all of my life-starting with minimum requirements of deposit without finding an extra lode. I am sure that it would be the same at Coronation Hill. With the known reserves, there is a $500m minimum production. The mine would have a work force of 600 people. If a factor of four is applied, many other jobs are created to keep that sort of enterprise going, the mine would create employment for nearly 3,000 people. If to that figure we add the employment created by the many other resources that we could open up around Australia, we would make a hole in the unemployment in Australia today.

I just mention the Jawoyn people for a moment. It is reported that they are against development yet, when I went up there twice for an inquiry held two or three years ago, groups of those people told us that they were certainly interested in getting the mining going ahead. We have heard all the excuses on earth for not proceeding with the mine, including the bula sickness, the spirit and that sort of thing. If I were to use the same sort of arguments and ideas elsewhere, I would be locked up for insanity. I believe that we and the Jawoyn people have progressed beyond that point.

What annoys me about Coronation Hill is that the excuses for delaying the development of the mine or, indeed, maybe stopping it altogether, can be used anywhere else in Australia. It is in a quite remote area, and has been described earlier as clapped out buffalo country. Exactly the same excuse could be used for delaying any proposed development, whether it be in the Nullarbor, the south west of Western Australia, the Pilbara or the eastern half of Western Australia. If the environmental groups or the Australian Democrats get away with this one, all other resources will cop the same sort of treatment. Many Australians are unemployed at the present moment because of the closing down of mines or because of resources not being opened up.

My final point on Coronation Hill is that there could be the production of platinum and palladium as well as gold there. Hopefully one day there will be a platinum mine at Fifield in New South Wales. The mine at Coronation Hill could quite easily get off the ground and we could have our first platinum mine. The Government needs to be condemned on that point.

My final point is on the Government's failure to get the National Rail Freight Corporation going. This idea was mooted by the Prime Minister at the Premiers Conference last year. There was to be a real micro-economic reform of land transport in Australia creating one corporation that would shift freight from all capital cities in Australia with one railway gauge, one industrial agreement and one signalling system.

We were told how much cheaper the transport of freight was going to be. In that way, the railways would compete more evenly with road transport. There is no way in this world that road trucks should compete with rail across Australia. A single truck should not compete with a train two kilometres long, yet it competes with and defeats rail. We were told how the system was going to work, and it was supported at all times by the Opposition.

Although the starting date is to be 1 July 1991, nothing has been put in place. I have asked two questions about this in the last three weeks. I have had two non-answers from Senator Collins representing the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown, about what is going on. We are certainly being kept in the dark on the matter.

The importance of this is that Australian railways as a whole are losing $4 billion a year. Interstate rail accounts for only 12 per cent of rail losses in Australia. It is interesting to note that the Western Australian section of the interstate rail is the only one that is making a profit now. If we can get the whole rail system between all capital cities sorted out, on an even keel and even making a profit, that could be a blueprint for the rest of Australia doing the same and reducing that bleeding of $4 billion.

The Minister tells us that the hold up is legitimate state rights. I believe in legitimate state rights, but I would like to know why this situation was not foreseen by the Prime Minister, Mr Brown and Senator Collins before they made this announcement. It is all right to make big announcements like that, just like the waterfront reform announcements, and that reform is pretty slow in getting off the mark. Even if the waterfront were to be reformed in the way that is needed, what is the use of having that in place when transport is locked away from the port? The waterfront could still be in the same backward mode.

It is of great importance that this railways scheme be put into place but the Government, having got a certain amount of publicity out of it last year, has now gone to ground on it and refused to answer questions. As I said before, all those reasons for delay that we have been told about in the last month or so were in existence before. I am afraid that the Government has shot its mouth off about one or two things without thinking or else it did not do its homework.

I cannot see freight being shifted by this Corporation by 1 July. There has not been any announcement on a headquarters or on a chief executive. There has been no arrangement about shareholdings or who is going to own the track-whether the Commonwealth or the States individually will own it. None of those questions have been addressed, and we have six weeks to go.

I condemn the Government on that issue and other issues that I have mentioned, especially Coronation Hill. If we want to get this country moving and to have some credibility with our trading partners in the rest of the world, it is time that the Government addressed these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation Bill (No. 5), gives us the opportunity to look in detail at those issues that we have been able to pursue through the Senate Estimates Committee process and, at the same time, to look at the thrust of government policies and their effects either in the electorates that we represent or, alternatively, in the areas and issues for which we take either individual or shadow ministry responsibilities in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, as shadow Minister for regional development, external territories and northern Australia, I have taken a very keen look at the Budget, the variations and the objectives that the Government is setting out to achieve, particularly at this point of review. As we well know, since the Budget was handed down in August last year the economic climate in Australia under the guidance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has ended up in a recession, if not a depression, totally engineered by the Treasurer and the Government. For that reason, the Government is to be condemned for the fact that many people-and many industries-are suffering. The consequences being felt throughout the community are severe and damaging both individually and to the national economy, whether in the public or private sector.

The fact that the Treasurer has somehow dissipated a total amount of $8 billion anticipated surplus, and will probably end up with a deficit at the end of the year, should concern us all. We have ended up with a Labor Government that reminds me of the sorts of lessons one often has to give to growing people in one's own family when they constantly experience the problems as to what to put on hire purchase, on mortgage or on loan and what should be paid for as one goes along. So much of the Budget scenario that has changed since August last year under the direction of the Treasurer and the Government pulls us up constantly in so many areas.

Throughout the review process that we have engaged in here in the Senate over the past month or so, I have concentrated on those portfolio and electorate issues that either affect principally regional Australia, northern Australia or, more specifically, the Northern Territory. During the Estimates process I put some 75 questions on notice to the Estimates committees and pursued another 30 or 40 questions in the various hearings and discussions with Ministers and departmental officers. I must say that this year the officers were forthcoming with the responses. I was pleased with the prompt return of questions placed on notice in advance by most of the departments. I can say that, with only a couple of exceptions, I was pleased that the information that we sought has come back in due and proper time.

That is not to say that I find the answers necessarily totally satisfactory, but given the issues that had to be pursued-and, as I said, in my areas of interest at least 75 major areas across just about every portfolio impacted in some way on regional Australia, northern Australia or the Northern Territory-I would like to take the time of the Senate to look in detail at some of the particular issues that I think still require attention by government and certainly constant action and reaction by the Parliament and, in particular, the Senate.

I asked a number of Government departments this year for information that they necessarily had to incur with regard to the effectiveness of spending millions and millions of dollars chasing, apprehending and repatriating illegal fishermen in north Australian waters. This issue has now blown out of all proportion and has become a major financial burden on Australian taxpayers. In fact, if we look at the departments that have had to make specific appropriations, I find it of concern that in this area we now have departments such as Primary Industries and Energy; Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs; Defence; Small Business and Customs; Foreign Affairs and Trade; the Attorney-General's; and Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories all having to engage in major programs looking at this issue and redressing those matters that should be addressed.

Some of the information I got from each and every one of those departments proved fascinating. I turn the attention of anyone who wants to pursue them, either in the media or in this place, to the detailed answers given by the respective departments. Unfortunately, unlike in past years, I cannot now put a total financial figure on the commitment in that area. Principally, the Department of Defence has decided that it cannot give discrete financial figures any longer with regard to this particular range of activities. Ironically, in the past it has done so. Last year I received an answer that in the order of $25m related to issues in the Department of Defence. But this year, while the Department has answered a number of questions with regard to the range of activities by the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) aircraft or by the Naval facilities that have to be applied, the Department could not discreetly give us the information that was required.

There is a lot of discussion going on, and many interdepartmental committees between the various departments have been set up. The primary responsibility will be sheeted home to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, to pursue top level discussions, particularly with Indonesian authorities, to redress this matter. If it is to cost us $20m, $30m or $40m a year to chase, apprehend and repatriate illegal fishermen in Australian waters, then there is a burden on Australian taxpayers that should not be an ongoing matter without major considerations. Although I accept that there is a need for a great deal of diplomacy because of the other trade arrangements that we have with our Indonesian neighbour, we cannot walk away from the seriousness of this matter.

As we know, there are hundreds of illegal fishermen who are apprehended and placed in Western Australian, Northern Territory or Queensland gaols. Perhaps the question should be seriously asked whether special arrangements ought not to be brought into place between Indonesia and Australia to arrange for the early repatriation of those illegal fishermen to serve their sentences in Indonesian gaols. Perhaps the compounding effect of that would be to provide the sort of pressure on the financial interests in Indonesia that are obviously backing the fishermen. I am not referring to the poor guys who work on these ships for whom the Australian pocket money handed out in gaols would often be a more advantageous benefit than the wages they receive, but to the fact that such action would heighten and put pressure on the business backers at home. The responsibility should be for the cost to be borne either by the regional administrations overseas, whether in Indonesia or other countries, or by the business interests.

It is a major issue. With so many departments now having to divert their resources rather than carrying out the primary purposes that we normally would have anticipated in those areas, it is a matter of major concern that the Government must address as a matter of urgency and priority.

In alluding to the issue of defence, let me also look at the continuing saga that surrounds the RAAF base at Tindal at Katherine in the Northern Territory. This base was finished several years ago. We are now well aware from the questioning that I undertook of the Defence Housing Authority and the Australian Construction Services of the Department of Administrative Services that there were a great many issues that were totally unresolved at the time that those contracts were concluded. The Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, acknowledged with regard to the Estimates of the Department of Administrative Services that a number of cases of fraud were still not properly concluded or finally investigated. It concerns me that so many of these issues still remain a saga and obviously will continue.

In one of the answers to my questions the Department replied that investigation of the 12 allegations of fraud that had been under investigation had now ceased through lack of substance or lack of evidence. There were a number of reasons why these 12 cases were not pursued. Some 17 allegations had been investigated and now only five matters remain under active investigation. Twelve have slipped off the agenda, despite the fact that they obviously demanded urgent attention. Millions of dollars-Australian taxpayers' dollars-were involved in the construction of this very significant and major project.

What do we then see when we look in a different area-at the Defence Housing Authority-and at the estimates now required for expenditure on repairs and maintenance of the defence housing at Tindal? It is not just the routine maintenance that would normally crop up a year or two, or perhaps five or six years after the contract had been concluded, but the repairs and maintenance are now covering up the issues arising from inadequate construction or fraudulently constructed buildings that now require major redress.

This is an issue that will not go away. It is an issue that requires and demands urgent Government attention-particularly with regard to the pursuit of the slack administration of Australian Construction Services. I believe that Senator Bolkus has to give a lot more attention to this matter, and it is a matter that I will certainly pursue with him. I am aware of many of the folklore stories which are now arising several years after things have been concluded. Nevertheless, I do not want to see criminals or people who have fraudulently ripped off the Commonwealth Government getting away just because time has slipped away and public servants have been shuffled in the pack from one posting to another. We certainly need to be aware that many issues need to be redressed.

In the area of defence, it also concerns me that the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, is proposing to make a major statement to the Parliament-I believe on 6 June-about the long term planning of defence facilities throughout Australia. I am pleased that in recent years the Government and the Parliament have recognised the priority of ensuring that Australia's defence has a northern Australian focus and that projects such as the 2nd Cavalry Regiment near Darwin are receiving priority. But we have to ensure that there is no slippage in the construction works program of projects such as the 2nd Cavalry Regiment or for additional fuel storage at RAAF base Tindal, where it is obvious that the planes could not be kept in the air for a decent exercise or for a decent engagement if that was required. Again, the questioning brought out that point and highlighted many of those areas.

In my review of the Department of Employment, Education and Training I was concerned about some of the information given to me as answers with regard to the funding that is made available to non-government schools. In northern Australia in particular, Aboriginal students make a very proper demand on the private school system. In order to accommodate secondary school students in particular, it is necessary that appropriate levels of government funding are paid to these non-government schools to ensure high student retention rates, that Aboriginal students will receive proper and high levels of education and that there will not be any discrimination anywhere in Australia against, particularly, Aboriginal children who need these facilities.

The answers that were given to me by the Department in this area give me cause for great concern. A college near Darwin, St John's College, which is run by the Catholic education system, in correspondence with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), Senator Collins, Mr Snowdon and me has continually highlighted the problems that it has because of the finicky attitudes of the Department concerning the level of funding that it provides to a private school. It really means that Aboriginal students are not receiving the proper and appropriate levels of funding needed in order to advance their education. It is the skinflint attitude of the Department in not recognising this particular area which causes me major concern.

But, on the other hand, there is a problem arising from a school not doing the right thing. I refer particularly to an independent Aboriginal school in Alice Springs, the Yipirinya School, which has received significant ceding grants-both for capital and recurrent expenditure and ongoing recurrent funding-of a major amount. Yet what do we see here? My criticism is not of the Government but of the staff of the new school. Because there is an Aboriginal cause being pursued in the Alice Springs community which relates to the provision by the Northern Territory Government of a flood mitigation dam, we find that staff have not given their full attention to the school but, under the very generous funding that the Commonwealth Government has made available to the school, have for weeks at a time been very actively agitating, promoting and spending time at public protests. That is a misuse of the generosity of government funding that is made available for the provision of facilities to Aboriginal people which requires open comment and open criticism. In that case, I hope the Department and the auditors go in and make the appropriate adjustments-if necessary to the funding-but not at the expense of the Aboriginal students in that area.

I also refer to the funding by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) of the Aboriginal radio network and media association in central Australia-the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association, commonly referred to as CAAMA. For the last two years this organisation has constantly demanded public scrutiny. I have certainly been quite open in my criticism of the funding of this particular organisation. I am aware that the management consultants, KPMG Peat Marwick, undertook, in association with the Media Association's own board, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and ATSIC, a major review of that organisation.

Since the middle of last year, and at the Estimates hearings in October last year, I have been asking to see the reports of that organisation-the draft report of 1990 and the concluded report of 1991-in order that we can assess the effectiveness of the millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds that have been put into this media organisation.

This week I finally received a copy of that report-some hundred pages of it-from an anonymous source. It turned up in my mailbag. It is a very disturbing document. If the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has had it on his desk since January of this year, or if the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) has had it on his desk since January of this year-the date of the report-I hope that the Government has not only pulled out the whips but has demanded that there be very significant changes to management financial controls within the organisation of CAAMA in Alice Springs.

The objectives of that organisation and its associated company, the Imparja television station of Alice Springs, are demanding and both organisations have positive roles to play in the community. But at the same time, if these organisations are guilty of slack management or slack financial control, that is certainly not in the best interests of the Aboriginal constituency or the people of the Northern Territory who depend on their services. I certainly hope that all of the Ministers with interests in the areas of communications, Aboriginal affairs and education will read the report as I have done and will guarantee that an immediate and effective change is brought about in that area.

Whilst I am looking at the issues related to the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs, I point out that I have asked more than 20 questions on notice. As I said in my general comments, I was happy with the satisfactory answers that were given to the majority of the questions. But I would highlight for the Senate's attention a couple of issues that I think do need to be pursued with a little more scrutiny and accountability and a little more questioning. One relates to the generous funding that was made available this year to enable Aboriginal participants to attend the World Council of Churches General Assembly in Canberra as delegates. In that regard I note that the board of ATSIC made available a grant of $130,552 to the Australian Council of Churches as a contribution to the costs of the participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people at the Special Assembly of the World Council of Churches, held here in Canberra.

The extent of that funding I certainly question. I believe that a very significant amount was made available to assist in the funding of travel, for media coordinators, media teams, promotional kits, team visits and Top End participation. Whilst the issue of Aboriginal reconciliation is an important one on the Government's agenda, and an important one for this Parliament and the nation to address, I believe that much of the activity needs to be carefully monitored against the often generous funding which ends up being spent on nothing more than advertising and for promotional purposes, rather than on the delivery of services which are so needed in the Aboriginal community in order to address the major problems.

I also note that, with moneys received from mining royalties, the Central Land Council, an independent organisation under its own charter, allocated $16,411 additionally for the World Council of Churches conference and the Northern Land Council in the top part of the Northern Territory allocated expenditure of about $11,209. I do note that the Tiwi Land Council, with which Senator Collins would be very familiar, made no expenditure provisions in this regard, despite the fact that it is probably the most Christian Aboriginal community in northern Australia, as a result of its own history. Obviously if any of the Tiwi people chose to participate in that conference, they did so from other than government-sourced finances. Therefore, it is a matter of questioning value received in that regard.

The other issue in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio to which I would like to pay particular attention relates to the necessary streamlining of the provisions of the community development employment program. This is a program that has now been under way for many years and reaches and services many Aboriginal communities throughout Australia. In the broad, it is a very worthwhile program. It replaces the provision of unemployment and many other forms of benefits in Aboriginal communities. It institutes a concept of work-related activity and management of those activities in each and every one of the participating Aboriginal communities.

However, the answers that have been provided, to both the Estimates Committee and various questions on notice from a number of honourable senators in each State and Territory of Australia, again cause concern in the areas of accountability and scrutiny and in areas where fraud and so many other issues have been allowed to creep in through mismanagement and the lack of appropriate guidelines and supervision. I know that ATSIC has turned its attention to this matter and is carefully monitoring the whole provision of services in this area. This is an area that we cannot walk away from. If we are to ensure that the Aboriginal beneficiaries of the particular scheme get the maximum benefit in each and every one of their communities, we must be constantly vigilant in that regard.

My final point under the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs relates to government assistance to a number of Aboriginal communities near the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory. The Kalano Community Association Inc. and the Binjarri community both receive grants from the Government. Unfortunately, in the past year or so there has been a serious fracturing of the relationships in those communities, between the Aboriginal people and Aboriginal management, and also a lack of trust and a lack of coordination between the officers of ATSIC and a number of people associated with either Kalano or Binjarri.

From the pursuits and representations I have made in this regard over the past six or eight months, I am still not convinced that the services so desperately needed by hundreds of Aboriginal families in great need are being properly recognised by ATSIC, although I appreciate its arms length distance from the Government. At the same time we must continue to stress the priorities. Because of the close association to the Katherine community, we must ensure that this situation is not allowed to become a flashpoint. It is one of those issues in which we-whether it is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Collins or myself-must continue to take a close responsibility for ensuring that the proper finances are getting through, that the essential services relating to health, education and housing are provided, and that efforts are not thwarted and frustrated by personalities in either politics or in the local community.

The national Aboriginal health strategy was a very important document tabled in the Parliament some time ago. There are many initiatives that will arise from government departments at the State, Northern Territory and Commonwealth level, and various agencies. It is always important to ensure that the amount of money getting through is properly reaching those who need it most. I am concerned that the provision of research facilities in Aboriginal affairs also needs to be closely monitored.

One such project relates to the financial assistance that has been allocated for the continued public health research into neurological syndrome amongst the Aboriginal people of Groote Eylandt in the area close to the manganese mining deposits. ATSIC appears to have walked away from the traditional funding that it has given to the research that is going on into this important problem by the Menzies School of Health Research based out of Darwin. In particular, I commend the work of Dr Tim Burt, the Medical Officer, Public Health Research, involving the Angurugu community on Groote Eylandt.

The work that Dr Burt and other people associated with him are undertaking is important for the future lifestyle of hundreds of people on Groote Eylandt. I was concerned that the answer given to me on issues raised in this regard merely flicked the matter aside. The answer was:

While ATSIC acknowledges the need for security of funding for the research team, ATSIC cannot guarantee further funding for research work. Menzies School of Health Research will be advised of this and it is recommended that they should continue to approach research organisations for funds to continue their work after June 1991.

Whilst there naturally has to be an assurance that government funding does come through appropriate areas, this again is indicative of other areas where the Government appears to lose sight of its priorities and lose its will.

There are many other issues that I would like to have addressed, some of which I shall have to take up in the committee stage. Regional Australia, northern Australia and the external territories are all important to Australia and its economy. In this very difficult time, irrespective of whether it is a recession or depression, I hope that the Government will pick up the need for ongoing support in so many of these functional areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Short's amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 in which he asks that the Senate condemn the Government for its economic mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility which has resulted in a severe and protracted recession. Senator Short was probably too generous, in moving the amendment, in simply mentioning that the Government has caused a severe and protracted recession. Senator Walsh, a Government senator, was probably far more correct when he said that the Government has, in fact, caused a depression. It does not mean much in the semantics of the word, I suspect, except to show that Australia is now facing the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's disgraceful record in managing the economy is shown in no better way than in the number of unemployment benefit recipients at the last seasonally adjusted estimates given out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force survey. The survey showed that a total of 844,000 persons in Australia were unemployed and receiving unemployment benefit. This equates to a seasonally adjusted estimate of unemployment at 9.9 per cent for April.

It is interesting to note that only in the Liberal governed State of New South Wales was the unemployment rate less than the national average. In all of the Labor governed States, the unemployment rate was much more than the national average.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a moral in that.

—As Senator Baume says, there is a moral in that. It is a simple message that I think the Australian public is now getting; that is, that the Australian Labor Party is simply unable to manage the economy. The unemployment rate in the Liberal governed State of New South Wales is less than the national average. Let us examine the unemployment rate in the Labor States: in Victoria it is 10.5 per cent, well above the 9.9 per cent national average; in Queensland, my own State, 10.7 per cent; in South Australia, 10.3 per cent; and in Western Australia, a massive 11.1 per cent. One can only wonder, with respect to the Western Australian figure, why it is not higher. Even in Tasmania, another Labor governed State, it is 10.8 per cent-well above the national average.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in all of those Labor governed States that the unemployment rate has exceeded 10 per cent. This is in spite of the commitment that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave on 4 December 1990 when he said:
The truth is this: unemployment will not reach double digit figures.

It is obvious that in Queensland the unemployment rate continues to increase from 10.2 per cent in March. In February last year, not long after the Labor Government took over, it was only a small 7.1 per cent. It has increased and blown out since the Labor Government took over in my State. There are 155,300 Queenslanders presently unemployed in Mr Goss's State. The figure does not include the part timers and those who have simply given up trying to get work. That is an increase of over 100,000 since February 1990 and since Mr Goss took over the reins of government in Queensland.

In the north Brisbane regional offices of the Department of Social Security, the number of unemployment benefit recipients continued to increase in April 1991 over and above the record high level of March 1991. In the north Brisbane regional offices of Alderley, Chermside, Fortitude Valley and Nundah, a total of 11,263 people are in receipt of unemployment benefit. That figure has increased substantially since last month and it has massively increased since a mere 18 months ago when the Goss Government took over. In the Toowoomba regional office the number of unemployment benefit recipients remains at the very high level of 5,371.

Bankruptcies Australia-wide have increased by 53.6 per cent. But in Queensland-Mr Goss's State, the man who claims that he is the great economic manager-bankruptcies have increased by 60.2 per cent; that is exceeded only by the increase in Victoria of 75.2 per cent. Who would want to be compared with Victoria? But I must say that Mr Goss, our Premier in Queensland, said that he wanted to do for Queensland what John Cain had done for Victoria-and he is certainly going about it the right way. Victoria is the only State which has a higher increase in bankruptcies than Queensland. The gross foreign debt in Australia is now $165 billion. For each Australian, that is $9,114. The cost of servicing that debt alone takes 20c out of every dollar we export.

The Government's mismanagement of the economy is, I suppose, exemplified by Senator Bolkus's complete lack of any managerial or administrative competence in the way he administers his Department of Administrative Services. That is very clearly shown by the way he has made a complete mess-I use the word `mess' rather kindly; less generous people would say worse things--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are generous to a fault.

—I am generous to a fault; Senator Baume is correct. Other people would say nastier things about the way Senator Bolkus has manipulated contracts that were openly and publicly tendered. The companies had put in responses, tenders had been accepted and Senator Bolkus then, quite improperly, with a lack of any propriety, altered the decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus's administration of his portfolio, however, slips further into the superdoubtful category as a result of some information which I have received, through the Estimates committees, dealing with something in the Attorney-General's Department but which Senator Bolkus's Department was in charge of. I am not sure whether it is a problem for Senator Tate or Senator Bolkus, who is in charge of the Australian properties group. Neither Minister has shown any great managerial or business efficiency in the running of their departments. I will leave it to them to try to work out who is at fault and who should wear the blame.

The answers from the public servants who appeared before Estimates Committee E tell me that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) in Sydney had a lease on a place called Kindersley House. They were quite nice premises, of 2,680 square metres. They existed on a lease which commenced on 1 July 1984 and which was renewed for four years on the same date in 1988. The current rental paid on Kindersley House is $1.098m per annum. In addition to that, the tenant pays outgoings of about $40,000 per annum, so the total rental package is $1,137,977.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal continues to occupy that property at the present time, apparently on a lease from Essington Pty Ltd. However, since 30 June 1990, apparently the Commonwealth no longer pays rent there. It is still occupying the place, but it does not pay rent there any more of about $1.137m. Instead, it is paying rent on a place called City Centre where the rent is some $264,000 more than the rent on Kindersley House. The rent paid there is $1.3m and the outgoings are $100,000-so it is paying a total of $1.4m on premises it is not yet occupying.

One might well ask: how could that occur? The tenant-the AAT-had an agreement with a company called Ozton Pty Ltd which, I am informed, is a wholly owned subsidiary of Essington. Essington, as I understand it, is the owner of both Kindersley House and City Centre. The agreement with Ozton was that Ozton would pay the difference in rent. This is all very fine if Ozton continues to operate as a company. But I am informed by officers of the Attorney-General's Department that Ozton was experiencing financial difficulties. As I understand what I have been told in the Estimates Committee, there were certain protections built into the agreement with Ozton. Why the agreements were made with Ozton and not Essington, I am not quite sure.

I have asked for copies of these documents, but they have not yet been made available to me. The questions I asked about these particular matters relating to the parties to the contract were not answered in the Estimates Committee and I have not yet been given the copies of the documents to make my own further research into them. But from the answers I have been given, this appears to be the situation.

It is abundantly clear that the Australian Property Group, the Minister for Administrative Services and/or the Attorney-General's Department have not operated as a prudent commercial developer would operate in its dealings with its leased premises in Sydney. As I understand it, if the rent was not paid on Kindersley House, could Essington-the owner-not sue the Commonwealth for the rent not paid? Honourable senators will remember that, by a deed of amendment signed by Ozton on 20 June 1990, it was agreed that the Commonwealth was to be released from paying rent on Kindersley House-that is, presumably paying rent to Essington.

Having Ozton agree to this-by saying that the Commonwealth would not have to pay the rent to Essington because it would pick up the difference in price-is a huge protection if Ozton is in liquidation. Would the deed of amendment releasing the Commonwealth from payment of the rental on Kindersley House not properly be the agreement of Essington rather than Ozton? If Ozton is simply saying that it will indemnify the Commonwealth against any rent that Essington might call up, because Ozton is, I assume, in receivership, in liquidation or has had a receiver manager appointed, the indemnity would be quite worthless.

In a written reply to a question I put in Estimates, the Attorney-General's Department says that in an agreement entered into on 5 December 1989-and that date is important-supposedly surrendering the lease, certain protections were included for the Commonwealth. But the usual and very standard clauses in building contracts which do give real protection seem to be missing from this particular lease. I might add that this lease is being done by the Australian Property Group on behalf of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Attorney-General's Department-the Commonwealth's top legal advising Department-but the contract seems to be anything but a quality one, particularly where the Commonwealth is concerned.

Where are the clauses in that particular agreement providing for the usual form of bank guarantees? Where are the clauses providing for the usual form of retention moneys? Where are the clauses providing for the usual forms of liquidated damages? Where are the clauses providing for directors or parent company guarantees to the agreements that this newly formed subsidiary company, Ozton, was to give?

In itself the use of the word `protection' by the Commonwealth shows just how completely naive the Commonwealth has been in its commercial dealings on this particular matter. Calling something a protection-as the Department did in an answer to some questions I put at the Estimates hearing-does not ipso facto mean that it gives protection. These agreements particularly show that. The real protection agreements that are usually included in clauses like this do not appear to be there. If they are there, they have not been told to me and they certainly have not been implemented.

It is well known in building industry circles and in legal circles that the Commonwealth Government is an easy touch. It is an easy adversary in these types of building agreements because its contracts are widely regarded in the industry as being badly administered and the quality of its legal advice in relation to these contracts is not particularly well regarded in the industry. As I understand it, the Commonwealth is still paying rent on the City Centre building from 20 June 1990, even though it is not in occupancy. I suspect that the Commonwealth is still liable to Essington for the rental on the Kindersley House tenancy if Ozton's promise proves to be ineffective. That is bad enough, but there is more to come.

The new premises that the Commonwealth is paying rent on, but not occupying, had to be fitted out. The usual Commonwealth Government efficiencies have prevailed again! As an incentive to move early and take on a bigger rent in the long term, Ozton was to do the fit-out of the new premises in the City Centre building completely free of charge to the Commonwealth. What a fine deal that is: it does not cost the Commonwealth anything. Ozton will do the fit-out for the Commonwealth completely free of charge and Ozton will also pay the relocation costs for the Commonwealth-a very attractive arrangement which was well negotiated by the Commonwealth.

The fit-out started in December 1989, but on 31 May 1990, some six months later, the Australian Property Group advised that the fit-out had ceased due to `financial difficulties being experienced by Ozton'. I am unable to ascertain whether Ozton is in receivership, whether it has a receiver manager appointed, whether it is in liquidation or whether it is in voluntary winding up. I wonder whether anyone in the Government knows either, because no-one seems to have been able to tell me. If someone does know, he certainly has not been forthcoming with the answer.

In May 1990 the Australian Property Group advised that Ozton was unable to complete the fit-out owing to financial difficulties being experienced. But just a few days later Ozton signed a document with the Government agreeing to pay the difference in rent between the rent payable on Kindersley House and the City Centre premises-that is, after Ozton said it was in financial difficulties. Ozton then agreed to compensate the Commonwealth for the $300,000 or $400,000 extra that it was going to be paying for the new premises which the Commonwealth was not yet occupying.

I am told that the Commonwealth has exercised its rights under what is referred to in the written answers to some of my Estimates questions as a deed of agreement to complete the fit-out. So the Commonwealth is now taking over the completion of this fit-out. As a result of this, the Commonwealth comes back to this Parliament and asks for an extra $3.723m of taxpayers' money to complete the fit-out of a building that it had arranged for someone else to do. This Government has come back to this Parliament to ask for more money-almost $4m-to do something that should have been done by someone else. This is a staggering amount that the Australian taxpayers are going to be asked to foot the bill for, at a time when they are already struggling under the huge amount of government taxes and the huge difficulties which the economy generally is suffering as a result of this Government's mismanagement.

I suppose the original idea of getting Ozton to pay the $3.7m fit-out for the Commonwealth was a pretty good deal-get someone else to do it and the Commonwealth gets $3.7m of free fit-out if it takes the new premises. But we all know that there is no such thing as a free lunch. Even if one is getting that supposedly free, it is added on into the rental that is paid later; that is normal commercial practice. So the $3.7m fit-out was being done free of charge but the rent that the Commonwealth had negotiated for the new premises-no doubt in accordance with normal commercial practices-took into account that additional capital outlay.

Honourable senators will remember that Ozton is not paying the almost $4m. We the taxpayers and we the Commonwealth have got to pick that up because Ozton has not got the money to do it any more. But has there been any corresponding reduction in the rental payable on the lease? Has there been any corresponding reduction in the rental that would have been increased because Ozton or Essington was paying for that fit-out? The answer that I have been given in Estimates is, `No, there has not'.

Because of this Government's mismanagement-Senator Bolkus's continuous incompetence in his Department, or Senator Tate in his Department-we are the bunnies, the taxpayers who have to pay the additional high rental because we are getting the you-beaut deal of $4m worth of free fit-out. But we are not getting it; we are paying the high rental and we are also picking up the tab for the $4m fit- out. That is why the Government has had to come back and ask for more appropriations.

At page E46 of the Hansard of 18 April 1991, the Department tells us that the Government has certain rights that the Department will be pursuing and that it will no doubt take legal action against Ozton. It is a great confidence booster if the company it is going to sue to recover the cost of the fit-out has already said that it has does not have enough money to complete the fit-out. If it has not got the money to complete the fit-out, what makes anyone think that the Government will be able to sue it, get a judgment and, by waving a magic wand, the company, to pay out the judgment, will find the money that it could not find previously.

As I am advised, we are due to take possession of the new you-beaut premises in September 1991, but what do we have at this time? We seem to be renting two buildings. We seem to be paying rent on the bigger one but I suspect that the indemnity we have against paying rent on the first one is worthless, in which case we are still liable to pay rent on the first one.
