In all probability, we will be paying rent on two buildings.

We are paying $300,000 to $400,000 more rent than we should be paying, because we are still occupying the old premises and we are paying rent on the new increased rental premises. Ozton was going to kick in to save us from having to pay that extra amount, but it is in financial difficulties. We also have this new lease that has been negotiated where the owner was to fit out the premises and save us that $4m, which would compensate us for the higher rent we are paying. But, lo and behold, we find that the owner will not pay the $4m fit-out and we will be paying it.

Madam Acting Deputy President, if you are perplexed so far by the Government's handling of this matter, there is more to come. I am still trying to get an answer from the Government on the upper limit of Government expenditure which can be arranged without going to an open and public tender. I have not had an answer from the Government yet on that limit, but I think it would be well below the $3m or $4m that we are having to pay out. If it is not, then it jolly well should be.

I do not hold up the Burdekin Shire Council as an example of what the Government should do. But in my days on the Council, when we had a tender over $10,000, I think it was, it had to go to a public open tender, and that was done for very good reasons. Although nobody has ever been able to tell me-and I thought that it would have been an easy thing to tell-I am sure that the Commonwealth Government would have a similar procedure, so that a tender of the magnitude of $4m must go to open public tender.

The Department has advised me that the single select tender process was used. I am not sure what that means. As a small-town country lawyer, maybe I could be excused for not knowing what the term the single select tender process means. I have made some inquiries of Sydney property lawyers who deal with leases and commercial properties and they do not know what that term means, either. So whether it is an attempt to say that the Government did not have to call tenders in this particular instance, and it could use this process, I am not sure. I wait anxiously for a departmental answer on that. I did ask officers of the Department whether, if they were fitting out the premises initially and the cost was to be $3m to $4m, they would have called tenders themselves. Their answer was `Of course'. If they would have done so then, then why did they not do it in this case?

To ensure that there is no suggestion of impropriety in awarding large government contracts, a system of rules has evolved which no doubt would require that open and public tenders are invited to give all Australian companies the chance to get some work in these difficult economic times and also to keep the process open and above board.

Whilst this system usually attracts the cheapest price and the most honest and open form of tendering, I am aware that Senator Bolkus does not have much regard for this sort of open, honest tendering and, as he proved with the Nashua contract, he has no hesitation in interfering and letting preferred companies have a second bite of the cherry. Notwithstanding his inability to understand propriety and normal business ethics, there is much to say for preserving open, honest and accountable public tendering.

Honourable senators will appreciate that the Commonwealth is taking over this contact for the fit-out of the building, which is being done by a company called Desaro Pty Ltd. I have no details of that company but I am sure that it is a very well managed and reputable company. That is not the point. It may be-and I do not know-that Desaro has common directors or shareholders with Ozton or Essington. It may be that there is commonality of interest or, alternatively, there may be personal friendships between the owners of Desaro and the owners of Ozton.

How do we know that in a perfectly normal and honest arrangement-I am not saying that there is anything wrong with this-Desaro has not given a concessional rate for other work it has done for Ozton or Essington, or the directors or shareholders, but is recouping any such concessional price on an increased price on this particular contract? I am not suggesting that that has happened. I am saying that, if we do not go to public open tenders, we will never know whether this sort of thing went on.

The difficulty that Ozton finds itself in at the moment is a sad indictment of the financial and economic mismanagement of this Government. No doubt, sadly, Ozton forms one of those statistics which I quoted originally showing that bankruptcies in New South Wales have reached 47.3 per cent. That does not alter the fact that there are a lot of questions to be answered in relation to this particular piece of Government bungling. The Government's repeated bungling of this very sensitive issue of honest and competent acceptance of a Government contract involving large amounts of taxpayers' money provides concern as to whether we are getting honest to goodness value for the money that taxpayers provide for these things.

Maybe it is time to establish a tender review board to oversee the Government's inept handling of tenders of which we have been getting details recently. Where questions are raised about the propriety of the Government tender process, perhaps the matter should be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

This matter is a sad indictment of the Government's ineptitude. From the answers that I have been given today, it appears that the Department of Administrative Services, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Attorney-General's Department have completely bungled a commercial lease of a premises in Sydney which has cost the taxpayers $4m. It has left the taxpayers with a deal on rental which is grossly in excess of what we should be paying because the fit-out that was to be done by the owner is not now being paid for by the owner but is being paid for by the taxpayers of Australia.

I await with some anticipation an explanation by the Government-by Senator Bolkus, by Senator Tate, or by whoever is responsible-of how it could have been caught so nicely and has to seek $3.7m additional funding in these Appropriation Bills to rectify what at this stage can only be seen as a classic but all too common and continuing example of government bungling and inefficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) is a good opportunity to review the economic crisis Australia finds itself in today. It will be useful to examine how we actually got here. There seems to be general agreement that high interest rates-a deliberate policy of this Government-were the major cause.

SPEECH.PARA: The admitted purpose of high interest rates was to reduce economic activity with the purpose, in turn, of reducing imports and Australia's foreign debt. One could argue that this is indeed a sledge-hammer to crack a nut. The Australian Democrats have always argued that it is possible to reduce our imports-and they should be reduced-by specifically targeted measures. But unfortunately, the ideology that we now subscribe to as a nation, led by our econocrats, by this Government and by the Opposition, is that we must leave it to the marketplace. So the strategy was adopted to reduce economic activity across-the-board to reduce imports.

Now, after about 12 months of a gradually worsening recession, we have finally achieved some slight reduction in imports. In March the imports declined by $410m, still leaving us with a net trade deficit for the month of $1.2 billion, compared with $1.5 billion in February. Our foreign debt is still a net figure of $130 billion. Meanwhile, however, considerable damage has been done to the economy. Bankruptcies are up 53 per cent compared with a figure in March last year. In Victoria they are up 75 per cent. In the three-month period, 729 companies went to the wall and, Australia-wide, 844,000 people are unemployed-up 60 per cent on the figure of 524,700 a year ago.

It is an enormous waste of skills, experience and productive capacity and, on the other side of the ledger, there is mounting human misery multiplied many thousand times over, foreshadowing a rising crime rate, broken marriages, increased drug addiction and all the other socially corrosive consequences which follow inevitably when people are prevented from earning their own living. I will cite one example recently reported in the Melbourne Sun-Herald newspaper on 10 March 1991. I quote from an article by Nicole Newton headed, `Home violence soars as recession takes its toll'. The article states:
One of Victoria's three leading crisis contact points, the Women's Information and Referral Exchange, has reported a 100 per cent increase in cases of domestic violence compared with March last year.

It is the inevitable result of Government inaction, of `leaving it to the market'-today's doctrinaire ideology-which, in our view, is total abdication of responsibility which was aided and abetted by the Liberal-National Party coalition. Throughout this debate the conservative parties-the free marketeers-could hardly conceal their glee at having their policies implemented by a Labor government which had forgotten its roots, extinguished the light on the hill and busied itself selling strategic footholds in the economy such as the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The coalition parties are now wringing their hands and shedding crocodile tears but they are just as culpable as the Government-even more so, because it could be argued that the Government has not governed well but that the Opposition has totally forsaken its role of opposition, and the record shows it.

It will be useful and instructive to look at the record of cooperation between Tweedledum and Tweedledee. The old parties combined to vote against moves by the Democrats which were designed, firstly, to establish a register of foreign ownership of Australian land, property, business and resources as a first step to stop us selling our assets; secondly, to extend the general anti-tax avoidance provisions to all rebates, foreign tax credit and withholding tax to stop our revenue haemorrhaging as it has been for years; thirdly, to amend the Commonwealth Bank legislation to ensure that it could not be totally privatised and sold to foreign interests-commitments which were made to the Australian Labor Party caucus; and, fourthly, to prevent lifting the export market development grant threshold to levels which exclude most small businesses. Apparently this Government believes that big business only is entitled to get some assistance to increase our exports; and fifthly, to exempt from sales tax recycled plastics, recycled paper products and communication aids, cars and other equipment used by disabled people.

There are many other instances where the two old parties have combined to oppose Democrat reform initiatives, but these few examples illustrate clearly the view of economic policy that the Government and the coalition parties take severally and jointly as distinct from what it should be. Instead of abdicating responsibility to the marketplace-which has no values except the dollar sign on the balance sheet-economic policy and economic measures should be used to meet needs, goals and aspirations of people and, indeed, of the community as a whole.

In the view of the Democrats, a society which is socially and economically just, environmentally responsible and democratically controlled, should be the objective of a government policy designed to influence the economy to achieve these objectives. It is a concept and a vision which appears to be beyond the grasp of both of the old parties, which vie with each other in selling public assets and then creating the sort of dog-eat-dog society where the rich get richer and the poor are trampled underfoot in an inexorable cycle of disadvantage.

With an officially acknowledged unemployment rate of 10 per cent-probably more closely in the region of 15 per cent-and with a 27 per cent youth unemployment rate, it is time for the Government to acknowledge that Mr Keating's policies have failed and that carefully targeted government intervention is of the utmost urgency. In answer to a question of mine yesterday Senator Button, representing the Treasurer (Mr Keating), could not name one measure the Government would take to reverse the rising tide of unemployment. Let me offer, then, a few suggestions.

In the short term it is essential to stop the growing spate of business failures and to get people back to work. The first measure that the Australian Democrats would urge the Government to initiate is a further one per cent drop in interest rates. The second one would be elimination of payroll tax by the States, which could easily be paid for by a 2c a litre petrol excise and a 40 per cent lift in the excise on alcohol and tobacco. In the debate on Austudy yesterday I had occasion to challenge the Government to declare its priorities as to whether it wished to continue to have a 27 per cent youth unemployment rate, or whether it had the political will to get some means from an increased excise on alcohol and tobacco products which add to our health bill every day.

The next measure that the Democrats would favour is a 5 per cent bounty to be paid to exporters on new exports. Last year the Government would have paid $140m on additional exports of $2,800m. It would have been cheap to double that at a cost of a further $140m. The accelerated depreciation allowance, which was heralded with such a lot of noise in the industry statement, is little more than a technical adjustment. The Democrats believe that accelerated depreciation on manufacturing equipment to increase investment expenditure is essential in carefully targeted and selected industry sectors.

Mr Keating rightly chastised the business community for wasting the increased share of profits the accord has delivered to it since 1986. If business is not prepared to invest in Australia, then company tax should perhaps be increased again and the funds channelled into infrastructure and technological investment in government business enterprises. If that does not work, maybe we should introduce a research and development guarantee scheme, based on the training guarantee scheme model, to ensure that Australia's research and development expenditure continues to rise to a level approaching that existing in Japan, Switzerland, the United States and Germany. The situation is serious enough to move into pump priming by increased expenditure on public transport, public housing, education and scientific research and development.

But, as important as these measures are, they need to be supplemented by initiatives which enable at least some of the million or so Australians now on the scrap heap to move back into jobs quickly. Here the Democrats propose the community work program. This would be administered by local government and would be based on unemployed people in receipt of unemployment benefits carrying out labour intensive work at community level for pensioners, people with disabilities, hospitals, child-care centres and conservation projects. Unemployment benefits would be supplemented by an additional hourly payment to bring the total remuneration to award levels plus a margin for the administrative costs of local government.

Certainly, it is clear that social security provisions would have to be amended and that unions would have to be pacified. But that surely could be achieved in the face of the crisis in which we find ourselves. Surely one million unemployed, and 27 per cent unemployment among young people, can justify some administrative adjustments that we can make, provided we have the political will. This model was submitted to the Government as long ago as 1983. The then Minister for Social Security, Mr Don Grimes, submitted it to his Department. Unfortunately, the 1984 election stopped work on it and it has been forgotten ever since. It is now time that the responsible Ministers, Senator Richardson and Mr Dawkins, again look to a scheme of this nature to get people back to work.

I return to economic matters and to medium term strategies. These must include an overhaul of our education system with higher expenditure on buildings, equipment and teacher training and, most importantly, a substantial increase in the qualifications, professional dedication and, indeed, all-round quality and performance of our teachers and lecturers.

Readers of Tim Colebatch's article in the Age of 19 February and of a more recent article by Peter Smark, also in the Age, both detailing the performance and results of the German education system, will appreciate why the Democrats consider these proposals have such a high priority. The German economy can offer two other examples. Manufacturers spend five times as much on research, and worker participation in Germany is a reality, creating a partnership between labour and capital which shows results. In 1985, Germany lost 34,000 working days. The Australian economy, a quarter of the size, lost 1,256,200 working days. Germany shares with other successful economies, such as Japan, a strategic approach to the fostering of key industries with the potential to increase their exports and to develop employment.

It is time that Australia adopted a strategic support approach for industry sectors capable of significant expansion utilising our competitive advantages. One of these sectors would be environmental technology. Dr John Stocker, the Chief Executive of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, recently detailed the advantages and the head start that we possess in this industry. The areas include pollution control technology; technology for assessing and managing the environment; repairing environmental damage; development of alternative energy sources; and recycling.

The second industry that the Australian Democrats would name as an industry worthy of further development would be tourism. Inbound tourism is Australia's premier export industry. It is the biggest single earner of foreign exchange in the nation, accounting for 9 per cent of Australia's total export earnings. Last financial year it contributed more than $6 billion of Australia's export revenue ahead of coal, wool, iron ore and wheat. Over the past 35 years, inbound tourism has grown at an average rate of 13.5 per cent a year, faster than any other Australian industry.

Finally, manufacturing generally should concentrate on value added production for products such as wool-and this is not an advertisement for Mr Jeff Kennett. Developing manufacturing sectors for the environmental technology industry and industries such as wine and food products should be further encouraged, given growing international demand for pollution-free produce.

Australia should consider tax incentives such as long term accelerated depreciation, which I have mentioned before, to provide certainty and encouragement for investment. We should examine other possible incentives provided by some of our international competitors-for instance, a five-year tax exemption for 50 per cent of export income. We should target infrastructure expenditure to industry sectors which are capable of picking up the sort of initiatives that I have detailed.

We have seen in the last few weeks a distinct change in the climate of the environment of our commerce and industry leaders. I refer to an article in the Australian of 30 April where Mr Douglas Brass, the Managing Director of Pacific Dunlop Ltd, is quoted as saying:
``But I am talking about sector winners-mining and energy-let's try and attract investment into those to add value.
``A worry is that our Government has shown itself to be very much persuaded by trade negotiations.

``In Malaysia, they looked at rubber, put an export tax on raw rubber and gave tax incentives to manufacturers so all of a sudden you have the price of rubber coming down because of the export tax and giving credit back to people who add value.
Further on the article states:

Mr Brass said exceptionally high tariffs were a problem for Australia as an exporter but said no tariffs meant that unless micro-reforms took place, there would be a manufacturing industry in this country.

It is very clear that we cannot proceed along the lines that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) outlined when he said that, no matter what our competitors do, we will lie back and reduce our tariff protection totally and allow other people's products to come into Australia when our own manufacturers are suffering from the Government's inaction and from the Government's and the Opposition's adherence to the gospel of free market ideology, which takes account of no values, which shrugs its shoulders when we have one million people and 27 per cent of our young people unemployed. It is time that we changed. It is time that the Government took action to target our economy into activities which realise the goals and aspirations of ordinary Australians.

Senator Spindler spoke about some changes in the tax policies which he felt were appropriate. I have raised the issue of the Australian Democrats tax policies in this chamber before and have been subjected to fairly vigorous exchanges from the Democrat senators on my left-hand side.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past I have suggested that the Democrats were in favour of wealth taxes, a capital gains tax on the family home, higher income taxes and death duties. Yesterday, Senator Lees took me to task on this, as indeed did Senator Bell. Senator Bell took up this theme and argued, and I quote:

There is no mention . . . of a capital gains tax on the family home. Anybody who can identify that as a Democrat policy has looked at policies that certainly I have never taken part in promoting . . .

I was a bit surprised that when I left the chamber I was subjected to fairly vigorous debate from Senator Spindler, who was clearly unhappy with my comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said wealthy people.

— Senator Spindler now says that these taxes apply only to wealthy people, that this vast range of Australian Democrats taxes apply only to wealthy people. I question whether that is in fact the case. Last night Senator Lees and Senator Bell spent a considerable time explaining that people can be asset rich yet income poor. It is more than probable that the people to whom Senator Lees and Senator Bell were referring, people who are suffering because of the assets test on Austudy, could in fact be hit by the Democrats wealth taxes. It is unlikely that Senator Spindler could stand up here and say that my comments in this regard were inaccurate.

SPEECH.PARA: To take another example: the Democrats policy itself says that capital gains tax is payable on an inherited residence. This is either a death duty or a capital gains tax. We have a Labor Government that finds it very difficult to make any substantial cuts in expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—As a consequence, the Labor Government is ceaselessly seeking new forms of revenue, such as capital gains tax. The Minister for Administrative Affairs, Senator Bolkus, may laugh, but people are nervous about the Democrats' wealth tax policies, capital gains tax policies and higher marginal income tax rate policies because they are an open invitation to the Labor Government to bring in some more taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been very careful to read the Democrats' policy documents. I do not believe that Senator Spindler's interpretation of those policies is correct. TALK.START.PARA: —On economic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Martin Ferguson.

—As Mr Martin Ferguson has told us, the accord is part and parcel of this Government. I think this is quite an extraordinary statement but also an accurate statement. There is no question that the trade union movement is part and parcel of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorts of measures that I have mentioned are relevant in measuring the effectiveness of the accord, but the bottom line for most families is what has happened to their living standard. I think that is a fair enough measure. The typical Australian perhaps does not focus in the way that we do on things like micro-reform but thinks of what has happened to his living standard, what has happened to his job and whether he is likely to hold onto his job in this climate or whether he is likely to join the growing queues of unemployed.

Senator Cook has spent a considerable amount of time in this chamber attempting to justify the accord with the trade union movement on the basis of outcomes. There is less talk these days from Senator Cook on such matters as economic growth and its natural partner, job growth. The figures that were released last week show that unemployment has risen to over 10 per cent. Some are predicting that it could rise to 12 per cent or more.

Senator Cook still continues to defend the accord and its outcomes. In a speech last week in this chamber, Senator Cook pointed out that this Government is about creating a framework which enables moderate wage outcomes to be achieved and which enables-and this is the important point-living standards in the broader community to be protected. I have spoken before in the chamber-and Senator Faulkner will certainly remember this-on the issue of living standards and how we measure living standards. Do we use average weekly earnings or such measures as household disposable incomes?

Senator Cook has been very vigorous in telling us that we should be measuring household disposable incomes per capita. According to Senator Cook, that is the central measure of living standards in the community. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may recall that on a number of occasions last year Senator Cook was asked-by Senator McKiernan on one occasion and Senator Childs on another; and I have no doubt that if Senator Faulkner could read a question he would probably have been given one too- `What has happened to household disposable incomes?'. That would be the sort of question asked. Senator Bolkus may be interested to know that I have not heard any such questions this year.

Senator Cook replied to such questions with a fairly standard brief: when looking at the well-being of families, real household disposable income per capita is the real test. One wonders why we have not had any of those questions recently. I ask Senator Bolkus whether it is because household disposable income has perhaps taken a serious fall. If I was asked that question by Senator Bolkus, I would have to reply, `You are right, household disposable income is falling, and falling sharply'.

In answer to the question from Senator McKiernan just six months ago, which I mentioned earlier, Senator Cook said that household disposable income had risen by 11 per cent since the start of this Government in contrast to the Fraser years, when growth was somewhat lower. He said that that figure was probably around 7 per cent. The question to be asked six months later is: what has happened to household disposable income since the start of the Hawke Government? I can tell Senator Faulkner and Senator Bolkus that household income has not increased by 11 per cent since the advent of the Hawke Government; household disposable income has increased only by 7 per cent.

That explains why we have had no questions to Senator Cook on the central issue of living standards. What is of fundamental concern to a Labor member of Parliament? Perhaps I am being somewhat naive, but I would have thought that the fundamental concern of a Labor member of Parliament or a trade union leader would be what is happening to the living standards of Australian workers. In the last three quarters, we have had the most savage fall in household disposable incomes per capita since at least 1975. I followed the figures back to 1975 and could not go any further. Rather than getting up and defending the accord day after day, I would have thought that Mr Martin Ferguson and Senator Cook would have started to show some concern. Indeed, one would have hoped that his back bench would have started to show some concern about what is happening to the living standards of Australian workers. The question could then be asked by Senator Faulkner-if he ever wanted to ask a question in this place- `You say, Senator Kemp, that living standards have risen by only 7 per cent since the advent of the Hawke Government. What is going to happen in the future?'.

I think that would be a very good question. I would very much welcome a Labor senator standing up in the chamber and putting that question to Senator Cook. TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you smile when you say that?
—I smile because Senator Bolkus seems so utterly confused about this. Household disposable income is not a complex measure.
—You smile at other people's problems; you have no sensitivity at all.
—For Senator Bolkus to tell me that I have no sensitivity at all is really something. He is a man who lacks many virtues. We could never point to him, saying that he is a sensitive Minister.
—I would not want you to think that.

—Senator Bolkus should be interested in this because it is about the living standards of Australian workers. Why do I say that the prospects for living standards for Australian workers are particularly grim? Senator Faulkner could get his Budget Papers, turn to the relevant table, and perhaps be comforted by the fact that the Government said that in the forthcoming year household disposable income was going to rise by a certain amount. If Senator Faulkner turned to the Budget Papers today, he would not find any reference to a forecast of household disposable income. I suggest to Senator Bolkus that the reason for this is simply that the forecast is grim, and rightly so.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of the economy that makes us feel that household disposable income per capita and living standards will continue to fall is that unemployment is now rising and farm incomes are falling in a catastrophic fashion. Those two features will probably have a very adverse effect on household disposable incomes in the current year.

I have to say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it comes as a surprise to me and to the great proportion of supporters of Senator Faulkner and Senator Bolkus, who are great men of the Left-the big men of the Left who are present in the chamber-that they, above all, should have evinced some concern about what has happened to the living standards of Australian workers under their accord. It was very interesting that today Mr Martin Ferguson, on the radio program A.M.--

TALK.START.PARA: —Comrade Ferguson.

—I ask Senator Faulkner whether he listened to Comrade Ferguson. When the trade union leader, the head of the peak council of trade unions in this country, was asked whether he could find anything critical to say about the Government, whether there was anything wrong with Government policy-this is the Government which has now created the worst recession since 1930, which has created the highest foreign debt in our history, which has given us record interest rates and record bankruptcies and which has policies that day by day are throwing Australian workers out of jobs- he said that nothing was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: When the history of this period is written-and it will start to be written fairly soon-we will be able to evaluate, with the advantage of hindsight, thank God, the performance of Ministers such as Senator Bolkus and deputy whips such as Senator Faulkner, and what they did in this last decade. We will evaluate what they did for Australian workers and for Australian families. I suggest that historians will ask this question: why did the Labor Party persevere with a policy that destroyed the employment prospects and living standards of the Australian worker? There is no argument about that now. Living standards and employment prospects have collapsed.

Mr Martin Ferguson, the comrade of Senator Faulkner, in his defence of government policies over the last nine years, has demonstrated that the interests of union leaders and union members are not one and the same. TALK.START.PARA: —In the seven minutes remaining before the dinner recess, after which I shall resume my remarks at 8 p.m., I wish to outline some of the things I would like to address in the course of my speech on the Appropriation Bills. At the outset I would like to talk generally about the state of the nation as it is, left to us by the hands of the likes of the Ministers who sit across the way. These Appropriation Bills are evidence of the collapse of the Government's fiscal strategy. Let us consider that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) passed this Parliament only months before a Bill of its kind generally would. We then had the passage of a loans Bill, the first of its kind since 1987. This meant that for the first time in a number of years the Government found that the amount in the consolidated revenue fund was insufficient to meet the ongoing expenditure requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: It used to be regarded as a simple mechanism for making the books balance. For years we had a Treasurer who trumpeted loud and wide that we did not require that strategy or mechanism because his budgeting skills were so great that there was sufficient surplus for it not to be necessary. However, this year has seen the true state of the nation and once again it required the passage of a loans Bill.

Today we are witnessing the expenditure of a blowout born of the Government's policy-induced recession. According to the Government tax revenue estimates, every area of Government revenue is now well behind original Budget forecasts. I think it is worth while seeing where those shortfalls lie. Net pay as you earn (PAYE) collections in the eight months to February are said to be $1.65 billion behind Budget estimates. This reflects a $1.384 billion reduction in estimated PAYE collections, and a blowout of $266m in PAYE funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't be reading this, would you?

—Those figures are so horrendous that one could expect them to be etched in the minds of many Australians. However, to make sure they are accurate, they are written down. Indeed, in terms of the human suffering of people who are no longer in a position to make a PAYE payment because they no longer have a job, I hope that the Minister has the good grace to look shamefaced when he realises that those reductions in revenue represent crushed lives.

SPEECH.PARA: Company tax receipts are down by at least $377m from a Budget estimate of $10.041 billion. Withholding tax receipts are down $62m, while sales tax receipts have fallen by $614m. It should be remembered that these figures are based on only eight months to February, and are bound to be much worse for the full financial year. Again, let us look at those PAYE receipts for the full financial year which will be down $3 billion, while sales tax receipts are expected to be down by some $1 billion. In all, the total revenue has been predicted as being short of the budgeted forecasts by a massive $4.4 billion. On the outlays side, expenditure in the current financial year is expected to blow out by between $1.6 billion and $2.6 billion. Again, those figures simply tell the tale of the tragedy that has been forced on the Australian people by a Government which personally designed a recession which it said we had to have. What a mockery it makes of the Government's flaunted big budget surpluses in recent times. They were a fraud from the start and they are a fraud at the finish. They were a fraud in that they were financed by bracket creep, high taxes and massive cuts in payments to the States. In short, the Government has simply misled the Australian people in proclaiming those surpluses in that it took from the States and effectively gave itself a rise in the section of the income tax dollar which it commandeered to itself by over 5 per cent.

The Opposition has consistently called on the Government to adopt a strategy to curb inflation, which has become a fundamental problem in the Australian economy but, when it came to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), our words landed on deaf ears. Mr Keating refused to accept that inflation reduction had to become the prime macro-economic policy goal of the nation. But guess what? In November last there was yet another conversion on the road to Damascus. Confronted with a near satisfactory consumer price index outcome for the September quarter, the Treasurer had seized on the figure as being an economic policy success for the Government, but someone forgot to tell him that the figure was consequent on a virtual collapse in asset prices. A price freeze on petrol had little more than a side effect of his deliberately engineered recession.

In fact, Opposition members did tell him. He simply did not bother to listen. One does not have to be the world's greatest Treasurer to appreciate that if one creates the environment in which 750,000 workers are thrown onto the dole queues and where a record number of businesses are forced to go bankrupt, there will not be some sort of trade-off with lower inflation. If the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has set the Government a 4 per cent inflation target, one wonders what is in store for those workers lucky enough still to have jobs or those firms that are not in the red. For this Government there is no reason to gloat over lower inflation figures. Again, they represent the pain that has been inflicted unnecessarily.

Instead of inducing lower inflation with the recession, it should have come about through improved labour market flexibility where wage rises were the product of productivity improvement, and not the farce we have seen in what has passed for an acceptable so-called wages policy and the late lamented accord. It should also not be forgotten that the only free policy arm of government in recent years has been monetary policy. With the interaction of the wage-tax trade-off, the fastening together of fiscal and wages policy has been to impose the bulk of the burden of aggregated demand restraint onto monetary policy. What a blunt instrument it has turned out to be. The Government has grossly overestimated the required changes to monetary policy to bring about its outcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the sitting was suspended for dinner at 6.30 p.m. I was dealing with the total mismanagement of the economy by this present Government. I was dealing specifically with the way in which the monetary policy had been used. I was about to make the point that, clearly, what we require is a much better attitude and a better policy with regard to an independent central bank, armed with the brief that its main purpose is to control inflation and, indeed, the tool for achieving that would be monetary policy. That, in turn, now leads me to the knowledge that when a government gets out of touch with reality, as this one has, there is a tendency that many of its public servants will do likewise. It is this sort of thing that we discover when we go to the Estimates committees hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say right at the outset that the Estimates committees are but a part of the whole system of scrutiny which is conducted to allow the expenditure of public money, and those who spend it, to be accountable to the Parliament. There are, of course, committees such as the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and other committees of scrutiny, such as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. There is, of course, the linchpin in the whole of this operation, the Auditor-General. Indeed, the Public Accounts Committee brought down that now very well-known report entitled The Auditor General: Ally of the People and Parliament which describes very aptly the pivotal role which the Auditor-General holds in the whole question of scrutiny.

Thus, when we go to the Estimates committees hearings the material we look at is not only the program notes-the explanatory notes which accompany the documentation with which we deal-but also things such as annual reports and, indeed, the Auditor-General's reports. As we go through that process of scrutiny we find some officers in the Public Service who give straightforward and informative answers, and who attempt to assist the Committee in its deliberations. But we find, and have found over the years, others who obviously have no wish to cooperate with the committees or the committee system at all. Indeed, one could be pardoned for saying that some of them hold the Parliament in contempt. I take that attitude right back to the attitude that the Government holds.

On many occasions I have described this Government as being peopled with members and senators who hold no regard or feeling for the parliamentary tradition or, indeed, the knowledge that it is the Parliament to whom executives and the Public Service must be accountable if we are to have a working democracy. If one looks at the Hansards of those Estimates committees hearings, and if one reads the reports and some of the answers that have been furnished, one will find that that unfortunate attitude does prevail.

But quite an interesting thing occurs. After matters have been raised it is by no means an uncommon occurrence for people such as myself and other honourable senators to receive telephone calls, letters or documentation from people who have either read a report of what has transpired or, indeed, read the Hansard itself, and have felt that they could add something to the debate with the knowledge that is peculiar to them. As usual, following this series of Estimates committees hearings exactly that process has taken place. Tonight in my contribution to the second reading debate I intend to touch on some of the things with which we dealt in Estimates Committee A, one or two matters which were dealt with in Estimates Committee B and flag that, when we come to the Committee of the Whole, many questions will be pursued as a result of further information that has come to hand.

Dealing with the Estimates Committee A report, some of the more important issues with which we dealt come early in it. The first one was the question of parliamentary security-something which has had a good deal of attention again in the last few days. The public, when they read about, and are informed of what is happening, by way of stories that are written or interviews which are given on radio and television-which, presumably, under the Government's new legislation would be banned; at least for the electronic media-show that they are quite angered by the cavalier attitude that prevails.

In dealing with parliamentary security we had certain examples of the way that that security is lax. We also saw when the subject was broached that, firstly, there was a not clear understanding of where authority lies-of who should make the final decisions; and, secondly, there was a complacency about the way in which security is administered.

The security in this building costs the taxpayers several millions of dollars and yet the evidence that was given in the Estimates Committee hearing itself was highly unsatisfactory. We have recorded in the report the farcical-indeed, shall we say Monty Pythonesque-situation whereby somebody was caught in the act of stealing. The police were called and declined to lay charges; an internal committee inquiry was held; that person was sacked; that person appealed; and that person is now a security officer again. As a result of that coming out, more information has come to hand and we will deal with that when we come to the Committee of the Whole.

The Clerk of the Senate said that this was a matter of grave concern, but the question is: what sort of messages are we sending out? In this place it is quite common that people who have things stolen from their offices do not even bother to report it. The reason they do not bother to report it is that they feel it is pointless because nothing will happen about it.

When a very valuable painting in this building was damaged-as it was during that notorious party held by the Treasurer, Mr Keating-we had a security officer whose idea of a follow-up investigation was to interview 12 people and say, `It's all too hard, I can't solve it'. He then sent the bill for the conservation attention that the painting required, not to the Treasurer personally, but to the Department of the Treasury. A further bill for $50, which was discussed in the Supplementary Estimates, to continue the inspection of that painting to see whether its condition had deteriorated was, again, sent to the Department, not to the individual.

The messages we send out are that the security in this place is lax; that, really, one can get away with anything; and that the sorts of things that occur are the sorts of things that happen, in a very pertinent way, to people on this side of the House in that a video recorder was stolen from the party room of the Opposition and nobody turned a hair. Larger items have walked out of here and if we had a better security system in place something could be done about it. I really want to see some attention given to the problem, some plan of action devised and some propositions put to the Presiding Officers so that there will be an examination of what is a better way in which to conduct the security of this building. Tonight, I have not even touched upon the incident of the Iraqi diplomat who was free to walk around this building during the Gulf war.

We then dealt with question of the Governor-General's overseas trip. The rationale for a trip that encompassed Rome, London, New York and Hawaii was basically that it was an economy measure to buy an around the world ticket instead of a straight Sydney to London ticket, which would have enabled the Governor-General to have his discussion with the Queen. The saving of buying such a ticket would be $2,500 to $3,000 per passenger travelling first class. Presumably the Governor-General and Mrs Hayden were accompanied by an entourage, but I do not know the numbers involved. We have asked for details of that.

I find it quite an interesting set of arithmetic that says that, to save $6,000, we should take in three other capital cities, with the associated accommodation and various other associated charges. It may well be that it is important for the Governor-General to go on a visit to the centres of Rome, New York and Hawaii. The answers we were given are recorded in the Hansard and I shall leave it for others to judge whether they were sufficiently important to be included.

We then come to a very serious matter-the way in which the Auditor-General is regarded by at least one very senior officer of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC). I find this sort of attitude almost reprehensible. It is the sort of attitude that places that whole system of scrutiny at risk. The Auditor-General reported in his report that officers within DITAC had first applied for an advance to the Minister for Finance in order that a particular bill could be paid. The Minister for Finance rejected that application. What did the Department then do? It took money out of another appropriation and spent that money on something for which the appropriation was not made; that is, an illegal payment was made. The law was broken-both the Constitution and the Audit Act.

What response do we get to that? We heard Dr Bell say, `We have a genuine difference of opinion with the AuditorGeneral'. `There are often differences between the departments and the Auditor-General and this is just one'. `It is a technicality'. `Mistakes do happen'. That is just not good enough. There was a brighter side to that story and that was that the Department of Finance, on seeing and hearing what occurred in that hearing, contacted DITAC and administered what can only be interpreted as a reprimand. That is a very serious occurrence. If the departments and the officers in those departments do not acknowledge that the Auditor-General has found a most important breach and dismiss it as a technicality, the whole system of scrutiny and accountability starts to break down. That is exactly the sort of situation we had in the inquiry into the Parliamentary Information Systems Office which came before this place some months ago and was investigated by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on reference from the Senate. The finding was that more illegalities had taken place.

A pleasing result of that matter is that certain secretaries of departments have taken that matter very much in hand and do instruct their employees that they are public servants; that they are covered by the Public Service Act; that they are concerned with the Audit Act and the Crimes Act and, of course, the Constitution; and that they are in no way immune or exempt from complying with the law. One would have thought that was axiomatic. But, quite clearly, what has crept into the culture is that some people think they are above the law. It just will not do.

I move on to another serious occurrence in Austrade. It was quite late at night when we dealt with Austrade. We dealt with a fraud which had been perpetrated on the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) of $16m. We heard evidence that this was a very clever con trick which had been perpetrated against EFIC in which $16m of what was effectively taxpayers' money had been successfully siphoned off. From there we went onto a case of the building of a boat for one Mr Cantor in Queensland, where a loan of $8m at 8 per cent for eight years was made by EFIC to Mr Cantor to build a boat. We then heard that Mr Cantor was subsequently arrested and charged with defrauding the United States Federal Bureaucracy Trustee of more than $1m.

In questioning about the $16m scam, my colleague Senator Short had asked the General Manager of EFIC whether with hindsight it had put in place better scrutiny so that it would not be defrauded again. Dr Fisher went on to assure Senator Short and the Committee that much better mechanisms were in place that would ensure that would not happen again. I then asked Dr Fisher whether with the new mechanisms in place he could assure me that the likes of Mr Cantor, who is known to have affiliations with the Mafia, would not get in the door. I got no such assurance. I was simply told that he was paying his bills. I ultimately got a statement that the arrest took place after the agreement had been entered into and therefore could not really have been taken account of.

The worrying aspect of that-and we will have more questions to ask in the Committee of the Whole-is that I have had more information; that is, that the arrest took place in May 1987 but the contract was not signed until October 1987. In fact, the contract was signed after Mr Cantor had been arrested. Dr Fisher did not seem to be particularly worried that an arrest was a determining factor because there was no conviction. My point is that Mr Cantor is not the sort of person we would expect a public authority to be lending taxpayers' money to.

But the story does not end there. The sum involved is not $8m; it is more like $16m. As well as the $8m payment, I am informed-and we shall ask questions and ascertain whether it is true-that, in addition to the $8m loan, DITAC made a bounty payment of $3m; that the company building the boat raised and expended $2.5m because the architect of the boat made changes and that $2.5m was guaranteed by EFIC; and that, when the company went bust, because of the changes that were perpetually made by Mr Cantor, EFIC had to pay out another $2.5m. Then there was the form of a performance bond which was entered into to underwrite the boat builder's performance and the creditors were owed a further $2.5m. So we paid out another $2.5m.

The company itself believed that it had a good claim of $6m which could be pursued by the liquidator. But guess what? It is not being pursued. The bottom line is that we have had Mr Cantor allegedly going around New York boasting that he has had a boat worth $25m built courtesy of the Australian Government, and that is where $16m has gone. I think Senator Richardson described former Premier Brian Burke as being guilty of sloppy administration. This is what I would call very sloppy administration, and when we come to the Committee of the Whole there are many questions along those lines that I will be wanting answers to.

We then move on to the Australian Customs Service, where we seem to have officers who have very bad memories appear before Estimates Committee A. I think honourable senators will recall that at the end of the last Estimates hearings, after the Budget, the Committee took a very long time to complete its inquiries, largely because again and again, particularly with DITAC and in dealing with program 2-the Australian Customs Service-we had answers such as, `I do not know', `I am not briefed on that' and so on. A tortuous path we had to traverse.

It has ended in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts investigating the Customs Service and its activities, an investigation which has been forestalled at the moment because of a request from the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). Subsequently, we will be able to discuss the reasons that the DPP asked for hearings not to be held and whether that was the way to proceed.

In dealing with the Supplementary Estimates we again went along the path of finding the Customs Service unable to answer questions that were asked. We have now received lengthy answers-some of which are satisfactory and some of which are not. They are carefully couched in language designed to make us think one thing but which, if we probe a little further, we find means another. Again, we will be asking questions concerning that matter.

In addressing the second reading of the Appropriation Bills, we find the country in a pretty sad state. We have the former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, saying that we are in a depression. We have hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians out of work, in danger of losing their homes. We have people who have spent 20 years of their lives building businesses losing everything. We have a Treasurer (Mr Keating) who talks about beautiful numbers.

When we go to the detail of the manner in which the taxpayer's dollar is spent, we find that the cavalier attitude that is prevalent in the Government is reflected in too many of the people who come before those committees. Honourable senators should not get me wrong; there are very good members of the Public Service who appear at these committees-people who genuinely want to see the system work. This becomes very apparent when one is later asked to go to address meetings of people who really want to understand the accountability process more. That is very gladdening for the heart.

At the end of the day, at the end of this process, I can only say that it is a sorry state. But I hope, as we start to move forward, to see a new dawn-which must come with a new government-that there will be some hope for this land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dealing with the elements of the financial situation facing Australia at the moment and the horrendous unemployment, I raise another matter which I believe is of some concern. It relates to the Government's handling of, and the involvement of the Australian Labor Party in, the reception for the President of Turkey, Mr Ozal, and the demonstrations against Mr Ozal. In particular, I draw to the Senate's attention the manner in which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was basically abandoned by his Cabinet and by his Ministry at the State reception for Mr Ozal.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw to the Senate's attention the fact that, to my certain knowledge, a member of the staff of a senior New South Wales Labor member of parliament was involved in organising protest rallies against the Turkish President. The member of Parliament whose staff member was involved was Mr Laurie Brereton. I have no position either way on the rights or wrongs of a member of Mr Brereton's staff doing whatever he likes in these matters provided, of course, they are not in breach of the law. It is up to Mr Brereton to determine whether it is proper for his staff member to become involved in the organising of such protests. I understand that there is a great deal of feeling among the communities in Australia whose origins are Greek, Armenian and Kurdish. But, that said, it is no doubt appropriate for Mr Brereton to dissociate himself from his staffer's activities if, in fact, Mr Brereton intends to be dissociated from those activities.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the most extraordinary event that took place in this building at the official reception, the governmental reception, for the President of Turkey. I do not remember a head of state attending a formal dinner of this kind to find that 10 of the 17 members of the Cabinet were not present and that only two of the outer Ministry were present. In other words, a total of only nine out of 34 Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries attended a major function, a major reception, for the President, the head of state, of a friendly nation, who had just been invested with the Order of Australia by the Australian Prime Minister. It was an incredible situation.

What is more incredible is to note who of the Hawke Ministry did not attend the reception. I may as well start second from the top. I do not know what pressing engagement forced the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Keating, not to attend. One would have thought that a reception of this significance for a head of state would have encouraged the Deputy Prime Minister perhaps to miss whatever other appointment he had. There is no doubt, for example, that he certainly was not invited to participate in the New South Wales election on that day. The New South Wales Opposition, led by Mr Carr, has shown no interest at all in having any of the senior members of this Government assist it in its doomed venture to try to win power in New South Wales. I note, for example, that Mr Carr contrived to have the opening of his campaign on a day that Mr Hawke was, regrettably, unable to attend because of the sitting of Parliament.

Mr Keating was not there; Mr Duffy was not there; Mr Howe was not there; Dr Blewett, I think, was overseas and certainly was not there. Senator the Hon. Graham Frederick Richardson was not there-I underline that name. The Hon. Gerry Hand was not there; the Hon. Brian Howe was not there; Senator Peter Cook was not there; and Senator Nick Bolkus was not there-I could hardly have expected Senator Bolkus to attend in the circumstances.

Those of the outer Ministry who did not turn up were Senator Tate, Mr Staples, Mr Bob Brown, Mr David Simmons, Mr Peter Baldwin, Mr David Beddall, Mr Gordon Bilney, Senator Bob Collins, Mr Simon Crean, Ms Wendy Fatin, Mr Robert Tickner, Mr Ross Free, Senator McMullan, Mr Con Sciacca and Mr Warren Snowdon.

The reason I particularly underlined Senator Richardson's name was that he joined a large group of senior Labor people from New South Wales who absented themselves from this most significant dinner for a head of state. Among others of that ilk who managed to avoid attending were the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr McLeay; Mr Brereton who, with Senator Richardson, is the well-known fishing mate of some Western Australian mates of the Prime Minister; Mrs Crosio and Mr Punch.

Quite frankly, looking through this list I wondered just how many of the Prime Minister's New South Wales supporters and mates actually did attend this dinner? I am not an expert in Labor Party cabals, but it seemed to me that very few of his group of intimate supporters in New South Wales attended the function. Clearly, these great supporters of Mr Hawke, his right-wing buddies in New South Wales, abandoned him on this occasion. By the way, I have just noticed that I missed out Senator Button; he also did not attend. The great bulk of the senior members of the Labor Party in this Parliament abandoned the Prime Minister on this occasion and so did his right-wing mates in New South Wales. They abandoned the Prime Minister because he made an awful mess of this whole situation; just the latest of the awful political messes that he has been making so frequently in recent times. The main members of the Labor Ministry were notable more by their absence than their presence at this reception. I must say I find it extraordinary.

I am not suggesting that everyone is of one mind on the difficulties between Greece and Turkey over Cyprus; I am not suggesting that these are not matters of some substance. I am not going into the merit of those matters. What I am going into the merit of is the insult accorded to a visiting head of state by the leading members of this Government not attending such a function. While that insult is a matter that the Turks can work out for themselves, maybe there is a political significance as well.

If Mr Hawke's right wing colleagues in Cabinet and in the outer Ministry and the backbenchers from New South Wales who help to keep him in office are prepared to abandon him in a situation like this, where they leave the Prime Minister exposed in a reception of this kind-clearly indicating their objection to his decision to honour the President of Turkey with the Order of Australia-then I wonder how committed they are to sticking with him on the leadership. I wonder when they are going to abandon him on that. It would seem to me that when one looks at absentees like Mr McLeay and Mr Brereton, for example, one wonders what the New South Wales operational heavyweights are up to; particularly when one adds Senator Richardson to that band.

There is no doubt that politically Mr Hawke's hopeless mismanagement of this matter has generated the quite proper response: the Turks are very unimpressed by the Prime Minister; the Greeks are also very unimpressed, as are the Armenians and the Kurds. Once again, he has demonstrated his remarkable ability to get everyone offside and drop the ball. One wonders how long such a Prime Minister is going to stay in office when he is so readily abandoned by his colleagues.

I finish up by expressing my concern about the role of a staffer of one of the Prime Minister's colleagues in organising demonstrations against Mr Ozal, particularly when I understand that the staffer expressed concern that it would cost something like $25,000 to organise the Canberra demonstration. I wonder who paid that $25,000. I wonder whether Mr Brereton can assist us in explaining what really happened.

By the way, this question of absence from the function in the Great Hall of this Parliament just reminds me of the fact that when this Parliament House was officially opened by the Queen two years ago there was a major function to which members of parliament were invited and we sat in the Great Hall to participate in that ceremony. However, former distinguished parliamentarians such as Senator Carrick, who was Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Margaret Guilfoyle, a very distinguished Minister in this place for many years and a whole range of former Ministers were excluded from the Great Hall during that ceremony so that the friends of the Prime Minister could attend-his fishing mates from Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Burke!
—Yes, the Premier of Western Australia attended. I do not remember, by the way, whether Mr Burke was still Premier of Western Australia at that time.
—He was a has-been by then, thank heavens.

—He was a has-been. Frankly, I do not know which of the Prime Minister's mates attended because when we asked for a list of those who attended, we were denied it. We members of parliament were not to be told who were the Prime Minister's mates who had in fact pushed our former colleagues, senior parliamentarians, out of the Great Hall for that function.
—Former Ministers.

—Yes, former Ministers of the Crown-people who had in fact made the decision to build this place were excluded from the Great Hall ceremony officially opening it so that Mr Hawke's mates could attend. It might be very interesting if at last the Government changed its mind and allowed the freedom of information, to which it gives lip service, to actually apply in this case so that we could see which of Mr Hawke's mates who attended that gathering are not subject to the sort of court procedures that so many of them seem to be subject to at the moment. Maybe Mr Hawke could clear the matter up by listing them for us.

SPEECH.PARA: That matter just sprung to mind. When I looked at how many of the Government's Ministers did not attend this state dinner in honour of the President of Turkey I was reminded of those of our former distinguished colleagues who were not allowed to attend another major function in that Hall. As I recall, I think most of the officers who serve us in this chamber were not permitted to attend. Perhaps the Clerk was permitted to attend, but no other officers who run this place were permitted to attend.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are often excluded from a lot of things.

—Senator Knowles is correct and it is quite wrong that that is the case. The next matter I want to deal with relating to mates is the scandalous situation in Victoria where the Australian Council of Trade Unions engaged in clear, uncomplicated blackmail of Tennis Australia as to whether there should have been demonstrations at the last national open. There was a question as to whether that blackmail would be pursued through the courts. The Herald-Sun has been running very properly a dramatic series of exposures on this issue. I am astounded to see that a decision has been taken by the Victorian Government not to prosecute anyone over the affair. This was a case of clear, uncomplicated blackmail. A demand was made on Tennis Australia for a $10,000 donation in exchange for peace at this year's Australian Open. I referred to this incident at the time in this place as blackmail. As the Herald-Sun says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there was an attempt to get Tennis Australia to hand over a $10,000 donation to the National Olympic Sports Congress of South Australia in exchange for a guarantee that the Australian Open would not be disrupted by anti-apartheid demonstrations.

. . . the president of Tennis Australia, Mr Geoff Pollard, said the demand was made first at a face to face meeting with him by the president of the ACTU, Mr Martin Ferguson, the Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council, Mr John Halfpenny-
I think he is now a former mate. The article continues:

and a spokesman for the Anti-Apartheid Movement (Vic), Mr David Howes. This verbal demand was followed by a letter making the same demand. It was written on ACTU letterhead and was signed by Messrs Ferguson and Howes. Mr Halfpenny's name was also typed at the bottom of the letter, but he had not signed it.

It is astounding that the Chief Commissioner of Police in Victoria, Mr Kel Glare, announced 10 days or so ago a police decision not to prosecute following legal advice from the Victorian Government Solicitor. But he would not reveal the detail of the Victorian Government Solicitor's advice.

The Leader of the National Party in Victoria, Mr McNamara, in a letter to Mr Glare, has claimed that the prosecuting police recommended prosecution, which was not proceeded with. As the Herald-Sun says, this brings us to the most puzzling aspect of the affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Special laws for special mates.
—I agree with Senator Kemp. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . why, as seems the case, did Mr Glare not forward the papers to the Director of Public Prosecutions, rather than the Victorian Government Solicitor? Or if Mr Glare did so, what did the DPP say?

The reason the Herald-Sun is quite right in raising this matter is because the office of the DPP was established soon after Mr Cain came to power in Victoria, before he started to dig a hole both for himself and for his State. The article says:

It had long been his aim to remove the decision on prosecutions in indictable offences from the political process. As he remarked when he created the post in 1982: ` `In the UK, the concept puts it outside the government.''

I totally agree with the conclusions of the Herald-Sun. If there was ever an argument for ensuring that strict impartiality was being maintained, the Tennis Australia affair, involving as it does political figures, is a glaring example. The article continues:

A former chairman of the Criminal Bar Association, Mr Col Lovitt, QC, declares himself ``mystified'' by Mr Glare's rationale. He believes, as we do, that the process by which the police decision against prosecution was reached must be spelt out in detail in the public interest.

More and more, the matter of mates is expressing itself in different ways. Let us have a look at what mates are doing to the Australian economy. Earlier this evening we heard Senator Maguire having what could politely be described as a go at me; he beat me with a feather. He claimed that I had misled the Parliament on sales tax. He withdrew the word `misled' when he realised-not as a result of any pressure from this side of the House-that he was talking absolute rubbish. This Treasurer has ceased to express an interest in his old plan for a broadly based consumption tax, because it is self-evidently true that he has largely introduced one by stealth. I have often said in this place that we have plenty of evidence of that in the extended sales tax, which is a consumption tax by another name. The consumption tax has been extended to foods like ice cream and orange juice. Is orange juice not a food? It has also been extended to include flavoured milk, confectionary and wine-and so it goes on; there is quite a list. Certainly this tax is not on all foods; I have never claimed that it was. Senator Maguire must be in some dreamland.

I have said-and it is evident from the facts; Mr Keating has said it himself-that the scope available for a consumption tax when he was pushing it some years ago is not there because of the way he has extended the taxation system. He has extended it, all right, particularly into consumption taxes. I waited, with no result, for Senator Maguire to express a view-I have been saying this consistently-on the curious set of priorities this Government has when it is prepared to tax kids' orange juice and ice cream and flavoured milk but is not prepared to tax pornographic magazines. Apparently, that situation suits Senator Maguire. If that is this Government's order of priorities, they are wrong; it is indefensible. The whole sales tax regime at the moment represents that kind of ad hoc, unreasonable, unfair and ludicrous set of priorities that this Government apparently holds dear.

Let us see the extent to which Senator Maguire's pathetic defence of the Government falls apart. Let us have a look at the evidence of the huge increase in consumption taxes under Mr Keating. There are quite a few: for example, excise. The Fraser Government raised something like $3.49 billion in sales tax. This year, this Government has budgeted to raise $10.67 billion in sales tax. Sales tax has more than trebled during this Government's term of office whereas the total taxation revenue has increased only-the word `only' is unfortunate-by about 134 per cent.

As a result sales tax, which used to make up only about 8.5 per cent of total Government taxation revenue, now makes up 11.1 per cent. Here we have the steady expansion of the consumption tax that this Treasurer has tried to tell us he is opposed to introducing and that the Government would not have a bar of. He does it by stealth instead. Ask the kids whose orange juice and ice-cream are now being taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It used to all be exempt by this Government.

—It used to be exempt. These taxes on food were only introduced by this Government. They did not exist under the previous government. This Government's incompetence has brought us a massive economic downturn-the recession we had to have; the recession that was engineered-and we have apologists for it trying to rewrite history.
