SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume, in his usual lucid style, said it is wrong for the Victorian Government to decide not to take action against certain unionists, including Mr John Halfpenny and Mr Martin Ferguson. He said it would be wrong for governments to take action on a particular bias. I could not agree more. It would be wrong for a government or government authorities to take action against people based on bias. I agree wholeheartedly that any government decision based on bias would be wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure how Senator Baume relates those propositions to what is happening in Victoria because no decision has been taken by the Victorian Government not to take action. As Senator Baume said, the decision was taken by the Victoria Police Force. You, Madam Acting Deputy President, like myself, are from Victoria. I do not know whether you can think of any instance where it has been alleged that the Chief Commissioner of Police, Mr Kel Glare, is in any way influenced by the Government; I certainly cannot. Indeed, his reputation in Victoria would be to the contrary.

I think specifically of his approach at the appropriate time that a suspect can be held in custody before being charged. It differed, at times at least, from the approach of the Victorian Government. In making that decision, the police-I am sure it would not have been Mr Glare himself who made the decision-were acting no differently from the way they do in any instance where people are investigated for an alleged crime. The procedure is that the police investigate and, if the police think it appropriate, charge the person.

If the charge is for an indictable offence, as it was in this case, the crime of blackmail, the person concerned is put through committal proceedings. At the committal proceedings, if the magistrate decides on the evidence-usually uncontradicted at a committal-that a properly instructed jury could reasonably come to a verdict of guilty, the person is committed. Only at that point is the matter sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

There are instances where the Director of Public Prosecutions can put somebody on trial without the matter going to a committal but that is an unusual procedure. It would be unfair if these two men, Mr Ferguson and Mr Halfpenny, were treated differently from the ordinary citizen. Some propositions have been put that if people have a special status they should be treated in a special adverse way. Mr Temby was of that view some years ago but he has now moved away from that position.

It seems harsh to take the Victorian Government to task for simply carrying out the law. The police obtained an opinion from the Victorian Solicitor-General, Mr Hartog Berkley. He is a public servant and not a political figure in the same way that the Attorney-General is. He is a very eminent member of the Victorian Bar Council where he has a high reputation. I have not heard him criticised in any way for dishonesty, nor has it ever been suggested that he is corrupt. He has given advice to the police in the normal course of his duties. I simply point that out because, unfortunately, it is very often the case these days that people are maligned and blackguarded and their reputation reduced on the basis of a misunderstanding of what has happened.

I do not for one minute suggest that Senator Michael Baume has in any way spoken maliciously tonight. He has taken from the Herald-Sun in Melbourne an account of what has occurred in respect of Mr Ferguson and Mr Halfpenny in relation to the last Australian Open Tennis Tournament. That paper has pursued a course which, on the face of it at least, is quite vindictive. Whereas Senator Baume has every excuse in the world for not going into the details of the way these things end up in court-if they do so end up-and whereas he is reasonable in relying on the Herald-Sun in what it has written, the same cannot be said for the paper. It does have access to legal advice and it has had time to analyse this. For it to write the editorials it has, and to have written up this incident as it has, does not leave it with a great deal of credibility.

The Herald-Sun said that a different decision should have been made. We all say that different decisions should have been made about many things, but in a society like this we have to accept the proper authorities and the decisions they make. So long as the procedures that have been adopted which lead to the decision being made are legitimate and have been properly used, that is the correct decision by definition. The way the decision was reached in respect of both Mr Halfpenny and Mr Ferguson was the correct way. As the law says, they have been left without any stain on their characters. The golden thread running through the common law-which we all accept-is that everybody is innocent until proved guilty. In this case, the evidence against them was not even sufficient to go to a committal, much less to put them on trial.

I want to say something about the union movement generally, given the attacks that have been made on it. The movement has been blamed for the state of the economy-or a major part of the economy's problems have been attributed to it. In 1983, Australian non-primary industry was inward-looking and concerned overwhelmingly with the local market. It was ill-equipped to export overseas and unable to provide employment for the increasing numbers seeking work. Something had to be done so that in the long term this country could offer its citizens a secure, civilised and fair life.

Tremendous advances have been made in the last eight years. I say that, being fully conscious of the unhappy state of the economy in Australia at the moment. There has been a change in understanding, attitudes and goals, and a change in how one section of the community perceives the other. In the long term, the work done by the labour movement during the 1980s will be seen as one of the great shifts for the good in Australian industry. The relationship between government, management and the work force is much healthier now than it was a decade ago. That relationship must grow better, or at least remain as sound as it is now, if this country is to advance to that state we all want.

The risk that the coalition poses for Australia is the damage it will probably inflict on the relationship that presently exists between the work force, management and government. Capital and labour need to work together in a way that brings both equity and productivity. If only one of these is attended to, the other is likely to suffer. Where productivity becomes the sole target, equity is readily prejudiced.

Workers, with their unions, have made great sacrifices for their country in the last eight years. There has been a 10 per cent lowering in the real unit cost of labour since the accord began operating in 1983. Over the same period, the share of the national income going to profit has increased dramatically. In the last three full years of the Fraser Government, the number of working days lost per thousand employees through industrial disputes was 649 in 1980, 797 in 1981 and 348 in 1982. In the last three full years under this Government, the number of working days lost per thousand employees through industrial disputes has been 269 in 1988, 190 in 1989 and 216 in 1990.

If there is confidence between management, capital and workers and the labour they provide, then great things can be done. Clearly, workers are willing to make sacrifices and, in many cases, so is management, but mutual trust is essential, and sometimes that does not occur.

The now famous case of the Shepparton Preserving Co. Ltd is an example where the actions of management leave something to be desired. Because of the state of the industry in Shepparton at the time that the agreement was made between the workers and the company, things were bad. As a result of the agreement reached between the union, management and work force, seasonal workers lost $25.40 a week, three rostered days off and payment for unused sick-leave, which was usually two to three days; permanent workers gave away $60 to $80 a week, depending on the shift they were working, and three rostered days off; and the staff gave away 17.5 per cent loading on their annual leave, and that was all.

In January this year, management decided to give staff, as distinct from workers, a 5 per cent increase in pay. It might well have been that the 5 per cent increase was justified or it might have been otherwise but management sought to give it in a way that would avoid unfavourable media attention. It tried to do it in a surreptitious-I think that is the appropriate word-way, so that the contrast between the increase in salary for staff and the sacrifice made by the work force would not be apparent.

If productivity is to increase, if industry is to flourish, it needs to be done on a cooperative basis. If one part of the equation that is needed to produce a happy industrial outcome is going to prevaricate and act in a surreptitious fashion, then the unified action that we are looking for will not occur. The way that the management of SPC went about giving the 5 per cent increase to staff was unfortunate. Another illustration of where management or its representatives could have acted in a better way is in the pastoral industry, with the Victorian Farmers Federation and the National Farmers Federation. In Victoria there has been a dispute about the conditions under which shearers work. That has gone before Commissioner Merriman in the Industrial Relations Commission, and some changes have been made by him in respect of which an appeal has been lodged by the Australian Workers Union. At the same time there has been a temptation on the part of the employers to pay below award wages and, unfortunately, in some cases they have given way to that temptation.

It has often been said to unions that, when they are making decisions that affect their members, they ought to take a ballot-that, for example, there ought to be a ballot as to whether or not to go on strike. Taking this into account, on 3 March this year the union invited the Victorian Farmers Federation and the National Farmers Federation to hold a ballot of their members in the pastoral industry to determine their official position on Commissioner Merriman's decision of 5 February 1991 and their position on the question of the further widening of the shearing combs that shearers use.

This was a serious proposition from the union, because it believed that the smaller farmers, the ones which had less power within the two federations, disagreed with what the executives of those federations were doing. The following was proposed in a motion that was carried unanimously by the members of the union voting on the measure:

We believe that the current practices of the VFF and NFF in determining their positions on major industrial issues is undemocratic and out of step with the majority of farmers and the rural community in general. We believe the NFF and VFF in determining their policies and positions are dictatorial in nature and only act to serve the interests of large Pastoralists in their desire to make financial gain at the expense of rural workers, small farmers and the entire rural community.

Unfortunately, neither the Victorian Farmers Federation nor the National Farmers Federation have conducted a ballot amongst their members. I raise these matters simply to illustrate that in the industrial arena it is time for management, workers and anyone else concerned with that arena to be frank, to be democratic and to act in a way that the other side can respect.

In this regard, I want to say something about the common law. It is put by organisations such as the National Farmers Federation and the Victorian Farmers Federation, by many employers and employer bodies, by commentators and by people in the media, that the law should prevail. I agree with that, and that is what I said at the beginning of my speech. Having said that, I think it is proper to recognise some problems with the common law in its ability to deliver equity. There are two ancient concepts running through the English legal system which have much influenced the development of industrial law. The first is that contracts are sacred and the second is that restraint of trade is against the public interest. The influence of those two concepts has often been an unhappy one. The common law gives priority to contractual rights and to the interests of commerce over the needs of working people for fair wages and conditions.

Judges of today are captives of the law as declared by their predecessors. What prompted the courts of yesteryear were the concepts that contracts were inviolate and trade should not be restrained. They were certainly not driven by the concepts that people should receive fair wages and should work in safety and in decent conditions, or that they should work reasonable hours. So when we talk about the need to obey the law-and, as I say, I absolutely agree that we do-it is proper to remember that, given the history of the law and the fact that the law of contracts and the law in respect of restraint of trade evolved long before the industrial law, this developed in a way which often has adverse consequences for workers.

Because of that it is incumbent upon the legislature to bring about laws that suit the workplace. Indeed, much of the debate in this chamber is directed towards that objective. Another comment I make in this respect is that those ancient concepts of inviolability of contract and of the need for free trade are the same concepts that lie behind sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support those?

—I support them while they remain on the statute book, but I do not support them as concepts because I think they are the wrong sorts and, in my view, we as a legislature should change them and introduce laws that are more conducive to meeting the needs of the workplace. We see there a law that encompasses concepts that not even the New Zealand law--
—There is a New Zealand law that is totally compatible with section 45d.
—Let me put it this way: the New Zealand law would not disallow all the things that are disallowed under sections 45d and 45e.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, those concepts are commented upon by the New Zealand bishops. They issued a statement on the employment contracts legislation in New Zealand. The New Zealand law is not as draconian as sections 45d and 45e. I quote the statement of the bishops of New Zealand on this:
The prescription for freedom in the legislation includes the freedom of the strong to exploit the weak, resulting in less freedom for the weak. Thus the legislation will not lead to common good.

Secondly, the church teaches that human beings are by nature social beings and therefore the rights of individuals cannot be separated from the duty of individuals and the rights of the group. There is a relational aspect to all human activity: freedom is not the right to do anything one pleases but the right to act freely in doing what is just, not only for oneself but also in relation to others. The pre-eminence given in the legislation to the rights of the individual and the ignoring of the corresponding duties of the individual in effect negate the rights of the group. Thus again the legislation will not lead to the common good.

I simply say that, in the year 1991, which is the centenary of Rerum Novarum, we should not treat workers as if they were commodities. High Court judges have spoken about that. When I am challenged on 45d and 45e, I say that those sections, certainly in my view, do not conform with the sorts of concepts set out in the bishops' statements or in the encyclical by Pope Leo XIII one hundred years ago or, indeed, in the encyclical, Centesimus Annus, now published by the present Pope.

When Senator Alston challenges me in his questions, I say, `Yes, I stand solidly with that hundred years of church teaching and with many other people and great thinkers who say that the oppression of workers in the interests of productivity, in the interests of the economy, is not to be tolerated.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just take up one matter that was raised by Senator Cooney-that is, SPC Ltd. He suggested that it was a stunning example of cooperation between management and union employees. With respect, that is not the truth. The resolution was in spite of current practice, and it was in the teeth of bitter opposition from the Victorian Trades Hall Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Shepparton is a town of some 26,000 people and, as a result of circumstances very much visited upon its business-SPC Ltd-by this Government, those people found themselves facing a very doubtful future. They found that interest rates were going up, their borrowings were going up, their profits were going down and their likelihood of surviving was severely tested. The employees of SPC Ltd entered into an agreement, an 11-point plan, approved by 93 per cent of them in a secret ballot without interference from, approval by or even discussion with the Victorian Trades Hall Council. They were prepared to make certain sacrifices on the basis of keeping their jobs and participating in future profits, but Mr Halfpenny, with his myopic, blinkered, obsessive attitude, said that he would rather see them lose their jobs than compromise previously won conditions. In other words, there would be no room to negotiate backwards for the sake of survival.

It did not matter to Mr Halfpenny that, in the event of those 300 people losing their jobs, they would lose their homes, they would have no future and there would be no prospects for them in Shepparton. Some rigid, ideological parameter was more important than the practical realities of daily living, so Mr Halfpenny and his cohorts interfered.

It was only as a result of public outrage and the courage and determination of the Shepparton workers that the Shepparton Preserving Co. and the employees were able to consummate an arrangement, a contractual deal entered into without coercion, but with full agreement between management and employees. With respect, that was with no thanks to the strongarm tactics of the union movement; it was done in spite of those tactics.

I find myself speaking today on the fifth anniversary of Mr Keating's famous banana republic speech, which occurred on 14 May 1986, if my memory and arithmetic are correct. At that time, Mr Keating said that under certain circumstances this country and our economy would slide into a banana republic. We might well ask ourselves where we are now. The essential question that one is always tempted to ask is: are we better off now than we were when this Government was elected; are we better off now than we were in 1986 when that dire prediction was made by the Treasurer about what would happen to our economy if certain changes did not take place? Let us look at a modest number of the indicators. For instance, have more buildings now been started? Of course, there are fewer now than in 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have more GDP per head now than then.
—That is not the point, and that is not the criterion. There are a number of criteria, as the Minister knows, with respect.
—There are more people in jobs now than then.
—We will turn to unemployment in a minute. There are 884,000--
—There are more people in jobs now than in 1986.

—That is as relevant as saying that population has actually gone up and not down since 1986, and therefore that that is a plus for the Government. That is one of the few things it has not interfered with. The number of motor vehicle registrations generally is down. If Senator McMullan wants to look at pluses--
—Those are selective statistics.
—What about import volumes, which is one of the criteria, one of the hallmarks. It is up dramatically. What about the level of foreign debt?
—What about export volumes?
—Export volumes have gone up in some respects, but it is important to remember that terms of trade have gone up and saved us from the misery that this Government was seeking to drag us into.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the level of bankruptcies, which is perhaps some kind of indicator of economic activity. For the March quarter of 1989, there were 1,690 business bankruptcies. In March 1991, there were 2,370. As Senator McMullan will know, statistical bankruptcies are not an indication of the number of people who have gone bankrupt or out of business. A lot of people simply pull down the shingle and walk away. There are those who are surviving with a shingle and nothing else, with simply a shell of a business. They are the sort of indicators that are relevant to making judgments about the performance of this Government. A recent survey was done by the Confederation of Australian Industry on investor confidence. Ninety per cent of the respondents viewed current business conditions as poor, very poor or deeply depressed. Only 10 per cent of the respondents found the circumstances to be other than poor, very poor or deeply depressed.

I turn to the subject of unemployment, which is a human statistic. We see that nationally that figure is running at about 9.9 per cent and in Western Australia at 11 per cent. Those figures do not take into consideration the hidden unemployed or the hidden underemployed, but they account statistically for 884,000 people and 663,000 who are now receiving unemployment benefits-double that of last year.

Perhaps the most stark tragedy of all is youth unemployed. In terms of tomorrow's hope, tomorrow's Australia, the intellectual assets for the future of this country, we find that 27 per cent of people between the ages of 15 and 19 are presently unable to find a job. That is for those who still have the courage and fortitude to keep looking. Of course, what these statistics do not tell us are the number of people who simply opt out and drop out from the pursuit of looking for full time or part time jobs. The tragedy is that in a number of suburbs in Western Australia one in three young people is unemployed. These are the beautiful numbers that Mr Keating talks about. A recent survey showed that 60 per cent more firms plan to cut staff than over the same period last year.

We all know the social cost of those statistics-the misery, the loss of self-esteem, the despair, the sense of failure. Perhaps what is unique about this recession-cum-depression is that in many respects it is significantly a white collar recession. That does not make it better or worse, but very many people in middle and senior white collar management positions have been made redundant and have no prospect of returning to the work force in comparable positions to those from which they have been retrenched. One of their assets, their unique skills to their employer, is their experience and knowledge about that business. Of course, that is now lost. In fact, taxi companies are reporting an increasing number of people in that category applying for jobs with them. That is not to mention the rural crisis and the tragedy inflicted there. No doubt we shall be told in due course that that is the result of the collapse of commodity prices over which this Government has no control. That does not take into account what this Government can be doing in those circumstances.

Let me say a couple of things about the accord-this discredited deal between the Government and its masters, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We are told what it has done for Australia. Let us remember that nominal wages have increased by between 6 and 7 per cent since 1983, yet workers during that period have been subject either to flat or to declining levels of real wages. This has given us inflation double that of our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) trading partners. That is guaranteed to be where it is because the accord puts a floor under inflation.

Nominal unit labour costs have increased by 45 per cent between 1984 and 1990 compared with 20 per cent for the OECD countries. In recent times, there has been a modest fall in inflation, but we know that it is not due to increased productivity or a nominal reduction in unit labour costs. It is simply a question of biting into profits. In fact, gross domestic product per hour is below the 1984-85 levels. As I have said, inflation has come down through falling profits and rising unemployed. Thanks to this Government, we now have a standard of living which has declined by 9 per cent.

I wish to touch on one matter that I briefly mentioned last night. This Government has let down itself and Australia in terms of micro-economic reform. It was during the last term of this Government that Mr Keating confessed that the opportunity for micro-economic reform had been lost and that this was to be the new horizon. What we have seen so far has been abysmal. In transport, we have seen no reform whatever. On the waterfront, we have seen Senator Collins valiantly struggling but compromised by the union movement that begrudges every single step backwards that it has taken. It has not been prepared to accept the need for greater productivity other than the price of having extra money put in its own pocket. We see the enormous cost to the Australian taxpayers amounting to an average of $100,000 in redundancy payments to those who are leaving the industry. As I said last night, we are in the same situation as we were.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that their low income friends don't have the same choice.

—Yes, that is right. We have paid some $30m in taxpayers' money to 300 gangway watchmen, a position that has been redundant for years. They discovered that they could do without those workers, but they still had to be paid and have now been paid off at a cost of $30m. I think Senator Button told us last year that one wharfie had been paid for 20 years and had not been to work for one day. Senator Collins tells us that we can look forward optimistically to significant reforms. The truth is that, even when these reforms take place, they will still leave us way behind the rest of the world. I will say no more other than to observe that when this Government comes up for election it will be ignominiously dumped from office because of its record, if nothing else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I wish to speak to this evening. One is to pick up some comments by Senator Crichton-Browne, but I particularly want to refer to an interesting article in the Adelaide Advertiser that appeared on Monday of this week that gives some facts about the reason for bankruptcies and financial breakdowns. In no way do I want to be understood as saying that I am not concerned about the number of people who declare themselves bankrupt; nor do I want to be understood as being unconcerned about the number of people who are suffering hardship. But I am concerned about the misinformation that is being led particularly by the Opposition about these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The gravity of the situation demands that we put facts on the record, particularly facts about bankruptcies. There have been some debates led in this place by the Opposition. I remember Senator Boswell bringing on a debate-either a matter of public importance or an urgency motion-in this place about the appalling number of bankruptcies, but not once in the course of his contribution to that debate did Senator Boswell give a breakdown of bankruptcies. I think it is important for us to consider that, because the serious regard that we should give to this issue is qualified and assisted if we have the facts.

I have read another article-I cannot find it this evening, so I can do no more than refer to it-which contains a claim that a lot of those in financial difficulties, particularly bankruptcies, were no more than yuppies-I think they call them that-who had dashed into business with no serious consideration of what they were in for, and the easy way out was to declare themselves bankrupt. It allowed them to abdicate their responsibilities towards providing payment for debt and so on.

In particular, I want to refer to the evidence contained in an article from the Advertiser of Monday, 13 May 1991. It refers to a very large number of bankruptcies being due to young people who buy `bombs' and do not take out insurance. The article states:
Drivers without third party property insurance make up the biggest group of people going bankrupt, the South Australian Financial Counsellors' Association says.

That would certainly put a qualification on how we address the question of bankruptcies. As I said earlier, I do not want to be understood to be saying that we can therefore dismiss the question of people facing the hardship of bankruptcy but I do think we need to get down and examine the position of those people who are in serious financial difficulty and not those people who are behaving somewhat irresponsibly. The article continues:
Association president Mr Vin Glenn said young people who choose not to insure their ``bombs'' make up a significant proportion of bankruptcy cases.
``They always seem to run into Porsches or other expensive cars and end up with very expensive damage bills,'' he said.
Mr Glenn said the other two major groups of bankrupts were small business people and redundant workers.

I would have thought it would be important for us to tease out those small business people who have seriously tried to run a business and have had difficulty, and take out from the overall figures of bankruptcy those people whom I do not think deserve the same kind of compassion or consideration. For example, I do not believe we should be expressing the same kind of concern for people who are fiscally irresponsible. That is not to say that most people are, but certainly some are.

The figures taken from the Attorney-General's 1989-90 annual report on the operation of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 give the main reasons for business and non-business bankruptcies. Listed under non-business bankruptcies are:
1. Excessive use of credit.
2. Liabilities on guarantees.
3. Unemployment.
4. Gambling.
5. Ill-health.
6. Adverse litigation.
7. Domestic discord.

I am certainly aware of the difficulty caused to families by No. 7, domestic discord when, particularly at the time of a marriage break-up, the person in business-very often the male-declares himself to be bankrupt so as to avoid some of his financial liabilities as a consequence of that marriage break-up. Under the heading `Business Bankruptcies' were listed:
1. Lack of capital.
2. Lack of business ability.
3. Failure to keep proper books.
4. Economic conditions.
5. Seasonal conditions (floods and droughts).
6. Excessive interest rates.
7. Inability to collect debts.
8. Excessive drawings-
meaning borrowings-
9. Gambling or speculation.
10. Personal reasons (ill-health, domestic discord).

It seems to me that this report provides information in the debate about bankruptcies. I think the Senate would do itself proud to actually address the facts and breakdown of figures on bankruptcy numbers rather than just use the total number to suggest that everybody who is declared a bankrupt is a victim of the current economic circumstances.

I have said it once, I have said it twice and I will say it again in case Senator Alston misunderstands me: I have nothing but compassion and concern for people who, for reasons of economic circumstances, lose their business or have to face the difficulty of declaring themselves bankrupt. But I think it is very important that we take out of those aggregate figures those people who are bankrupt for other than those serious reasons.

I put that on the record and refer people to this article by Tim Satchell which appeared in the Advertiser of 13 May this year. It is an analysis of bankruptcies under the operation of the Bankruptcy Act and I think it contains very good information for people who want to address this difficulty seriously.

The other matter I wanted to raise in the debate on the Appropriation Bills tonight concerns the question of Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA) principally because Senator Kemp has come into this place and it is really quite interesting to listen to Senator Kemp and his comments in some of these debates. He definitely evokes memories of times past. He actually wishes to abuse the union movement, and unionists in general, in a way that is certainly devoid of any current fact. As I said, he indulges in union bashing of a style which is, I think, at least a decade out of date.

I find it rather disappointing that Senator Kemp would choose to limit himself in that way because, mostly, his contributions under the heading `union bashing' betray a considerable degree of ignorance or misinformation of which he seems not to want to disabuse himself. I think it does him no credit to resort to such primitive and, I think, inaccurate attacks.

One of the attacks I heard him make in the adjournment debate in the Senate one night concerned APHEDA. I was interested to note that he raised this issue again during the hearings of Estimates Committee B on 1 May. This appears in the Estimates Hansard on pages B135, B136 and B137. Some of the questions asked by Senator Kemp then suggest that he is still not aware of the facts about APHEDA and the funding which goes to the APHEDA organisation. It is disappointing that he continues to attack the union movement in general and in particular by arguing that APHEDA is a disgraceful misappropriation of funds by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the union movement.

I would like to take this opportunity to put on the record some facts about APHEDA and remind Senator Kemp that it would do him credit if he got his facts about this matter correct. APHEDA is incorporated, so it is known officially as APHEDA Inc., and it is the overseas aid arm of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

While APHEDA is part of the ACTU, it is legally independent, registered under the Charities Act in New South Wales, and is incorporated as an association under the New South Wales Association Act 1984. It is managed by a board which includes not only ACTU executive members but also community representatives. I suspect that it is under the heading `community representative' that I am a member of that board.

As an independent, registered organisation, APHEDA not only raises funds from its support base but also submits proposals for funding to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which are assessed on the guidelines as non-government organisations (NGOs). Project funding that is approved is subject to direct agreement between the Government and APHEDA and is not channelled through the ACTU, as Senator Kemp's speeches on this matter have implied.

Senator Kemp implies that millions of dollars in taxpayers' money is going to the ACTU for that organisation to keep. In effect, most of the allocations are for specific humanitarian development projects through APHEDA, targeting alleviation of poverty and human resource development in needy communities overseas.

All of APHEDA's programs which receive financial assistance from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are subject to normal accounting and auditing procedures. Submissions and reports on projects are examined and assessed independently, not by politicians, but by both the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) and, for specific projects, by a group of peers, which is the Committee for Development Co-operation. In addition, APHEDA has its own in-house auditing of its projects and its allocation of money. It is assisted in this process by AIDAB and local embassy personnel.

I find it disappointing that Senator Kemp has not been interested in finding out the facts about APHEDA but, rather, has come into this place and suggested that AIDAB is actually funding the ACTU. He has, I think, called this a misappropriation of taxpayers' funds, and that is very close to deliberate misrepresentation.

APHEDA receives far less in Government assistance than many other non-government organisations which are operating in Australia, and that seems not to be a matter of concern to Senator Kemp. In the financial year 1989-90, World Vision received $7.198m; Care Australia received $5.4m; the Overseas Service Bureau received $4.4m; and all of those organisations were attracting much more government assistance than APHEDA.

It is also worth remembering that the amount of money available in the aid program has increased considerably since 1983. For example, to suggest that these funds are politically associated or in any way a misallocation of those funds because of the association of the ACTU with the Australian Labor Party takes no account of the fact that Care Australia, chaired by ex-Liberal Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, in 1987-88 received $134,000 from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and by 1989-90 that figure had increased to $5.4m.

This APHEDA organisation has joined the NGO community in Australia to campaign with all the other aid organisations for greater expenditure by the Australian Government on its overseas aid budget. I think that not only those directly involved with aid associations but also thousands of people in the community are prepared to contribute, through whatever fundraisings there are by all of these NGOs, to assist in overseas aid because of the very extraordinary generosity of the Australian people in contributing to relief works and emergency assistance and directly to overseas aid.

The thing that distinguishes APHEDA from a number of the other aid organisations is that it has a particular focus-or, if you like, a constitution-that allows it to aim at improving workers' technical skills. It assists the training of workers in developing countries in technical and vocational skills. The benefit of that is that once the Australian assistance and training has been put in place, the Australian aid and participation can cease. The skilled workers are there and able to carry on by themselves because what has been given to them has been that skill, that training. It is distinguished from other aid organisations which are involved more in the direct supply of the bricks and mortar-the food, the relief clothing and so on. It is a very distinct aid organisation and I should have thought that Australians of whatever sort would be very proud that this has been established.

The APHEDA organisation assists training in 10 countries in the Pacific, South East Asia, the Middle East and Africa. It concentrates its efforts on the poorest countries and, where possible, works with the poorest or most marginalised people-with refugees, young people, women and indigenous or ethnic minorities. The APHEDA organisation is currently funding over 40 projects world wide and some of those are financially or technically supported by individual trade unions. For example, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union has supported job creation and training in the Philippines through the training of blacksmiths; the teachers' union has provided technical training in Tanzania, the Middle East and Cambodia; and the Waterside Workers Federation has provided the training of nurses and midwives in Vietnam. In other words, various unions are prepared almost to adopt a project and they assist directly in keeping an eye on, and providing their fund raising support for, those particular programs.

The APHEDA agency is a humanitarian aid agency. As I said, it is directed to assisting with the technical training of people overseas. Its mandate from the ACTU does not include trade union training, as Senator Kemp has stated. A number of times he has got his facts wrong. For example, he said that APHEDA was also responsible for funding the Commonwealth trade union centre in Brisbane and the South Pacific trade unions, and this is not the case. The ACTU has its own relationship directly with AIDAB for assistance on these matters.

Another matter that Senator Kemp betrays a lack of understanding about is development education. In the recent Estimates Committee hearings, he asked questions about the allocation of money for development education and seemed to be rather taken aback that that money was spent in Australia. He asked, `Why doesn't it go overseas?'. Honourable senators in this place, and certainly Senator Kemp, need to know that development education is about educating Australians on the causes and effects of international poverty and its alleviation.

As a member of the United Nations, we believe that we have an obligation to understand better that world in which we live, particularly the human and environmental conditions that prevail. We also need to appreciate the consequences of international poverty and exploitation. Amongst other issues of concern in this place we are debating economics. It is a matter of considerable gravity that we understand exactly what economic effects happen from prevailing poverty in many countries and in pockets in many countries.

The Opposition in this place sometimes has taken issue with initiatives of this Government, particularly in the area of education. For some strange reason, it seems to be an affront to the Opposition that we should look at things like peace studies. I well remember the outrageous debates led by the Opposition in opposing those initiatives by this Government. We almost had the same kind of fight to get a consideration of Australian history and culture into the curriculum in our schools or tertiary institutions. It seems that the Opposition has the same willingness to not understand what development education is and how appropriately it can be done. It also ought to be understood by Opposition senators, and Senator Kemp in particular, that development education is not something that is done by APHEDA only. Indeed, it is done by most, if not all, of the aid organisations and they all receive assistance to do that.

Development education must be understood to be education of Australians about what underdevelopment means and what development aid can and ought to be about. As I have said before, APHEDA is to be distinguished because of the sort of aid it provides. I hope that Senator Kemp will get his facts about this right and not come into this place with mischievous misinformation. He certainly still seems to suggest that development education money is to be spent overseas, and that is incorrect.

He has also referred to wrong figures about the amount of money-or the assistance-for development education provided to APHEDA, claiming in some cases that over $120,000 has gone to APHEDA for this role. In fact, that is not the case. For the financial year 1990-91, APHEDA is receiving $34,000 in assistance for its development education program. Over 20 other non-government organisations also receive allocations under this scheme.

I think the issue is very important. It is important to know the facts about APHEDA and what it is doing in overseas assistance. It is also important to know how invaluable non-government organisations' overseas aid has been in allowing the Australian Government to be able to contribute in all sorts of ways in other countries, besides through government to government aid. Some flexibility is provided under non-government organisation aid assistance that is not possible through government to government aid, and I would have thought that that comment would be endorsed by every non-government organisation providing overseas aid from this country.

I also find it curious that the Opposition would want to use APHEDA, and misinformation about APHEDA, as a kind of backdoor way to smash unions. Indeed, if the Opposition were to inform itself properly, it might want to say something about the generosity of unionists in this country, who are not to be distinguished from most other citizens. I would like to know, for example, whether Senator Alston could distinguish a unionist from any other citizen if they were both members of a Rotary club, busy raising money and working in the community. What is the characteristic of a unionist that gets the Opposition so hot under the collar-those unionists who, out of their own funds and out of their own fundraising, have contributed a considerable amount of money through APHEDA to overseas aid, and who have also contributed time?

We are delighted that Senator Kemp has finally come into the chamber. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks this evening to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and to refer to some of the educational problems besetting Australia, and particularly rural Australia, at the present time. However, before doing so, let me say that I listened with interest to Senator Crowley trying to explain the high rate of bankruptcies in Australia and how a financial counsellor said that most bankruptcies resulted from young people driving bombs and the drivers of those bombs having accidents by driving into Porsches that other people were driving. It seems to be an extraordinary explanation and I find it very hard to accept. Certainly, Senator Crowley does not seem to realise or accept that the failed policies of this Labor Government are responsible for the high rate of bankruptcies. They contribute in no small way to Australia's present high unemployment rate of 9.9 per cent, which, sadly, is growing all the time.

SPEECH.PARA: However, one of the very great problems in this country, one which is perhaps not recognised generally and certainly not by many politicians, is that we have a growing dichotomy between city and country people. We as a nation are growing apart. This is indeed the biggest problem facing this country because we will not survive as a divided nation. The problem across the political field in Australia is that there is very scant regard for rural Australia, and that is because it is a minority. If this problem is not tackled it will destroy this country. There are a number of historical reasons for that dichotomy, although it is true to say that Australia has always been the most urban country in the world, even 100 years ago. But in those days there was a fellow feeling between city and country-a feeling that each depended on the other. That has gone and has largely been replaced by massive ignorance.

I do not believe that in the cities of Australia we find any animosity towards the rural sector or the country in general; it is simply ignorance. The city people do not understand what is happening and do not realise that most of the jobs provided in the cities are actually the product of the wealth that comes from the hinterland of Australia. Today an even greater number of Australians live in urban areas, yet the great bulk of the wealth of this country is generated outside the capital cities. The jobs and the standard of living enjoyed by people are related directly or indirectly to the wealth generated in the hinterland of Australia. At the present time, as I mentioned before, it is rather sad to know that the unemployment figures are so high. Many people are not able to enjoy the standard of living that we would like them to have.

We talk a lot about being the clever country. I guess it is a noble objective and one we would all like to see achieved, but it is clear to me that there is an inequity in the availability of education. If one lives in Sydney or any of the towns scattered around the eastern seaboard of Australia, if one is the richest person in the world one's child can walk down the street to high school for virtually no charge. In other words, it is almost free education. But if one happens to live in remote Australia-western Queensland, western New South Wales or the remote parts of Western Australia-one cannot do that. In many cases a very high cost is involved in sending children to school. In the name of equity it does not matter how rich we are: we should have the ability to send our children to school at a reasonable comparative cost. But that ability is just not there.

Australia's farming community has the lowest level of formal educational achievement amongst Western industrialised countries. This is obviously a cause for great concern. Statistics compiled by the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture show that less than a quarter of the Australian farm work force possesses more than a lower secondary education. This contrasts with more than 50 per cent in New Zealand, North America and western Europe and upwards of 90 per cent in Scandinavian countries.

This worries me enormously. Australian rural communities, and farmers in particular, have had an excellent record for productivity improvement in Australia in the past. They have far outstripped all other sectors of the economy, but one of the things that will increasingly hold them back in the future is a lack of preparation at an educational level to enable them to meet the challenges and grasp the opportunities of the future.

Studies in Australia and the United States of America have shown that higher levels of education and training significantly improve farm productivity. That is important, not only for the farmers involved in these tight times but also for Australia, which is desperately in need of export improvement and enhancement. There is also a problem with our need to keep young people on the land. That problem is directly related to being able to better equip them to cope with the challenges that confront them. This problem also arises from the few educational opportunities available. Only last Saturday honourable senators would have read in the Australian newspaper an article reporting the comments of Mr Dave Thomas, a farmer from western Victoria. The article stated:

``What galls me most is the thought that our best product, our children-we're exporting them. We need their ability, their youth and strength and talents and skills to build a viable agriculture in the future, and they are leaving.
``In some districts you can count the number of young people under 25 on one hand,'' he says.
``Where will Australia find its farming expertise in the future?''

With economic conditions such as we are now facing in many cases, it is the education of rural children which is suffering. Many on the Government side are ideologically opposed to private boarding schools, but for students in isolated areas it is their only access to high school education. This fact is recognised by this Labor Government through the payment of an isolated children's allowance. For each child who is forced to leave home and study because of isolation, a non-means-tested, non-asset-tested allowance of $1,500 is paid. Any additional payment is income and asset tested. The maximum allowance per year for primary school students is $2,912; for high school students under 16 years of age, $3,235; and for those over 16, slightly more.

However, the cost of tuition and board at an average boarding school is in the vicinity of $11,500 per year. One does not have to be a mathematical genius to calculate that parents have to pay a shortfall of approximately $8,000 per student per year. Even in the case of city parents who send their child to a school like that, a good quality school, it still means that a lot of money has to be paid out for that child's education. These costs are horrendous, especially when parents have two, three, or four children away at school.

Last week I had the opportunity to talk to some members of the Isolated Childrens Parents Association (ICPA) about the crisis being faced by farming families who are trying to educate their children. I congratulate the ICPA on the work it is doing to improve access to education for students in isolated areas of Australia. When the assistance for isolated children (AIC) scheme was introduced in 1973 by Mr Kim Beazley, Sr, the then Labor Minister for Education, the basic payment represented 55 per cent of average Australian boarding costs. In 1991, it represents only 32 per cent. If we were to increase the allowance to that original benchmark of 55 per cent, it would amount to $2,650 per annum.

This allowance is not just for a tiny group of students. The ICPA is pleading for the continued education of 9,000 geographically isolated children throughout Australia. Surely it is not asking too much of the Government to give some extra help. Australia's 9,000-plus geographically isolated students are the only ones in the country who do not have the option of a free or low cost bus to a free government school if they suffer a financial disaster. School is too far away and isolated parents have always had to pay in thousands, not hundreds, of dollars in order to get to the school gate.

When uninsurable flood, fire, drought or price collapses strike, such as in the last 12 months, remote families must still find the cash or credit to get their children to school; otherwise they have to drive excessive distances to school or teach their children by correspondence.

Government assistance for isolated children eases the financial burden in normal times, but it is proving very inadequate in the rural depression sweeping Australia. I have a few examples from the ICPA of what this depression is doing to rural families. The first family that is mentioned lives on a specialist sheep and wool property in the western division of New South Wales. Like many areas of remote Australia, it has land tenure laws restricting the sale of land. The property also supports two grandparents who are assets tested out of the age pension. Three children were attending school 120 kilometres away via the local school hostel. The annual fees are $4,560 by three, which equals $13,680. Federal assistance for isolated children of $1500 by three equals $4,500, which reduces the cash cost to $9,000. This amount plus family living expenses has to be borrowed from the agents at 18 per cent interest.

At the end of term one in 1991, one student has been withdrawn from the local school and hostel. The mother is attempting to teach correspondence and run the farm, whilst the father is travelling 1,200 kilometres to cotton country to try to earn sufficient money to pay the two remaining hostel fees and to support the household. The mother has indicated to the hostel that the other two hostel boarders will probably be withdrawn before the end of 1991 as the father is unlikely to find continuous outside work for the whole of the rest of the year.

In the second example, the family live on a specialist sheep and wool property in the western division of New South Wales, 160 kilometres from their nearest school. They have had four students attending school via the local hostel. One student now remains at the hostel; one is being taught by correspondence at home; and two boys left school in years 9 and 10 to go shearing to generate some outside income for family support. That is rather a hard job for children who have been in grades 9 and 10 at school. The family have negligible net income and are precluded from additional AIC allowance by the assets test.

The third example is of a family whose eldest child boards with the grandmother in order to attend high school. This family also lives on a specialist sheep and wool property in the New South Wales western division. Two children are at home being taught by their mother through correspondence. In 1990, before the wool and sheep price crash, the property was above the assets test limit. At the end of 1990, the property was auctioned and failed to attract one bid. Then and now the family are precluded from additional AIC allowance because of the assets test.

After having cut their spending to the bone, parents are currently having to withdraw their children from boarding school. For those in extreme financial difficulties, this means bringing their children home and assisting them with their schooling by means of correspondence. However, in the main, this situation is far from satisfactory because, apart from the social aspects, the children must rely heavily on their parents' time and educational skills.

This is placing great stress on many families. Not being able to afford any labour means that the wife must spend a greater time helping her husband outside, whilst at the same time her children need her assistance with their correspondence lessons. This could also be said of the husbands where the role is reversed.

Other parents are driving their children excessive distances morning and afternoon, either to and from school or to catch a school bus. Apart from the physical toll on the child, any person who has driven in the outback would be extremely concerned if someone had to be on the road every day because of the appalling conditions under which they would often have to drive.

To avoid this situation, some mothers are leaving their husbands and renting a house in the nearest major centre which has a high school so that they can care for their children during the week. They return home only at weekends and this often involves a 250- to 350-kilometre drive one way on dirt roads with the added danger of hitting a kangaroo, an emu, or a goat, for example. That is certainly not conducive to keeping families together.

Other families will have to place their children in a student hostel in their nearest major centre with a high school. However, these hostels have only limited vacancies and cost approximately $4,500 per student per year, so some parents will find themselves in a very difficult situation.

It is not uncommon when travelling in remote Australia to be told by parents and relatives of schoolchildren that because they can no longer afford to pay hostel boarding costs they have to withdraw their children from high school in the nearest provincial centre. Many of these parents are not farmers but townsfolk on wages, and they cannot afford to pay the difference between the isolated children's allowance and the fee charged by the hostels. This is not the fault of the hostels, because they also are victims of the Government's high income cost policy. It is a particularly sad reflection on Australia when the education of rural students is at risk.

Testimony to the imbalance which now exists between rural and urban students is the fact that at the post-graduate level there is a higher proportion of students from urban areas than from rural and remote regions. The enrolment figures show that 16 per cent of enrolments came from urban Australia, while 12 per cent came from rural Australia. This only serves to highlight the need to provide incentive and genuine assistance for students living away from accessible education resources.

The figures show that 75 per cent of Australia's higher education students come from urban backgrounds; 19 per cent from rural areas; and only 3 per cent from the largest geographic areas-the remote areas of Australia. This situation reflects the incapacity of remote families to cope with the financial burdens associated with higher education, and I regret to say it is set to worsen.

We must remember that an essential feature of a fair society is equality of educational opportunities. It is therefore the role of government to ensure that financial barriers are removed in education so that all Australians have the opportunity to participate in the wide and improved range of employment, education and training opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this speech on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) I intend to concentrate on the Department of the Senate. At the end of last year, I gave notice of a motion concerning articles written by the Clerk and one of the Clerks-Aassistant. I seek leave to have that motion incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
That the Senate-
(1) notes recent published statements by the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk-Assistant (Committees), in particular-
* an article in The House Magazine of 12 December 1990 containing criticism of certain Senators,
* an AAP report of 4 November 1990 quoting criticism of certain senators, and
* an article in The Parliamentarian of July 1990 in praise of a former senator;
(2) believes that those statements are of a partisan nature and therefore compromise the independence of those offices;
(3) expresses its displeasure at those statements;
(4) recognises the immense power and influence available to and used by those officers by virtue of their positions;
(5) therefore requests that those officers avoid also involving themselves publicly in the political process in their official positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was never my intention that that notice of motion be just one of those given as virtually a brief speech, with no follow-up. I had thought it might have been brought on for debate. However, there was no sign of that happening, so yesterday I withdrew it in favour of the alternative of speaking in this debate on the Appropriation Bills. My withdrawing it has ensured that there can be no argument about my right to speak about the issues which would have been raised in that motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the opportunity to explain my case on this matter. All I ask is for those opposite to listen carefully to what I say, not what they think I might have said. Some of those who criticised me for the notice of motion have completely misunderstood my position. So, first, I should answer the question: why did I do this when-it is claimed-nobody had complained before? My action has been described as unprecedented.

There have been plenty of complaints before-for years that I know of-but nobody has openly complained before, because they have judged that it was not worth the trouble. I have judged that, even though it would bring trouble, it was something that had to be done. Many have complained for years, but I decided it was about time the complaints were brought to the surface. Continuing to keep silent, gritting one's teeth and bearing it, implied only approval or at least acquiescence.

I acknowledge that what I have raised is a very serious matter. I am not one for going overboard about something, even when I am very angry or resentful; I tend to seethe about things quietly. I am certainly not a person who enjoys or seeks out conflict. But it is too serious a matter for me to continue biting my tongue. Many of us feel we have put up with the situation for long enough. My tolerance certainly finally ran out, and I gave that notice of motion. Let me put a few things straight on the record, as apparently they need to be said, judging by some of the points made in defence of the Clerks following my notice.

I have said nothing about whether the Clerks are good fellows, cheerful, hard workers, helpful, wonderful and wise. These sorts of things are not at issue. I have nothing personally against the Clerks. I have been full of praise for much of their work, such as the redrafting and modernising of the Standing Orders in the last couple of years. The Clerk is able to produce-in no time flat-learned commentaries on all sorts of issues which arise. I do not decry his knowledge and understanding; his capacity for producing documentation is well known; he is assiduous at that task and has a prodigious output.

Further, I emphasise that I do not complain about the Clerks providing procedural advice to all sides in the Senate. There have been occasions when I have sought advice myself. That is an important part of their job, and they must be allowed to do it. Nowhere have I said that they should not do that, or that they do not do it well. I repeat that I am not complaining about the provision of advice. I do not suggest that advice which happens to be contrary to one party's objectives is partisan.

May I also put on the record why I did not discuss my complaints with the Clerk before giving my notice of motion. I did not do so because I believed it was quite inappropriate for me to enter into political debate with the Clerk or other officers of the Senate. It is precisely this issue of independence which was at the very root of my motion. I still believe that to be a correct stance.

I know the Clerk disagrees with my characterisation of such discussion as political. My definition of what is political is obviously much broader than his. It is not a question of party political at all, but political in the wide sense. I think it would be an impossible situation to argue these issues with those who I believe should be avoiding them.

Of course, there was a problem in having a notice of motion sitting undebated on the Notice Paper for a long period. But that is precisely what happens to most such notices, including some quite abusive of other people unable to defend themselves. It does not come well from those who use, and support the use of, this procedure day in day out to now decry it. Clearly, the Clerks are not short of supporters on the other side to speak for them and defend them. That raises a significant point: does it not make the Clerk, and the Opposition for that matter, stop and think, when all the support and defence comes from one side of the chamber?

I shall briefly state my general concern before dealing with the specific issues which I had set out in the motion. My concern is with the clerkist hierarchy of this place running its own political agenda. Again, I emphasise I use political in the broad sense. I emphasise I am not talking about their legitimate role of providing procedural advice when requested. I am talking about assuming a licence to go much further and to step over the mark between correct behaviour on the one hand and too great an involvement in the political process on the other.

There is a partisanship, not on a party political basis per se, though because of the nature of things it effectively becomes so. Partisan, by the way, is given the following alternatives in the thesaurus: biased, myopic, narrow, partial, prejudiced. Most of those alternatives could be satisfactorily substituted for partisan if that word is thought to be too strong.

There is a partisanship against anyone who does not automatically accept the suggestion that the Senate is an institution always to be revered in a way defined by the Clerks of whom I speak. The present Clerk is not the only one worthy of this complaint. The Clerk, in his letter which Senator Hill incorporated in Hansard on 19 February, quotes `far more robust' comments from his predecessors, which did not lead to adverse comment. That may well be true, but I would suggest that past tolerance does not prove that there is a licence. It merely provides an interesting comparison.

Of the present clerkist hierarchy, I only included in the notice of motion the two which I had specified, but there is a more general Senate culture which they encourage and those who do not subscribe to it do not get on in this little Senate world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the time of the Senate tonight to speak in memoriam of a very special friend and a very special man. I suppose that it is not usual to do this in this place. From time to time we do acknowledge people who have contributed to public office in a special way, but I think it is probably not usual for individual senators to do this on behalf of what we might call their average citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak tonight about a doctor, friend and colleague in South Australia, Deane Southgate, who died very suddenly two weeks ago. I also wish to acknowledge a respect for the preferment of members of his family for discretion about how he is mentioned after his death. They do not wish to make too much of this man's talents and his contribution not only to South Australia but to Australia. I believe that I do not abuse that preferment of the family if I place on record a few comments about Deane Southgate.

He was an associate professor of community medicine at Flinders Medical Centre in South Australia. He was a practising general practitioner, maintaining a half time involvement in general practice because of his passionate commitment to it and his understanding that he would be better able to speak about it and represent it if he continued in it.

Deane Southgate was also one of the driving forces behind the establishment of community health centres in general in South Australia and, in particular, Clovelly Park Community Health Centre, where I worked for some 10 years before coming into this place. He was very involved with the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners.

He was a bridge builder not only in his medical and political life but in all areas of his life. If people were at odds with each other, he was at pains to try to find a way to bridge the gap between them. Deane Southgate was a founding force in the establishment of the Service to Youth Council Incorporated in South Australia.

In all sorts of ways and in any number of areas in community life in South Australia, this man left his mark. His mark was of compassion and concern and of rigour and integrity. Deane Southgate was never a sloppy thinker. But in the way in which he practised his medicine and his life and his medical and political involvement, he was always concerned to have a regard for the condition of ordinary people and for those people who may find themselves behind the eight ball.

For example, he was very concerned to ensure that people in the community did not just talk about the problems of our youth but tried to set up a structure to address them. Indeed, the Service to Youth Council in South Australia has an excellent reputation partly because of the care, regard and compassion of those people who established that organisation and the way that the original founding intentions have been carried on by all those people continuing its work.

I suppose it is some measure of a person's standing in the community to mention the number of people at the funeral. I did not do a head count, but a very large number of people took time from their busy lives to pay their last respects to this very special man.

Deane Southgate was a most unusual man and I believe that he was a very great man. Indeed, I suppose it is all the more remarkable because not only did he not sing his own praises, but also he was at pains to get other people not to sing his praises. It was interesting for a number of us who knew him well and knew how he preferred not to seek that recognition to learn that, in the last honours, he was awarded the Order of Australia, which he was to receive the Tuesday after his death, which was on a Saturday. That honour will be provided to members of his family in a private ceremony at some time when they are in a better frame of mind to accept it.

I am delighted that Deane Southgate's contribution to the community did receive public recognition through the Australia Day awards and I am delighted that the work he set in train will continue. It was another way in which Deane Southgate can be characterised. It was important to set up the institutions, to set up the structures, and to make sure that the right people were appointed to continue that work. It was not necessary for him to continue or to promote his own glory.

Deane Southgate was a very special man. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to place on record those comments by way of acknowledging his contribution to South Australia and to Australia. In particular, I place on record his contribution to part of my development and to some of the benefits that I have obtained from knowing him.

I have not given anything like a definitive list of his achievements, the medical organisations he was involved in or the many people whose lives he touched. I am simply placing on record the benefits that I received from knowing this person. I say a thank you for having the opportunity to have crossed the path of such a man and to thank his family because they are of the same order and ilk. It has been very special knowing him and continuing to know his family.
