On 20 January 1987, the Australian Government announced that it was seeking a new surface combatant to be built in Australia to an overseas design, at an estimated cost of $3.5 billion. It was to be known as the joint Australian/New Zealand project, and became known as the Anzac frigate contract. It is the largest defence contract ever awarded in Australia. Eighty per cent of the outlay on the program was expected to be spent in Australia and New Zealand, and it was estimated that it would create at least 12,000 jobs.

Australian companies were invited to tender for the role of the prime contractor for this frigate project. Two designs were chosen: the Meko design of West Germany and a version of the M class frigate of Holland. At the outset, 13 organisations indicated an interest in the project. On Christmas Eve 1987 came the announcement of the two preferred organisations or consortia. They were Victorian-based AMECON, offering the Meko design of West Germany, and New South Wales-based Australian Warships Systems (AWS), a consortium comprising Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, AWA, Carringtons and New Zealand McConnell Dowell, which was offering the Dutch design M class frigate to be built principally at Newcastle but with subcontracting elsewhere in Australia.

The AWS consortium was viewed as being Newcastle-based chiefly because of the involvement of Carrington Slipways, which was the only current shipbuilder in the group, and it had already had experience in building Navy contracts through the minehunter project. These two consortia were now invited to tender as prime contractors for the detailed design and production of the Anzac ships. Australian Warships Systems publicly indicated that it would build the ships at Carringtons' facilities on the Hunter River and float the vessels downstream to be fitted out at the Government dockyard.

At the end of 1988, the New Zealand Government was getting cold feet over the whole project. The Australian Government offered to allow New Zealand industry to bid for local content in Australia's general defence procurement program to maintain New Zealand interest in Anzac defence projects, including the frigates. However, Australia was prepared to go it alone in building the frigates if the New Zealand Government would bow to internal pressure and pull out of the project. I want to stress New Zealand's reluctance towards involvement in the project in 1988, in the light of the very generous contracts which have been awarded to New Zealand in the last two weeks.

The final choice for the contract was to be decided between AMECON and AWS, that is, between Victoria and New South Wales. To indicate the importance of the contract for the winning contender, I remind the Senate that the handling of this contract would give the winning bidder a solid base for future industrial development. More than half the value of the construction would be made up of electronic and sophisticated technological equipment. Although AMECON would naturally situate the carriage of its construction at Williamstown and Australian Warships Systems at Carrington Slipways in Newcastle, both tenderers stressed that they would farm out substantial proportions of the project interstate.

Finally, on 14 August 1989, the Government announced that AMECON had been chosen to build the frigates. The new ships were to be built at Williamstown dockyard in Victoria and in Newcastle, at a total project cost of $3 1/2 billion for eight ships. The project would last for more than a decade. It would create over 7,000 jobs directly and 5,000 indirectly. However, at that time it was stressed that the benefits were to be spread around Australia, and that it was to be a truly national project. At that stage, Newcastle was still to have a share in the project, according to the Government. The Government's announcement was absolutely unequivocal. These are former Defence Minister Beazley's actual words:
Newcastle will play a particularly important role in the Anzac frigate project.
Under the AMECON offer Newcastle will build 58 hull sections.
Five of the twelve ships will be assembled and launched in Newcastle.
This and other work on the ships will give Newcastle industry $700 million of direct work, and create 1,200 jobs.

This project will bring to Newcastle a full range of shipbuilding skills, including not only the traditional steel-fabrication work, but also engineering, electrical, electronic, pipework, mechanical assembly, outfitting, commissioning and testing.
This will strengthen Newcastle's capabilities and provide opportunities to play a major role in through-life support for the Anzac ships and other navy vessels.
The Prime Minister was equally explicit on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Newcastle on 18 August 1989. I quote:
The fact is that Newcastle is going to have $700 million invested. There's a minimum of $700 million to be invested in Newcastle with 1200 jobs to be created there.
This is one of the biggest contracts that will have ever come into Newcastle-$700 million worth of investments and 1200 jobs at least.

I give a guarantee that I will ensure that every possible piece of work that can go to Newcastle consistent with meeting the Cross criteria, every piece of work that can go to Newcastle will go there.

The Government stated at the time that AMECON had been chosen to build the Anzac frigates because the consortium offered a comparable product at a lower price than its competitor, Australian Warships Systems (AWS). The AMECON bid was some $350m less than the AWS bid. The Government then finalised a contract with AMECON to build 10 ships with options to vary the number to either eight or 12.

In 1989 New Zealand was still to choose whether it would participate in the project. If New Zealand decided not to participate in the project, work on the Australian ships which would have gone to New Zealand firms then would be done in Australia. The Government promised that Newcastle would be the major beneficiary as AMECON would be building at least another extra 15 ship sections there.

I repeat: the Government stated very clearly that all States would benefit, especially New South Wales and Victoria. New South Wales and Victoria would each receive 40 per cent of the frigate work in Australia; South Australia was to receive 16 per cent; and the balance was to be shared amongst the other States. Carrington Slipways in Newcastle, as part of AWS, missed out on being chosen as the prime contractor, but the Government indicated that Carrington Slipways would gain work from the AMECON group. That is what was promised on 14 August 1989. What has happened since that date?

In December it was fairly certain that contractual work would come to Newcastle, but perhaps not before 1991. The Managing Director of AMECON claimed that it was AMECON's firm intention `to do half of the project's shipbuilding in Newcastle and the other half at its Williamstown shipyard'. He stated that Newcastle companies would have to win work through competitive tendering. He had no doubt that the region would get its promised $700m worth of work, but he refused to give guarantees. Already the Government's promise of work for Newcastle was being watered down.

At the end of 1989, the promises for Newcastle and the frigates amounted to the following: an AMECON promise for five of the 12 frigate hulls to be built in Newcastle; a promise from Prime Minister Hawke for $700m to be invested in Newcastle and the creation of 1,200 jobs; and a promise from Defence Minister Beazley, as he then was, that a Federal Cabinet committee would ensure that Newcastle was awarded a fair share of electronic and engineering work. To date, only one contract has come to Newcastle-a $4m contract to Commonwealth Steel to provide part of the propulsion system for the Anzac frigates. We are still waiting to hear when Newcastle will get the remaining $696m that was promised to it less than two years ago by the Prime Minister and Defence Minister Beazley.

Then came the news of the contracts to New Zealand, a country which has been reluctant all along to join the program and which now benefits greatly from it. Once again, Hunter and Newcastle have been jilted by this Federal Labor Government. Once again, Newcastle has missed the boat at a time when our own manufacturing sector is in a perilous state. Almost every remaining dollar's worth of work on the Anzac frigates would have to go to Newcastle for the promises of the Prime Minister, the Defence Minister and AMECON to be honoured. This will not happen. The Federal Labor Government should hang its head in shame and apologise to the people of Newcastle for its mismanagement, its broken promises and its wilful destruction of a very fine shipbuilding industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but I wish to draw the Senate's attention to a matter that happened over the weekend. On Sunday 12 May Tasmania, and indeed Australia, lost an individual who carved for himself a remarkable niche in the history of our nation. I refer to Tasmania's world-renowned naturalist, artist and retired tin miner, Mr Deny King, of Melaleuca, near Port Davey, who at 81 years of age passed away after suffering a heart attack in Hobart on Sunday night.

SPEECH.PARA: For those who are wondering where Melaleuca is, it is situated in Port Davey in south-west Tasmania, part of the South West National Park. It is about 120 kilometres south of Hobart. One cannot go much further than that. It is unbearably hot in summer, but mostly it is a chillingly cold and wet place.

Deny King was not a man who could be considered famous in the conventional sense. To some his achievements may seem small in the global sense of things, but Deny King was special because he achieved the rare distinction of becoming a legend in his own lifetime. The list of those who have expressed their respect for his outstanding contribution includes those who have taken the immense trouble to visit him personally at Melaleuca. I refer to individuals such as explorer Sir Edmund Hilary, photographer Lord Snowdon, and our present GovernorGeneral, Bill Hayden.

Deny King symbolised the attributes of our forefathers, which have made Australia such an outstanding nation. He battled the elements and won. He knew loneliness and failure and he survived. He overcame adversity to build a home in the wilderness and to raise a family, while at the same time providing hospitality for anybody who called upon him. I did not know Deny King personally but, like thousands of others, I have been touched by this man, his modesty and the contribution he made towards ensuring that the unique nature of Tasmania's southern natural heritage was brought to the world's attention.

Although a tin miner, Deny King was a conservationist long before it was fashionable. He was a naturalist with a concern for our native flora and fauna while many species were being eradicated from our continent. Deny King sought to open up the wilderness to those who valued it as much as he did, and in return he shared his own knowledge, much of which had been gained through his own experiences with those who were interested. He was born in 1906 on a farm outside Judbury in the Huon Valley and later joined his father, Charles, at a tin mining operation which he had established in the early 1930s at Cox Bight near Port Davey. Eventually he moved to Melaleuca just after the World War to work his own tin mine.

Those who are familiar with the ruggedness of Tasmania's southern coast would have some idea of the adversity which Deny King and his wife, Margaret, experienced in establishing their home. Everything had to be shipped into the area by boat as the area was, and remains, virtually isolated from the outside world. Visitors largely consisted of fishing boat crews and those members of pleasure boats who were game enough to make the journey south.

Such was the scale of Deny King's independence that he eventually built his own airstrip near his home and built his own windmill to generate his power. In recognition of the contribution which Deny King made to this southern wilderness area, last year the State Government gave him a 20-year crown lease on his existing property so that he could continue to live in the area which had become his home, even though it is within the world heritage area.

On behalf of the Senate, I wish to extend our deepest sympathy to his surviving family-daughters, Mary and Janet, son-in-law, Geoff Fenton, and his grandchildren. I know that many throughout the world will feel a distinct sense of loss at his passing. Deny King will never be replaced, and neither can the unique area of Tasmania's south which he sought to protect. Deny King should be remembered as an individual who led us to a greater understanding of Tasmania's special heritage.

MEDIA RELEASE
SENATOR BADEN TEAGUE
OPPOSITION URGES AUSTUDY HELP FOR RURAL STUDENTS

The Senate has passed a resolution moved by Senator Baden Teague (Liberal, South Australia) on behalf of the Opposition urging the Federal Government to give immediate help to students who are being denied Austudy although their families have been hit by the rural crisis.
Senator Teague explained that his objectives with the motion were:
1. To persuade the Government to act immediately to introduce emergency educational assistance by means of hardship provisions.
2. To ensure the special extension of Austudy benefits will be specifically targeted to rural families in financial difficulties as a result of the rural crisis.

3. To gain changes favourable to rural families in the Government's administration of the Austudy program especially by lowering of the Australian Valuation Office's estimates of rural property values thus removing the present cause of prevalent appeals.
At the same time, the Senate rejected attempts by the Australian Democrats to disallow a number of Austudy regulations.
Senator Teague said that the Opposition opposed the disallowance because it would have crippled the entire Austudy scheme, with no payments being possible from 13 May.

``The motion to disallow the entire assets test was not targeted to benefit those suffering from the rural crisis. Most of those who would benefit from complete abolition of the assets test are outside rural areas.

``The cost to the budget would be substantial. The cost of ending the assets test would be $57 million. The cost of disallowing other regulations so that eligibility became almost universal would be $1200 million.
``The Opposition insists that the right course is one that targets those in most financial need for special help.''

Senator Teague told the Senate: ``I want to say to the bush, to rural families in the country, that we understand the burden they are feeling and we are responding directly. We know the burden that is being felt in the Mallee, in the Eyre Peninsula, in the west out to Meekatharra, in Tasmania and in Queensland. We know there is an enormous struggle. I am deeply moved when I hear medical practitioners say that all their patients showing up in the middle of the Mallee have distress symptoms. On behalf of the Opposition, I want to assure those living in country areas that we have heard the cry. We will continue to be with them; we want to share the burden with them; and we want to ensure that they know that the representatives elected from rural areas are bringing those cries of anguish to our deliberations here in the Parliament.''

Senator Teague on behalf of the Opposition reemphasised the Liberal-National Party policy to abolish the assets test on the Isolated Children's Assistance Scheme and to maintain its opposition to any assets test on Family Allowances.
The resolution passed by the Senate on 13 May stated:

``That the Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from Austudy by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.''

AUSTUDY: LIBS/NATS ABANDON
FARM STUDENTS

The Liberal and National parties today rejected a move in the Senate by the Australian Democrats to make Austudy immediately available to students from many struggling farming and small business families.

Senator Lees said the Liberal education spokesman, Dr David Kemp, and a range of coalition speakers admitted the assets test was the cause of great problems.

Dr Kemp said on May 8: ``The rural crisis has exposed a significant weakness in Austudy. Families with little or no real income are being excluded by the asset test from Austudy and as a result are having to withdraw their children from education.''

Senator Lees said part of the problem was the Liberals were paranoid about getting another bucketing from Paul Keating. PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 20 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the chemical manufacturer Velsicol disclosed to federal health authorities the presence of the following additives and/or contaminants in heptachlor: (a) heptachlor; (b) gammachlordane; (c) alphachlordane; (d) 4,5,6,7,8, 8-hexachloro-3a,4,7, 7a-tetrahydro-4, methano-lH-idene; (e) carbontetrachloride; (f) hexachlorobutadiene; (g) hexachlorocyclopentadiene; and (h) propylene oxide; if so, for each of the substances, when did Velsicol disclose each contaminant and/or additive.

(2) Has the chemical manufacturer Velsicol disclosed to federal health authorities the presence of the following additives and/or contaminants in technical chlordane: (a) alphachlordane; (b) gammachlordane; (c) heptachlor; (d) trans-nonachlor; (e) `isomer-2-chlordene'; (f) betachlordene; (g) chlordene; (h) related compounds; (i) propylene oxide; and (j) hexachlorocyclopentadiene; if so, for each of the substances, when did Velsicol disclose each contaminant and/or additive.

(3) Was the Committee on Toxicity of the National Health and Medical Research Council informed that: (a) technical heptachlor; and (b) technical chlordane contain the contaminants and/or additives listed in (1) and (2) respectively.

(4) In relation to (1) and (2), did the company breach any of the requirements for disclosure under either current or past legislation governing the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
The listed additives and/or contaminants in technical heptachlor were included in submissions made to federal health authorities on 14th March 1986.
(2) Yes.

The listed additives and/or contaminants in technical chlordane were included in submissions made to federal health authorities on 14th March 1986. The identity of the material `isomer-2-chlordene' cannot be established from that name. However, several chlordene isomers were identified and disclosed.
(3) The Committee on Toxicity was aware of the complexity of the technical mixtures and their approximate compositions.

(4) The requirements of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act (1988) have not been breached. Registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals is the responsibility of the States and Territories.
